value.Name: Alpha Phi Omega
value.Description:
Sigma Chapter at Northwestern is comprised of over 40 active members who focus on leadership, friendship and service.

The major focus of our operations is service opportunities. Members help out on campus and in the local community. We have a variety of involvements including Campus Kitchens, Challah for Hunger, Center for Independent Futures, and Housing Opportunities for Women.

We also have fellowship activities like dinners, a formal, and trips downtown. Members get to know each other and have fun hanging out and doing service with their friends.

There are also plenty of leadership opportunities ranging from leading members for a service opportunity to committee chairs and the exec board. We focus on leadership development and work to create opportunities for members.

Finally, we are a national Greek organization so we have long-standing traditions as well as a national network of members. We recently hosted a conference and attend conferences every year to meet other members, participate in leadership training, and shape the future of the fraternity.

Please check out our website or email us at alpha-phi-omega@u.northwestern.edu if you have any questions!

Due to COVID-19, we will shift mainly to online service opportunities and fellowship activities, although there will also be opportunities to meet on campus for those living in the Evanston/Chicago area! We hope to return to fully in-person events when it becomes possible.
value.Summary: APO is a gender-inclusive national service fraternity with open recruitment at the beginning of every quarter. Members focus on planning and participating in a variety of community service activities as well as fellowship activities.

value.Name: Alpha Psi Lambda National, Inc.
value.Description:
Alpha Psi Lambda National, Inc. is a Co-educational Fraternity geared towards the goals of Latino students on university campuses. As the fastest-growing minority in this country, it is becoming more important that the Latino community continues their education. This trend has also brought with it a need for cultural awareness, cultural identity, and cross-cultural understanding. As a result, there is an increased need for Alpha Psi Lambda for which we try to assist in the identity of our culture. This trend has been demonstrated by the growth of our Fraternity. 

While we are a Latino interest Fraternity, Alpha Psi Lambda has welcomed people from a broad spectrum of cultures across the globe. Alpha Psi Lambda stands as one family united. Our strength lies in our ability to focus on our culture while appreciating the diversity of others. 

The Latino culture is very strongly rooted in family and support, which allows Alpha Psi Lambda to provide those same roots to our Fraternity. Alpha Psi Lambda, to its members, is more than just a Fraternity. It creates that true family support, brotherhood, and sisterhood, at a time in a student's life when it is most important. Our membership prides itself on the values of Familia, Culture, Academics, Service, and Leadership.
value.Summary: Alpha Psi Lambda was established on February 11, 1985, at The Ohio State University.  We believe in the concept of Familia to create a support network for our members while creating the real-world experience of working with anyone.

value.Name: Alternative Student Breaks
value.Description:
Alternative Student Breaks seeks to educate Northwestern students of all majors and backgrounds by sponsoring a Chicago based service-learning immersion during the academic break between winter and spring quarters. Service-learning is the heart of ASB, which promotes a critical approach to social justice and service that centers the communities affected by a social issue. 

 

ASB 2023 will take place March 17 - March 24, 2023. The immersive experience will be capped at 30 students. Participants will receive housing, food, and CTA passes as part of the experience. Trip cost is supported by Northwestern so participants have no financial barrier.

You can declare your interest in participating in spring break 2023 by completing an application during January 2023. You can receive an application by emailing val.buchanan@northwestern.edu at that time.

More information can be found on the website for Leadership Development and Community Engagement at Northwestern.
value.Summary: Alternative Student Breaks provides a guided community based service-learning experience for 30 Northwestern students in between winter and spring quarters.

value.Name: American Medical Women's Association
value.Description:
The American Medical Women’s Association Northwestern University chapter aims to foster an enriching environment for women in science and the medical profession. We hope to give back to the community through a variety of events spreading awareness about women’s health issues. 

Our Objectives:  

…to provide peer mentorship to undergraduate students pursuing careers in science and medicine

…to spread awareness about women’s health issues on campus and the community at large

…to create a positive space for women pursuing careers in science and medicine
value.Summary: The American Medical Women’s Association Northwestern University chapter aims to foster an enriching environment for women in science and the medical profession.

value.Name: American Society of Civil Engineers
value.Summary: We are the Northwestern student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers, a professional society dedicated to advancing members' goals and passions in civil engineering.

value.Name: AMPED
value.Description: AMPED is a weekend music mentorship program that connects Northwestern students with incarcerated young men at the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center. The “Saturday practice sessions” are offered for 2 hours every Saturday in the CCJTDC music lab to young men who show interest, talent, and desire to hone the skills they learn in their once a week classes. The sessions are facilitated by undergraduate & graduate mentors from Northwestern University, who provide musical assistance and support for the students. AMPED aims to help develop the students’ music composition skills through the use of GarageBand software while offering structured and trusting mentorships between the NU students and CCJTDC students.
value.Summary: We are a group of students that go down to the Juvenile Temporary Detention Center (JTDC) in Chicago to mentor residents through creating hip-hop music through Garage Band.

value.Name: APIDA Town Halls
value.Description: Please add.
value.Summary: TBA

value.Name: Applause for a Cause
value.Description:
Applause for a Cause is a philanthropic, student-run film production company. Our members annually write, produce, direct, and edit a feature length film (~90 minutes) to premiere in May and to raise donations for the chosen beneficiary of that year. In the past we have worked with local and national organizations including the Make-A-Wish foundation, the Howard Area Community Center, and Connections for the Homeless.

Our production timeline starts in the summer with screenplay submissions. Then once a script is chosen, we hold crew petitions and casting auditions when the school year starts in fall. Production occurs during the winter, and finally we edit and roll out the red carpet in the spring.

We are completely student run, and encourage students of all studies and film backgrounds (even if you have none at all) to join our organization so that you can experience college film-making and meet some great people along the way.

Not a student? We accept year-long support, advice, and donations and if you are in town, we invite you to attend the premiere.

It takes a village to make a feature, so we encourage you to participate in any way you can!
value.Summary: Applause for a Cause annually produces and premieres an original feature-length film, in support of an annually-selected philanthropic organization.

value.Name: Arch Society
value.Description:
The Arch Society is a group of student ambassadors sponsored by the Northwestern Alumni Association (NAA). Members will support and develop university-related programs and community-wide events to strengthen the relationships between alumni, students, faculty, and staff and to foster a sense of pride and community. Meetings occur once a month during the academic year with additional meetings or program support occurring as needed.

Candidates are chosen and serve as representatives throughout their time at Northwestern. Each member of the Arch Society will serve on one of the four committees:

(1) Class Programming Committee shall be responsible for class-specific programming to increase NAA touch points with current students between Wildcat Welcome and Senior Week (i.e., Sophomore Welcome Back, Senior Class Picnic)
(2) Marketing & Outreach Committee shall be responsible for social media presence/content creation and outreach to student groups on campus (i.e., supporting social justice and mental health initiatives)
(3) Traditions Committee shall be responsible for promoting current traditions and initiating new traditions (i.e., NU Day @ Wrigley, Northwestern Night at the Art Institute)
(4) Homecoming Committee shall support Homecoming programs, recruitment, and student-alumni engagement initiatives (i.e., Homecoming Social)
value.Summary: Arch Society members act as student ambassadors of the Northwestern Alumni Association. We support and develop university-related programs and community-wide events to strengthen the relationships between alumni, students, faculty, and staff.

value.Name: Archery Club
value.Description: We're a co-ed sports club practicing recreational and competitive archery for educational fun. People of all experience levels are welcome. We provide training for beginners, 1-on-1 coaching for serious competitors, and equipment & an archery range for all university-affiliated members!
value.Summary: We're a co-ed sports club practicing recreational and competitive archery. People of all experience levels are welcome. We provide training for beginners, 1-on-1 coaching for serious competitors, and equipment & an archery range for all!

value.Name: Area Councils
value.Description:
Area Councils are student-led organizations that serve as the hall-governance for Northwestern’s residential communities. If you are craving an opportunity to be a leader on campus and play a pivotal role in organizing in-person social programs and initiatives for the next academic year.

Area Councils are composed of four elected officer positions and selected building representatives. Elected officers will work closely with the members of the area leadership team through their advisors, who will ensure council activities comply with university policies and procedures. 

We encourage you to be a part of our Residential Services Area Councils!
value.Summary: Area Councils are student-led organizations that serve as the hall-governance for Northwestern’s residential areas.

value.Name: Armenian Student Association
value.Description: TBA
value.Summary: Cultural interest group for Armenians and friends of Armenia

value.Name: Art Union
value.Description:
Art Union is Northwestern’s premier art club.

We aspire to promote and develop a community of Northwestern artists, helping to nurture relationships, artistic skills, and various talents from a diverse network of students, through intentional art-making and sharing of the love of art practice. AU seeks to emphasize the art practice of artists at Northwestern, using their passion and skills for art to create a strong community within NU. From sketching and drawing nights, painting sessions, trips to the museums, and chill hangouts at local areas to simply get together and make art, we want AU to nurture the general public’s love for art practice, creating an art-loving family for all.

For updates, join our Groupme: https://groupme.com/join_group/62920933/1IS5tV4A
value.Summary:
Art Union is Northwestern’s premier art club.
We aspire to promote and develop a community of Northwestern artists, helping to nurture relationships, artistic skills, and various talents from a diverse network of students, through intentional art-making.

value.Name: ARTivate
value.Description:
ARTivate is a community arts engagement initiative that aims to use art to create a more diverse and interconnected community, provide safe spaces, and improve the overall well-being of individuals. We plan to host on and off-campus art workshops and guest speakers to reach this goal and to create a centralized digital platform to ensure accessibility and transparency of our program. We believe that art empowers and heals. We hope to share our love for the arts with both our NU and Chicagoland communities, while striving to create positive change through the arts. 

Our social justice arts initiative hopes to implement an art engagement program that would allow students and faculty to branch out and engage students at NU and neighboring schools in the performing and visual arts. This effort can be an effective way for the many NU students who are passionate about art to relieve stress while giving back to and learning about their local communities. Our program focuses strongly on providing a space for students to escape the rapid lifestyle that we constantly embody and extend the passions of students to the larger Evanston community. Through our efforts, we hope to highlight the importance of acknowledging and respecting the arts in our daily lives. We will provide students with the opportunity to embrace their passion or find a new passion for the arts.
value.Summary: ARTivate is a community arts engagement initiative that aims to use art to create a more diverse and interconnected community, provide safe spaces, and empower individuals to express and use their voices through art.

value.Name: Arts Alliance
value.Description:
Arts Alliance is the oldest and largest student arts group at Northwestern University. Founded in 1974 by a collection of arts groups looking to share space, Arts Alliance has grown to become one of the largest student arts organizations in the country. Its annual season consists of three mainstage shows and two Mee-Ow Improv & Sketch Comedy shows. Arts Alliance Executive Board consists of twenty three members committed to bringing accessible, exciting, and entertaining theatrical experiences to the Northwestern and Evanston communities.

All Arts Alliance programming revolves around the three pillars of our mission statement: art that is easy to relate to, art that is easy to speak with, and art that is easy to reach. We tell stories that resonate with our community members by delivering theatre that they want to see without physical or financial barriers. 

Arts Alliance is a non-profit student arts organization committed to providing diverse, accessible, and fulfilling artistic experiences to enrich the Northwestern University community. We continue to seek out new artistic opportunities while providing a positive atmosphere in which students can learn and work alongside a committed and supportive board to create professional-quality productions.
value.Summary: Arts Alliance creates art that reflects, deepens, and challenges the Northwestern community. We provide a positive atmosphere in which students can learn and work alongside a committed and supportive board to create professional-quality productions.

value.Name: Asian American InterVarsity Christian Fellowship
value.Description: Asian American InterVarsity is a group of students on campus who grow together to love God, His Word, His people and His purpose in the world. Students work together to find genuine friendship and a real community through small groups, one-on-one discipleships, and large group gatherings.
value.Summary: Asian American InterVarsity is a group of students and staff who strive together to grow in love for God, his Word, his people, and his purposes in the world. We seek to be a witnessing community to the Asian and Asian American community at NU.

value.Name: Asian American Student Journalists
value.Description: Affinity space for Northwestern's Asian American student journalists to build community and access resources such as mentorship, opportunities to interact with industry professionals, updates on internships/jobs, and more
value.Summary: Affinity space for Northwestern's Asian American student journalists

value.Name: Asian Pacific American Coalition
value.Description:
In recognition of the heterogeneity of Asian America, the Asian Pacific American Coalition is a sociopolitical group that provides a space for students who identify as Asian American and Pacific Islander to connect, learn, organize, and ultimately resist systems of domination. We recognize that our liberation must be collective because of the interconnected nature of oppressive power structures. From our unique position as similarly racialized peoples, we build community and raise awareness of historical, social, and political issues that affect all marginalized communities through the following:
  • Collective learning
  • Support systems
  • Programming, both educational and advocacy-based
  • Coalition-building
APAC’s history began in 1991, under the name of Asian American Advisory Board (AAAB). It started out as an umbrella organization for all of the Asian/Asian American student groups to coordinate and guide their different activities. In 1992, the AAAB gained A-status from the Northwestern’s Associated Student Government. The organization began to make headlines in 1995 when APAC organized a successful hunger strike fighting for the creation of an Asian American Studies Program. The hunger strike garnered public support from universities all over the country and inspired a new generation of young Asian/Americans. In 2003, AAAB officially changed its name to The Asian Pacific American Coalition (APAC). The new name was intended to be more expansive and reflective of the diversity, heterogeneity, and differences in experiences of Asian American communities. Along with the name change, APAC remade its constitution and redefined its mission statement towards a more holistic outlook, making commitments to community building by addressing political, cultural, and social issues both within our own communities and with the rest of NU’s student population through various programs and events. In the past, APAC has hosted events such as Asian American History Month, a screening of Better Luck Tomorrow with cast and director Justin Lin, Espresso Expressions, and speakers such as actor George Takei, music video director Joseph Kahn, SuChin Pak of MTV, Japanese Breakfast, and Alok Vaid-Menon.
 
APAC strives to achieve the following:
  • Commit to accessibility and inclusion and decentering East Asian communities/supremacy
  • Recognize differences in lived experience and racialization within the umbrella of Asian, Asian American, and Pacific Islander peoples, as well as the experiences of multiracial peoples
  • Engage and mobilize the student community through activism and advocacy
  • Undertake intersectional grassroots activism and advocacy in the larger Northwestern community, Evanston, and Chicago
  • Foster collective healing from historical, intergenerational, and individual trauma
  • Empower individuals with marginalized identities

If you are interested in joining APAC, interest forms are open near the beginning of every quarter -- keep an eye out on the FB page and Instagram, or send our presidents Russell Leung (russellleung2024@u.northwestern.edu), Sophia Liu (sophialiu2024@u.northwestern.edu) or Neha Ramani (neharamani2024@u.northwestern.edu) an email!
value.Summary: From our unique position as similarly racialized peoples, Asian Pacific American Coalition builds community and power, in addition to raising awareness of historical, social, and political issues that affect marginalized communities at large.

value.Name: Associated Press Sports Editors Student Chapter
value.Description:
The APSE student chapter at Northwestern has multiple goals, including short-term metrics like the attendance of organization meetings and creation of an events schedule for bonding and networking, as well as the eventual long-term goal of removing financial barriers for students and providing a new window of opportunity for all interested. 

One of the first short-term goals is to have students attend the regional meetings, national convention and other programming. Attending these events is not only a learning experience for chapter members, but also a way to gain access to other journalists and chapters of the organization to build connections. Additionally, it could help inspire members to create networks with experienced sports journalists. 

Prospective events like resume workshops and article critiques with our faculty advisor, J.A. Adande, and other APSE journalists is something that will continue next year. These are a unique way to prepare for networking with APSE editors, as well as learn from chapter members. The events would be open to everyone – not just chapter members – which would allow individuals to take part in a learning experience, as well as show them the different elements of work that the chapter does. 

A long-term goal for the chapter, which we hope to build on after our first year in existence, is creating a fundraising plan to subsidize trips to APSE conferences in the future. The key tenet of this organization is to introduce the benefits of APSE and its programming to students and, as previously mentioned, attending these meetings are a great way to grow as a chapter. Students can learn not only about sports writing at these events, but also the organizational structure of their favorite publications. Having enough money for a financial plan to fund these trips will allow students to not have to worry about the cost of such a trip, and be able to pursue their passion of sports journalism without short-term financial distress, removing further barriers from the complicated industry. Rachel Crader, the Chair of APSE’s Great Lakes Region, has communicated with the proposed chapter’s leadership regarding waived fees for student workers, and in some scenarios, additional covered costs for people participating on panels. Another option for ensuring students can attend APSE events is working with Northwestern’s Student Organization Finance Office, which supports a wide range of organizations on campus. 

Another long-term goal that we hope to create after our first year would be having more APSE editors come to our sessions – whether in-person or virtually – to help members work on their resumes, cover letters and clips, as mentioned on the website. One of these individuals, Naila-Jean Meyers of the Star Tribune, spoke to our chapter this year as one of our multiple guests. While chapter members will likely end up networking with some of these journalists, it could be a great opportunity for the entire chapter to learn from a true industry professional, and give the individual the chance to share stories and skills with passionate students. This provides interested members both a glimpse at the editing side of the profession, as well as preparation for the industry and what employers look for in writing.
value.Summary: The Northwestern student chapter of Associated Press Sports Editors, a national sports journalism organization.

value.Name: Associated Student Government
value.Description: ASG is the Associated Student Government of Northwestern, a group of undergraduate students devoted to working on behalf of the Northwestern community. ASG discusses and acts on ways to make Northwestern an overall better experience for students. We work with Northwestern administrators to bring change to the university, but we also provide services and funding directly to students. ASG is comprised of a student Senate – broadly representative of the varied student interests at Northwestern – an executive board, and 10 working committees that address issues affecting student life, academics, relations with Evanston, student groups, and more. ASG believes in building a better Northwestern.
value.Summary: ASG is the Associated Student Government of Northwestern, a group of undergraduate students devoted to working on behalf of the Northwestern community.

value.Name: Association for Women in Sports Media
value.Description: The Northwestern Chapter of the Association for Women in Sports Media is a network and advocacy group for women in the sports industry. Open to both males and females, AWSM at Northwestern aims to prepare its members for their professional careers through group meetings, guest-speaker insight, industry connections, and other unique opportunities.
value.Summary: Network and Advocacy Group for Women in the Sports Industry

value.Name: Association of Kenyan Students
value.Description: TBA
value.Summary: TBA

value.Name: Association of Undergraduate Women in Science
value.Description:
The purpose of our organization is to provide a space for students identifying as women and other underrepresented genders who are pursuing studies in the sciences at Northwestern. Meetings will involve discussion of the unique challenges faced by women in science, as well as discussions with female faculty or graduate students who are also studying science. There will be opportunities for volunteerism, professional development, and academic support throughout the year.

If you missed us at the club fair and/or want to get added to our listserv, just fill out this google form! https://tinyurl.com/auws2020

We hope to see you soon!
value.Summary:
The purpose of our organization is to provide a space for woman-identifying and nonbinary
students who are pursuing studies in the sciences at Northwestern.

value.Name: Asterik A cappella
value.Description: Asterik is Northwestern's premier all male range voices a cappella group, founded in 1994.
value.Summary: Asterik is Northwestern's premier all male range voices a cappella group, founded in 1994.

value.Name: AstroTutors
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Athletes in Action
value.Description:
Athletes in Action is a interdenominational Christian ministry. We desire to provide every athlete at Northwestern an opportunity to hear how they can know God through Jesus Christ. We are committed to do this as a community of believers laboring together in unity.

If you are curious about this relationship with God, or want to learn more about Christianity a great resource is Knowing God Personally. Also check out EveryAthlete.com
value.Summary: Athletes in Action is a interdenominational Christian ministry. We desire to provide every athlete at Northwestern an opportunity to hear how they can know God through Jesus Christ. We are committed to do this as a community.

value.Name: Athletics & Recreation
value.Description: The Department of Athletics and Recreation: Fitness, Aquatics and Recreational Sports oversees the sport clubs on campus.
value.Summary: The Department of Athletics and Recreation: Fitness, Aquatics and Recreational Sports oversees the sport clubs on campus.

value.Name: Athletics Sustainability Committee
value.Summary: ASC has a mission to decrease the environmental footprint of the Northwestern Department of Athletics and Recreation by increasing awareness among  students, athletes, staff, and fans and reducing waste within practices, games, and facilities.

value.Name: Aviation Club
value.Description: Aviation Club helps aviation enthusiasts at Northwestern explore their interest in and expand their knowledge of aviation, including, but not limited to, general, commercial, and military aviation. It fosters interests in students new to aviation by offering a place to explore it in a supportive, knowledgeable, and connected environment. We help Northwestern students connect with fellow aviators to expand their network of colleagues on campus, providing more opportunities to share and participate in their passion with others. We also help Northwestern students interested in a career in aviation connect with advisors and opportunities to pursue their goals during and after college. Aviation is a very cost-prohibitive activity. We want to make it available to all Northwestern students in as many ways as possible. This can be achieved in many forms, and we are excited to build on our current plans to bring it to Northwestern students as best as possible.
value.Summary: Aviation Club is Northwestern's only student organization dedicated to the social aspects of aviation. Dedicated to helping people expand their knowledge of and interest in aviation, we host a variety of meetings, events and trips each quarter.

value.Name: Ayers Residential College of Commerce and Industry
value.Description:
Thomas G. Ayers Hall is on north campus and houses 170 students in mostly double-
occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
value.Summary: Thomas G. Ayers Hall is on north campus and houses 170 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This building

value.Name: B Burlesque
value.Description: B. Burlesque is a dance interest group that serves to teach burlesque dance to students of color and showcase their performances in the annual burlesque show during winter quarter. Promoting body and sex positivity, B. Burlesque offers workshops led by professional burlesque dancers and trips to burlesque shows to get a better understanding of the art. Through 2 months of rehearsals, students will prepare for the annual show to showcase their unique routines.
value.Summary: A dance interest group for students of color to learn and perform burlesque dances!

value.Name: Badminton Club
value.Description:
Come join us at Blomquist Recreation Center every Tuesday & Thursday from 8-10! Click me for all information! 

 

Please join our GroupMe and follow our instagram @nu.badminton. Announcements will primarily be posted on GroupMe.


To allow everyone a chance to play, matches are one game to 21 (rally scoring) with a brief warm-up period. Rackets and birdies are readily available to borrow. Due to space restrictions, doubles is usually played.
value.Summary: Club Badminton provides court space for undergraduates, graduate students, professors, and the general public of all skill levels to play badminton. We strive to be an open, encouraging space for individuals to connect and have fun through the sport.

value.Name: Baja SAE
value.Description: The Baja SAE team's goal is to enrich the Northwestern experience through the production of a competitive off-road racing vehicle by inspiring creative automotive design, forging marketable leadership and technical skills, and building a close-knit engineering community. The one-man, dune buggy type car must be prepared to face the most rugged terrain—rocks, creeks, snow, jumps, and mud—and keep their driver safe through all driving conditions including a roll over. The team consists of students, mostly from McCormick, who simply like to build cars and play in the mud.
value.Summary: The Baja SAE team is a team of undergraduate students who design, build and race an all-terrain vehicle each year. Students are challenged to pull all their engineering knowledge and skills together to engineer a safe, functional racing machine.

value.Name: Balkan Student Association
value.Summary: The goal of BSA is to promote the cultures and languages of the Balkan countries by creating a space where individuals who originate from the Balkan Peninsula and individuals who are interested in our region can connect easily and build a community.

value.Name: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros
value.Description: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros was established in 2012 by 6 freshmen Chicanas to create a space at Northwestern that made them feel comfortable enough to share and embrace their artistic side, their culture, and their roots. We strive to critically preserve our Mexican culture by showcasing folklórico at Northwestern and the surrounding communities and to increase awareness of Mexican ancestry and to serve as a catalyst for others to take pride in their own backgrounds.
value.Summary: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano de Northwestern: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros (Rhythm of My Ancestors) is a traditional Mexican dance group dedicated to spreading folklore music and dance on Northwestern's campus and the surrounding community.

value.Name: Ballroom Latin and Swing Team
value.Description:
BLAST (Ballroom, Latin, and Swing Team) is an undergraduate partner dancing community. Our club is split into two main seasons - a competition season (fall - early spring) and a showcase season (mid-winter - spring), interspersed with social dance classes and workshops. New members are welcome to join at any point of the year, with no prior experience necessary to participate in either season. The dancesport dance classes are open to anyone and begin in the fall shortly after new student week. Auditions for the showcase occur early in Winter quarter and then subsequent rehearsals will occur throughout the year until showtime in Spring.  Classes, workshops, and social dance opportunities range in style from social dances like swing or salsa, to more formal ballroom dances like waltz and tango.

Our goal as an organization is to create a partner dancing community here at Northwestern. All dancers are welcome to attend our classes, workshops, and social events.

If you want to get more involved, the best ways to become a formal member of BLAST is to regularly show up to dancesport classes and actively participate in either the competitive or performance seasons.
value.Summary: BLAST, short for “Ballroom, Latin, and Swing Team”, is a partner dance organization committed to creating a community for all levels of dancers. We provide quality instruction alongside competitive, social and performance dance opportunities

value.Name: Be The Match
value.Description:
The Northwestern University chapter of Be The Match On Campus aims to increase awareness of the need for more young registry members, educate others about the under representation of ethnic minorities in the registry, and hold campus-wide marrow donor registry drives to give the entire student body the opportunity to join in this global effort. 

We welcome any student to join! In Be the Match, we partner with other groups to host events, have fundraising activities, hold registry drives, host speakers, and more. Members will be involved in planning and holding events. For more information, feel free to contact us or check out our facebook page!
value.Summary: Be the Match aims to register students and faculty for the national marrow donor program, and raise awareness of the minority ethnic groups that are underrepresented within the registry.

value.Name: Bel Canto Ballet
value.Description: n/a
value.Summary: n/a

value.Name: Best Buddies
value.Description: Best Buddies is an international nonprofit organization dedicated to enhancing the lives of those with intellectual and/or physical disabilities by providing opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, and leadership.  It was founded in 1989 by Anthony Kennedy Shriver. Each member of Northwestern's Best Buddies chapter is matched with an adult with disabilities. The buddy pair maintains regular contact throughout the year and meets several times a quarter for fun activities and themed outings. The chapter also promotes disability awareness on campus and throughout the community.
value.Summary: Best Buddies is an international nonprofit organization dedicated to enhancing the lives of those with intellectual and/or physical disabilities by providing opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, and leadership.

value.Name: Bhakti Yoga Society
value.Description: Bhakti Yoga Society provides students the opportunity to experience yoga and spiritual culture from ancient India through a blend of yoga classes, small group discussions, meditation sessions, vegetarian cooking classes and speaker events that provide ancient prescriptions for modern maladies. Bhakti Yoga is the Vedic Science of connecting with the Higher Consciousness through devotion, bringing about genuine care for all people and things. People of all backgrounds are welcome! We meet on Fridays at 6:00 p.m. for yoga, guided meditation, discussions and dinner.
value.Summary: Bhakti Yoga Society provides students the opportunity to experience yoga and spiritual culture from ancient India through a blend of yoga classes, small group discussions, guided meditation sessions and more!

value.Name: Bienen Student Advisory Board
value.Summary: An organization that helps connect the student body of Bienen to the faculty!

value.Name: Bienestar: Latinx Service Club
value.Description:
We aim to service the marginalized and socioeconomically disadvantaged Latinx communities many of us come from; including but not limited to ethnicity, FGLI status, uninsured, and Spanish speaking communities. We will do this by bringing together students from all backgrounds with the common goal of servicing Latinx communities  to create several group initiatives, such as: college admissions talks at public high schools in predominantly Black/Brown communities, Spanish interpretation/translation at free health clinics, work within uninsured populations, and promoting youth health via creative initiatives (i.e teaching guitar to students without financial barriers).

A secondary goal just as important to us is to create a community among Latinx pre-health students which we have found Northwestern to lack in. From personal experience, many of us have experienced isolation at Northwestern or become overwhelmed by academic and social demands, which for many of us, are new experiences as first-gen students. This club will be a space for many to network and empower one another through our academic journeys, although not Bienestar's exclusive goal.
value.Summary: Bienestar is an identity-based service club. Our mission is to unite Latinx students and allies to service the communities many of us come from not limited to race, class, or socioeconomic status. We aim to support Latinx wellness on campus and beyond.

value.Name: Billiards Club
value.Description: A community for all those interested in billiards regardless of skill level! We hold our meetings and events at the Norris Game Room located on the Norris basement level.
value.Summary: A community for all those interested in billiards (pool) regardless of skill level! We hold our meetings and events at the Norris Game Room located on the Norris basement level.

value.Name: Biology Students Association
value.Summary: Biology Students Association (BSA) at Northwestern seeks to connect students with a common interest in biology, provide a forum for discussion, and bridge the gap between textbook knowledge and real-world science.

value.Name: Biomedical Engineering Society
value.Description: The Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) at Northwestern University offers the chance to establish leadership skills, networking, and career development opportunities. BMES also facilitates community among biomedical engineering undergrads through social events and opportunities to interact with faculty in a casual setting. Members can participate in BMES through attending club events, joining committees, and competing in biomedical-focused design teams.
value.Summary: The Biomedical Engineering Society at Northwestern University brings together biomedical engineering students and faculty members to promote academic, professional, and social collaborations.

value.Name: Biomedical Informatics and Data Science
value.Description:
The purpose of the Biomedical Informatics and Data Science (BIDS) Student Group is to create a community for biomedical informatics and data science students across Northwestern University’s Evanston and Chicago campuses. The main goals of the group are as follows:

  • Develop an internal and external network for BIDS students and alumni.
  • Foster an environment for discussion related to BIDS work at Northwestern University and beyond.
  • Increase awareness of current BIDS research and promote cross-program collaborations between the domains of informatics, data science, medicine, health and biology.
  • Create an avenue for inter-institutional collaborations with other BIDS student groups across Chicago.
  • Promote additional opportunities for BIDS students through lectures and workshops.
  • Serve as an informal advisory board to BIDS Faculty in curriculum planning and program development.

The main benefits of joining the BIDS student group are to:

  • Develop professional and leadership skills.
  • Network with other BIDS students, alumni, and faculty.
  • Gain a deeper knowledge and understanding of BIDS research, educational programs, and outside projects.
  • Have fun with other BIDS students at Northwestern University!
value.Summary: The purpose of the Biomedical Informatics and Data Science (BIDS) Student Group is to create a community for biomedical informatics and data science students across Northwestern University’s Evanston and Chicago campuses.

value.Name: Biotech Club @ Northwestern
value.Description: The purpose of Northwestern Biotech Group is to build a community of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who aspire to become successful professionals and leaders in the life sciences and biotechnology industry. Our intended goals are to provide professional development, networking and support for the broader Northwestern graduate and postdoctoral community and bridge the gap between academia and industry. We will serve as a platform to connect students and trainees with companies and alumni to expose them to the life sciences sector.
value.Summary: The purpose of Northwestern Biotech Group is to build a community of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who aspire to become successful professionals and leaders in the life sciences and biotechnology industry.

value.Name: Black Formal
value.Description: A collective of students, representative of members that both do and do not hold formal leadership positions in Black student organizations, pulled together to identify an event based on a community need. This event was intended to mirror other Northwestern-funded student formal affairs- with students dressing up and going to an off-campus venue for an evening of entertainment, food, and fun. The Black community has not had an event like this in recent years. Most formals or balls that occur within the Black community are hosted by Black Greek-letter organizations. This formal is unique because it is not affiliated with any student organization in the community and aims to create an inclusive space. This formal is in celebration of the Black community, and seeks to fulfill the needs expressed in the Black Student Experience Report.
value.Summary: Black formal organizes a yearly formal in celebration of the Black community, and seeks to fulfill the needs expressed in the Black Student Experience Report.

value.Name: Black Graduate Student Association
value.Summary: Founded in 1996, the Black Graduate Student Association (BGSA), a graduate student organization within The Graduate School (TGS), aims to support the academic, professional, and social growth of graduate students of color from underrepresented groups.

value.Name: Black Health & Wellness Collaborative
value.Description: Our mission is to provide a safe space for mental health discourse and reduce the stigma surrounding mental health within the Black community through collective conversation and advocacy. We intend to be a peer-based support system for Black students that prioritizes Black mental health needs and improves the Black experience at Northwestern. Throughout its first and subsequent years, the Black Health & Wellness committee plans to offer weekly seminar-style discussions about mental health, physical well-being, and collective self-determination. We also plan to work with POC-focused mental health nonprofits in the Chicago area and the Black psychologists at CAPS in order to highlight mental health advocates and promote mental health resources. We also would want to offer coping days once a month; this would act as a self-care retreat where students can prioritize themselves and their healing through self-care activities and discussion.
value.Summary: We intend to be a peer-based support system for Black students that prioritizes Black mental health needs and improves the Black experience at Northwestern.

value.Name: Black Mentorship Program
value.Description: The Black Mentorship Program (BMP) is a mentorship program for Black undergraduate students at Northwestern. Our mission is to improve the undergraduate experience of Black students at Northwestern through mentorship, community building, racial identity development, and engagement with community resources. During its pilot and subsequent years, the program has held weekly meetings throughout the school year with topics ranging from study skills and getting acclimated to college life to what it means to be Black at Northwestern. We are student led and hope to be an asset to the broader Northwestern community by creating a strong Black community and producing confident Black student leaders.
value.Summary: BMP's mission is to improve the undergraduate experience of Black students at Northwestern through mentorship, community building, racial identity development, and engagement with community resources.

value.Name: Black Poetry Society
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Black Pre-Law Association
value.Description: As a group, the BPLA wants to create an inclusive environment for Black students who are aspiring law students at Northwestern University. We have goals of acquiring experienced speakers from multiple backgrounds, going on tours of Pritzker Law school, and volunteering in the Chicago area at local centers.
value.Summary: An organization for Black students aspiring to go to law school.

value.Name: Blackboard Magazine
value.Description: This student-led publication aims at reporting on issues concerning the Black community both on Northwestern's campus and in the United States, more broadly.
value.Summary: BlackBoard Magazine is Northwestern University’s historically Black student publication.

value.Name: Block Student Advisory Board
value.Description: The Block Student Advisory Board (BSAB) is a crossroads between the Block Museum and the campus community: we are a group of students with diverse backgrounds of study (art history to engineering) who share a love of art and interest in connecting art to our lives on and off campus. The BSAB seeks to bring a multifaceted range of students into the museum to develop new ways to engage the student body and the local arts community through planning and marketing creative events inspired by the museum's exhibitions and collection.
value.Summary: The BSAB seeks to bring a multifaceted range of students into the museum to develop new ways to engage the student body and the local arts community through planning and marketing creative events inspired by the museum's exhibitions and collection.

value.Name: Blockchain Group
value.Description:
Founded in 2017, Blockchain Group aims to foster a healthy and active ecosystem in Northwestern/Chicago and solidify our community on the map as a strong hub for blockchain technology. We work towards this vision by doing the following:

  • provide a gateway for interested students to learn about blockchain technology
  • organize speaker events that feature leaders in the industry
  • work on portfolio-worthy technical and non-technical blockchain projects 
  • collaborate with enterprises to empower our ecosystem
value.Summary: NU Blockchain Group is an undergraduate group aiming to foster a healthy ecosystem surrounding Blockchain technology on campus through a series of workshops, speaker events, and development projects.

value.Name: Boomshaka
value.Description: Boomshaka is Northwestern University's premier drum, dance, and rhythm ensemble. Entirely student written, directed, and produced, Boomshaka has established a reputation for consistently delivering energetic and inspiring performances. We combine dance styles such as hip-hop and contemporary with various forms of percussion, using everything from sticks, poles, and buckets to our hands and feet. Our performers come from a variety of backgrounds and have a number of areas of artistic expertise, ranging from classical music composition and formal dance training to free style rapping and break dancing. We blend our unique talents and experiment with new mediums of expression to create a performance like none other!  Check us out on Youtube, Facebook, Instagram, or on our website.
value.Summary: Boomshaka is Northwestern's premier drum, dance, and rhythm ensemble. Entirely student written, directed, and produced, Boomshaka has established a reputation for consistently delivering energetic and inspiring performances.

value.Name: Bounded Rationality in Decision Making
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Brain Awareness Outreach
value.Description:
The NU Brain Awareness Outreach (NUBAO) organization is a graduate student-led public outreach initiative dedicated to educating, exciting, and inspiring Chicago area youths about the brain and the progress and benefits of neuroscience research. Founded in 2010 as part of the Northwestern University Interdepartmental Neuroscience PhD Program, NUBAO consists of a diverse group of mostly graduate students, in addition to several undergraduate students, post-doctorate fellows, faculty, and research staff from various departments and scientific disciplines at Northwestern University. Through close collaboration with public schools and science education programs in the Chicago area, NUBAO organizes hands-on lectures, workshops, and open-house style events regarding a variety of neuroscience topics for students of all ages.

We are an all inclusive organization. Anyone is welcome to join. 
 
Visit us at http://www.nubrainawareness.com
value.Summary: The NU Brain Awareness Outreach (NUBAO) organization is a graduate student-led public outreach initiative dedicated to educating, exciting, and inspiring Chicago area youths about the brain and the progress and benefits of neuroscience research.

value.Name: Brain Exercise Initiative
value.Description: It has been suggested in scientific literature that brain exercises could help slow down Alzheimer's. One article from 2005(1) indicates that exercising the brain through reading and completing math questions while speaking out loud could slow down Alzheimer's. The Brain Exercise Initiative Club intends to help Alzheimer's patients combat the illness by recruiting volunteers that help the patients at retirement homes complete basic mathematics questions or read books aloud. Therefore, the main goals of this club are to help patients with Alzheimer's combat the illness, improve the communication skills of participating students in a volunteering/healthcare setting, and allow students to participate in a sustainable, long-term volunteering project.
value.Summary: BEI is an organization that helps patients with Alzheimer's by using simple math, writing, and reading exercises to decrease the rate of disease progression and improve that cognitive function.

value.Name: Brazilian Student Association
value.Description:
The Brazilian Student Association (BRASA) aims to establish prolific and long-lasting relationships between American universities and Brazil, thereby creating a platform through which Brazilian students in the United States – and non-Brazilian students willing to be involved – can act to improve Brazil. In addition, BRASA aims to promote the understanding of Brazilian culture, professional opportunities, and the Portuguese language.

A Associação Brasileira de Estudantes (BRASA) visa estabelecer relações prolíficas e duradouras entre universidades americanas e o Brasil, assim criando uma plataforma através da qual estudantes brasileiros nos Estados Unidos, e estudantes não brasileiros que desejam se envolver, podem atuar para melhorar o Brasil. Adicionalmente, a BRASA tem como objetivo promover o entendimento da cultura brasileira, oportunidades profissionais e da língua portuguesa.
value.Summary: BRASA strives to engage the Brazilian community at Northwestern, integrate it with the community of Brazilians studying abroad, as well as to promote Brazilian culture, social life and pre-professional opportunities on campus.

value.Name: Bridge Club
value.Description:
Welcome to the world of Bridge! Bridge is a game of practically infinite possibilities and one of the world’s greatest card games. You’ll love Bridge if you enjoy puzzles or cards or if you’re just looking for a fun social game to participate in. Players of any experience level are welcome to join us at our weekly meetings at the Norris Student Center -  whether you’re a bridge master or have never touched a playing card in your life, we hope to see you there! Participation is open to all members of the Northwestern and Evanston community.

 

For new players there will be mentors available to teach and offer tips about the game. The atmosphere is always very casual and geared towards learning. For experienced players, it’s a great place to meet other bridge enthusiasts, forge partnerships, and get in some good practice. Chances are you’ll meet someone to partner with at local bridge games both down in Chicago and nearby in Evanston.

 

Looking for some serious bridge competition? We also participate in the ACBL Collegiate Bridge Bowl qualifiers each winter and spring. We have a strong history in this event and have qualified for nationals several times in recent years, which typically means a travel package to the NABC in the summer!

 

For more information, stop by our booth at the activity fair this Fall or email Ben at benfisk2023@u.northwestern.edu.

 

We plan to hold our first meeting of 2022 on Tuesday September 27th at Norris Student Center in the Evans Room at 7:00 PM. This will be mostly an information session for new members, but we'll definitely get to play some bridge too!
value.Summary: Northwestern's Bridge Club. Come play with us! All levels welcome!

value.Name: BridgeUSA at NU
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Brown Sugar
value.Description: Brown Sugar is the nation's premiere South Asian-interest co-ed a cappella group. Founded in 1999 by two Northwestern students looking to embrace their South Asian roots, Brown Sugar performs a refreshing mix of South Asian and Western music, ranging everywhere from Bollywood classics and Punjabi pop to American rock and R&B. The group performs around the Chicagoland area and around the country. We are currently recording and producing our fifth studio album! Check us out on Instagram and Youtube!
value.Summary: Brown Sugar is the nation's premiere South Asian-interest co-ed a cappella group.

value.Name: Buffett Institute for Global Affairs
value.Description: Our mission is to foster meaningful engagement across borders of all kinds. We create opportunities for dialogue across academic disciplines—the humanities, social sciences, business, law, medicine, the arts and more—and catalyze connections between researchers and experts from government, industry, nonprofit and nongovernmental organizations worldwide.
value.Summary: Northwestern University’s Roberta Buffett Institute for Global Affairs brings together the brightest minds from across Northwestern University and around the world to address critical global challenges...

value.Name: Business in Healthcare Club
value.Summary: The Business in Healthcare Club aims to educate, inform, and expose undergraduate students at Northwestern to the intersections of business and healthcare. From wanting to learn more about healthcare, to searching for a job, this is the club for you!

value.Name: Cambodian Cultural Awareness
value.Description: CCAC aims to recognize and share the Cambodian student experience at Northwestern by fostering an appreciation of this culture. Introducing different parts of Cambodian cultures and traditions to all students at NU through means of different community activities such as trips to museums, cooking lessons, and movie nights. All students are welcome!
value.Summary: CCAC aims to share and celebrate Cambodia's rich culture, history, and cuisine through fun activities such as field trips to museums and cooking sessions. Hence, if you (all students) are interested to learn more, we're very excited to have you join us!

value.Name: Campus Inclusion and Community
value.Summary: DCIC is dedicated to collaborating with students, faculty, and staff with the aim of making Northwestern University an inclusive community for all Wildcats. DCIC's primary goal is to cultivate a community of respect at NU.

value.Name: campusCatalyst
value.Description: Each quarter campusCATALYST recruits undergraduate students to provide consulting services for local nonprofits. Students take a cC designed for-credit seminar where they learn about consulting, nonprofit management and the social sector. Teams of 5 students are paired with a local nonprofit that needs assistance with strategic challenges. Each team is also mentored by a Kellogg MBA student for the quarter, who offers advice and guidance in the consulting process.
value.Summary: campusCatalyst is a student group and Kapnick Business Institutions Program class at Northwestern University that engages college students, supported by business school mentors, in high-impact pro-bono consulting for nonprofit organizations.

value.Name: Canterbury Northwestern
value.Description:
We're the Episcopal campus ministry. Through communion and community, we offer students a place to explore issues of vocation, social justice and spirituality -- where the life of the mind meets the concerns of the soul and the needs of the world. We meet weekly to worship God and enjoy each other's company, and we also participate in Diocesan Conventions and weekend retreats. Using the traditions of the Christian faith in contemporary language, we seek to support each other to meet the challenges of campus and society. We invite all seekers -- Episcopal, Anglican, or of any faith -- to join us in these conversations and fellowship.

 

Weekly services during the academic quarters: Sundays at 5:00 p.m. We also host book studies and social events throughout the quarter. Contact us to get on our listserv.
value.Summary: We're the Episcopal campus ministry. Through communion and community, we offer students a place to explore issues of vocation, social justice and spirituality -- where the life of the mind meets the concerns of the soul and the needs of the world.

value.Name: Cats Who Compost
value.Description: CWC aims to engage the Northwestern community in reducing food waste through composting. Northwestern’s Hillel Center oversees large, free, publicly-available, industrial-composting bins provided by Collective Resource, Evanston’s industrial composting service. These bins are also located behind Sheil and UCM. CWC shares additional composting resources, such as compostable countertop compost bin liners, and works to disseminate knowledge about composting throughout campus to make it a more environmentally conscious space. CWC host social, educational, and volunteer events!
value.Summary: CWC's goals are to share knowledge about composting and engage the Northwestern community in composting around campus!

value.Name: Center for Awareness, Response & Education
value.Description:
CARE provides services for survivors of past or recent trauma, and friends of survivors, including confidential support and advocacy services, education programming, and referrals.

Please note that this page is not kept active.  If you wish to know more about CARE, feel free to email care@northwestern.edu, follow us on Facebook, or stop by our office in Searle Hall.
value.Summary: The mission of CARE is to create a culture of healthy sexuality at Northwestern University where sexual violence, relationship violence, and stalking are not tolerated

value.Name: Center for Civic Engagement
value.Description:
Northwestern University's Center for Civic Engagement promotes a lifelong commitment to active citizenship and social responsibility among all students. Through an integration of academics with meaningful volunteer service, research and community partnerships, the Center supports students, faculty, staff and alumni as they enhance their own academic experiences while contributing to stronger communities and a more engaged university.

The Center for Civic Engagement utilizes a variety of strategies to meet this mission, building in part on the successful programs that are already underway in various halls of the institution. The Center for Civic Engagement:

    • Promotes meaningful community involvement and a culture of active civic engagement among all members of the university community (pre-college students, undergraduates, graduates, alumni, faculty and staff)
    • Develops and promotes cohesive curricular strategies that integrate service and hands-on experience with academic learning in a variety of disciplines
    • Connects and coordinates related efforts among individual faculty and staff as well as programs and departments throughout the university
    • Serves as a clearinghouse to collect and disseminate information on civic learning opportunities
    • Facilitates mutually-beneficial partnerships with community organizations locally and across the globe
    • Provides training and technical assistance to faculty, staff, and student leaders who facilitate service-learning projects and community partnerships
    • Conducts and publishes research on civic engagement and service-learning
    • Evaluates programs and disseminates information on best practices for academically based centers on civic education
value.Summary: Northwestern University's Center for Civic Engagement promotes a lifelong commitment to active citizenship & social responsibility. CCE integrates academics with meaningful service, research and community partnerships to promote a more engaged university

value.Name: Center for Health Equity Transformation
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Center for Leadership
value.Description:
Northwestern is one of only a few academic institutions that boast a university-wide research center dedicated to the study of leadership and dissemination of the latest and best practices.

The Center for Leadership offers opportunities for all students to improve their skills, in an environment that nurtures experimentation and innovation. We also encourage staff and faculty to get involved by contributing their expertise, by embedding assessment tools into the curriculum, and through consultations with the Center’s directors.

For Undergraduate students, we offer programs like Leadership Coaching, the Paradigms and Strategies of Leadership class, and the Leadership Certificate. We encourage everyone to learn more at lead.northwestern.edu.

By engaging with the Center for Leadership, you will build your leadership resilience through our robust assessment tools and deep expertise.
value.Summary: The Center for Leadership provides programming for undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty that enhances leadership and teamwork. We start from a "questions first" approach and help leaders grow authentically by building on their experiences.

value.Name: Challah for Hunger
value.Description:
If you like to bake, eat, or volunteer, Challah for Hunger is for you!! Challah for Hunger (CfH) raises awareness of and money for hunger and disaster relief through the production and sale of challah bread. Volunteers gather weekly on afternoons at Hillel to make challah, which we sell to the Northwestern community. Challot come in a variety of flavors: plain, chocolate chip,  cinnamon sugar, and flavor of the week! Fifty percent of each CfH chapter's profits are donated to the national CfH cause-- Swipe Out Hunger. The remaining 50% goes to The Ark, an organization that supports Jews in the Chicago area.

Although we are a Hillel student group, Challah for Hunger is open to all students!! 

 

Contact Sarah Katz at sarahkatz2025@u.northwestern.edu for more information!
value.Summary: If you like to bake, eat, or volunteer, Challah for Hunger is for you!! Challah for Hunger (CfH) raises awareness of and money for hunger and disaster relief through the production and sale of challah bread.

value.Name: Chapin Hall
value.Description: Chapin Hall is the Humanities Residential College. It houses 65 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live on separate floors. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
value.Summary: The Humanities Residential College.

value.Name: Chi Alpha Campus Ministries
value.Description:
XA's focus is in three parts: 
 
God • Bringing you to a place where you can grow closer to God
Community • Building a community of people you can rely on, spend time with, and grow with
Mission • Pursuing the mission of helping others find the joy of experiencing God and community
 
Everyone of all backgrounds and identities are welcome in XA!
value.Summary: Chi Alpha (or XA) is a Christian campus ministry focused on allowing students to grow together in their experience with God, community, and mission.
