value.Name: Chi Sigma Iota-Nu Upsilon
value.Description: CSI is an international honor society that values academic and professional excellence in counseling. We promote a strong professional identity through members (professional counselors, counselor educators, and students) who contribute to the realization of a healthy society by fostering wellness and human dignity.
value.Summary: Our mission is to promote scholarship, research, professionalism, leadership, advocacy, and excellence in counseling, and to recognize high attainment in the pursuit of academic and clinical excellence in the profession of counseling.

value.Name: Chicago Graduate Student Association
value.Description:
For more information check out our website: http://sites.northwestern.edu/cgsa/

 

The Chicago Graduate Student Association (CGSA) is a student organization composed of graduate students from programs on Northwestern University’s Chicago Campus, including, but not limited to,  the Driskill Graduate Training Program in Life Sciences (DGP), Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP), Northwestern University Interdepartmental Neuroscience (NUIN), Biomedical Engineering (BME), Clinical Psychology, Genetic Counselling and Physical Therapy.  The CGSA aims to serve in the best interest of all graduate students on the Chicago campus. We work to achieve this goal by advocating for and promoting students’ rights, academic and professional development, social interaction and community outreach. We also strive to bring together students from both the Chicago and Evanston campuses, whether through academic or social events. Our mission is to represent the diverse interests of Chicago graduate students and facilitate The Graduate School’s objective of funding and supporting graduate students’ academic and career goals.
value.Summary: For more information check out our website: http://sites.northwestern.edu/cgsa/

value.Name: China and Sinophone Studies Society
value.Description: China and Sinophone Studies Society (CNSS) is an academic organization that seeks to engage the Northwestern community in research, discussion, and writing relevant to contemporary China and the Sinophone world through the lens of culture, art, politics, economics, and history. It aims to provide a space for open, genuine intellectual debates in studies of China and the Sinophone cultural sphere, including the Chinese diaspora. Issues and implications less documented by the U.S. mainstream media will be of particular interest.
value.Summary: China & Sinophone Studies Society is an academic organization seeking to engage the Northwestern community in research, discussion, and writing relevant to contemporary China and the Sinophone world through culture, art, politics, economics, and history.

value.Name: China Care
value.Description: China Care is a cultural philanthropy group who helps to fund surgeries for Chinese orphans with disabilities and provides programming for adopted Chinese children who live in the Chicagoland area. Please check out the NU China Care website here!
value.Summary: China Care is a cultural philanthropy group who helps to fund surgeries and education for Chinese orphans with disabilities and provides programming for adopted Chinese children who live in the Chicagoland area.

value.Name: Chinatown Health Initiative
value.Description:
What we do:

  1. Volunteer - You will work with medical students and health professionals to provide free primary healthcare to the indigent public at health fairs and clinics. Interpreting is a further way get more involved clinical experience (conversational proficiency in Mandarin or Cantonese required as translator).
  2. Education - CTHI hopes to foster greater education of health-related issues on campus and in Chinatown. On campus, we have held speaker events and discussions. In Chinatown, we are starting outreach initiatives to connect to the public.
  3. Fundraising - In the past we hand-made and sold Chinese spring rolls and pastries to raise funds to buy medicine, equipment, and other medical supplies. New initiatives always welcome! No cooking or language experience needed
  4. Socials - We hold all types of socials, including dim sum outings, movie nights, game nights, etc! Come meet fellow CTHI members and have a good time.
  5. Apply to join the student board as a Junior Executive (Fall) and Executive Member (Spring). Our executive board coordinates volunteering activities and fundraisers. This is a great way to gain event planning experience and build communication and leadership skills!

If you're interested, please contact chinatown@u.northwestern.edu. We will reply within 1-2 days!
value.Summary: Welcome! We are a student group that supports health initiatives in Cermak Chinatown. Get involved by volunteering as an interpreter or joining the student board.

value.Name: Chinese International Student Association
value.Description: Formed in 2009, Chinese International Student Association is a culture-based club that welcomes international chinese students and all friends who are interested in Chinese. It aims to promote the authentic Chinese culture on campus, while providing a sense of belonging for the international Chinese students, helping them in transition to college life in US. CISA also aims to connect Northwestern students with the scholars/ visitors from China in order to gain understanding of Chinese society from a local perspective. Moreover, CISA is also promoting the brand of Northwestern University in China, helping to match Northwestern students to career opportunities in China.
value.Summary: Formed in 2009, the Chinese International Student Association is a culture-based club that welcomes international Chinese students and all friends who are interested in Chinese. It aims to promote the authentic Chinese culture on campus.

value.Name: Chinese Students Association
value.Description:
The Chinese Students Association is one of the first established, and largest Asian-American student groups at Northwestern. We aim to promote the awareness of Chinese culture on campus and elsewhere while encouraging a social environment for students of all backgrounds. Furthermore, we strive to bring service to our community. Our events are geared towards bringing together the Asian community while sharing our culture with others. Some annual events include: Celebrasia, Dumpling Night, Cultural Festivals, dances, dinner parties, and hosting famous guest speakers.

Please follow us on instagram to stay up to date with events and general news: northwesterncsa 

Please email csa@u.northwestern.edu for questions, and if you are interested in joining! 

Warning: We do not use this page very often, so please refer to email and instagram!
value.Summary: The Chinese Students Association is one of the first established Asian-American student groups at Northwestern. We aim to promote the awareness of Chinese culture on campus and elsewhere while encouraging a social environment for students of all

value.Name: Christians on Campus
value.Description:
Christians on Campus is a campus group comprising of believers in Christ from various backgrounds. We warmly welcome all Christians in Christ, and reach out to the greater Northwestern community.

Our Faith:

We hold the faith which is common to all believers (Jude 3):

  • The Bible is the complete divine revelation inspired word-by-word by God through the Holy Spirit (2 Peter 1:21, 2 Timothy 3:16)

  • God is uniquely one, yet triune - the Father, the Son, and the Spirit (1 Timothy 2:5a, Matthew 28:19)

  • God became a man, the man of Jesus Christ (John 1:1, John 1:14)

  • Christ died on the cross for our sins, shedding His blood for our redemption (1 Peter 2:24, Ephesians 1:7a)

  • Christ resurrected from among the dead on the third day (1 Corinthians 15:4) and ascended to the right hand of God to be Lord of all (Acts 1:9, Acts 2:33)

  • When a person repents to God and believes in the Lord Jesus Christ, he is regenerated (born again) and becomes a living member of the one Body of CHrist (Acts 20:21, John 3:3, Ephesians 1:22-23, Romans 12:5)

  • Christ is coming again to receive His believers to Himself (1 Thessalonians 2:19)

 

Events:

  • Weekly Bible study on campus to pursue the Lord and the truth in God's word with other students
  • Each Friday during the school year, Christians on Campus hosts fellowship meetings at several homes in the community adjacent to Northwestern. These times generally include a home cooked meal, singing hymns, and mutual Christian fellowship through reading the Bible and reading excerpts of spiritual books.
  • In addition to the Friday night fellowship meetings, we regularly come together with other Christians from the NU Medical Center, the Law School, UIC, and the University of Chicago.
  • Campus ministers are available throughout the week to meet with students at the students' convenience for prayer and fellowship, reading the Bible, or simply to talk.
value.Summary: Christians on Campus is a campus group comprising of believers in Christ from various backgrounds. We warmly welcome all Christians in Christ, and reach out to the greater Northwestern community.

value.Name: Chronic Illness Alliance
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Club Baseball
value.Description:
Interest Form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfYaLoDqYqEIPm3-2hNvBXsrdyBJheL3HSPkdHK1KUbB6ITiw/viewform?usp=sf_link

If you're looking for a way to continue playing the game you love, but not quite at the rigor you did in your glory days, club baseball is for you. 

Stay tuned or contact us for info on tryouts to be held in early October – Dates TBA.

Our schedule is usually something along these lines:

- 1.5 - 2 hour practices twice per week throughout the year (we have a practice facility w/ a batting cage)

- Fall Season: 1 conference series, 1 or 2 non-conference series

- Spring Season: 3-game series most weekends vs. NCBA Great Lakes West Division teams (March-May), with opportunity to advance to NCBA playoffs and World Series

For more information, please contact new president samessex2024@u.northwestern.edu
value.Summary: NU Club Baseball is the best way to continue playing competitive baseball after high school. We practice two to three times a week year-round and have games during the fall and spring seasons. Tryouts will occur within a week or two of class starting.

value.Name: Club Cricket Team
value.Summary: Northwestern's official club cricket team, open to all undergraduate, graduate and faculty members.

value.Name: Club Field Hockey
value.Description: Club Field Hockey provides students of Northwestern the opportunity to play high quality field hockey in a fun environment. The recreational, yet competitive nature of the club enables members to enjoy the sport through outdoor practice and games in fall and spring, in addition to regular training games with the Chicago Field Hockey Club and tournaments at nearby universities. Additionally, the club fundraises and organizes social events to further bond the team. The club contributes to the growth of the field hockey community at Northwestern and the greater Chicago area.
value.Summary: Club Field Hockey is open to athletes of any skill level. The recreational, yet competitive nature of the club will enable members to enjoy the sport through training sessions, away games, tournaments, and bonding events.

value.Name: Club Figure Skating (NUFSC)
value.Description: The Northwestern Figure Skating Club consists of the NU Synchronized Skating Team (The Purple Line). Members of the club have the opportunity to continue figure skating in college and experience collegiate-level competition. The synchronized skating team draws in both seasoned synchro skaters as well as freestyle skaters who have never been on a synchro team before. Our season runs during fall and winter quarter and practices occur 2-3 times a week. Practices consist of both off-ice and on-ice work, coordinated by the team's coach. We travel to 2 or 3 competitions in the winter, and we end the season with our annual ice skating exhibition for family and friends!
value.Summary: The Northwestern Figure Skating Club consists of the NU Synchronized Skating Team as well as an individual freestyle skating program. Members have the opportunity to continue figure skating in college and experience collegiate-level competition.

value.Name: Club Golf
value.Description: Club golf was brought back to campus during the 2013-2014 school year.  The club was created in order to provide a place for students to play competitvely, in regional tournaments in the spring and fall, as well as recreationally.
value.Summary: Club Golf was re-formed during the 2013-2014 school year.  We will be playing recreationally at local courses as well as competitively in regional tournaments.  Club Golf was created so give students a chance to play competitively and recreationally.

value.Name: Club Softball
value.Description: We are a fun group of female student-athletes who come together to play the sport we love - fastpitch softball. We play other university club teams at a competitive level as part of the National Club Softball Association. In 2019, we ended our season ranked 12th in the Nation after our first ever trip to Nationals.
value.Summary: Northwestern Club Softball is a competitive, collegiate girls' fastpitch softball team. We are a member of the National Club Softball Association and play teams generally located in the Midwest region. 2019 was our 1st appearance at the national tourney.

value.Name: Club Spikeball
value.Description:
Whether you're a seasoned veteran and are ready to compete in the next Spikeball College National Championship, or just love playing casually and are looking to hang out with a fun group of students, Club Spikeball is the place for you!  No experience necessary, just come ready to have fun!

Our competitive team will travel to two tournaments this year - sectionals (date tbd) and college nationals (spring).

 

If you are planning on joining please fill out this sign-up form here                                                                      

Also join Club Spikeball on IMLeagues here                                                                                                        

Join our GroupMe!                                                                                                                                            

top plays
value.Summary: We are a team dedicated to competing in the sport of Spikeball (roundnet) and providing a supportive community for Northwestern students.

value.Name: Club Tennis
value.Description:
Our team is close to 130 people. Based on tryouts, we will select Men's A-team, Men's B-team, Women's A-team, and Women's B-team. A-team practices twice a week including co-ed practice on Sundays. B-team practices once a week. The top members of the team sometimes compete against other schools in the USTA Tennis on Campus format.

Practices are held at night, a variation of times between 8pm-11pm, at the Combe Tennis Center inside the Henry Crowne Sports Pavilion. 

Follow us on instagram @nu.clubtennis

Please feel free to reach out with any questions at nuclubtennis@gmail.com

 

Please don't request to join the roster yet. Thank you!
value.Summary: Club Tennis is a group for students who want to continue playing tennis at a competitive level, but in a more recreational environment.

value.Name: Cognitive Systems and Artificial Intelligence Student Group
value.Summary: TBA

value.Name: College Democrats
value.Description: The Northwestern University College Democrats serves as a campus hub for progressive thought and action. In an effort to increase student involvement in politics and voter turnout among college-aged students, we host events with distinguished keynote speakers every academic quarter, sponsor colloquia on campus, and organize a multitude of canvassing and outreach opportunities in Evanston and the greater Chicago area. In addition, we hold weekly meetings on campus, where we discuss current events, debate progressive ideals and policy, and, most importantly, build a strong community.
value.Summary: The NU College Democrats serves as a campus hub for progressive thought and action. We hold weekly meetings on campus, discussing current events, debating progressive ideals and policy, and, most importantly, building a strong community.

value.Name: College Feminists
value.Description: College Feminists is the premier feminist and pro-choice organization on the Evanston Northwestern campus. We meet at the Women's Center, discussing issues ranging from domestic violence to the college hook-up scene. We believe that every woman should be able to make her own decisions regarding abortion and birth control and we seek to educate students and the community at large about their rights to such decisions. We also work to counteract negative images of women and work against gender stereotyping. We believe in a progressive, informed, and open-minded community. We hope to accomplish these goals by rallying, supporting and educating one another in the Northwestern Community and also by creating a network with other college campuses nationwide.
value.Summary: College Feminists is a premier feminist and pro-choice organization on the Evanston Northwestern campus. Email nufeminists@gmail.com to find out when we meet. New members are always welcome!

value.Name: College Republicans
value.Description:
College Republicans is Northwestern's conservative student organization that supports the ideals of the Republican Party. We host high-profile speakers, participate in campus debates and activities, and provide a variety of opportunities for all political backgrounds.  We bring speakers to campus who appeal to moderates, libertarians, objectivists, and conservatives of all colors, and all are welcome to attend meetings and events.  

Get on our email list at: https://tiny.cc/nucr2020
value.Summary: College Republicans is Northwestern's conservative student organization that supports the ideals of the Republican Party. We host high-profile speakers, participate in campus debates, and provide a variety of opportunities for all political backgrounds.

value.Name: Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies
value.Description: The Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies is an interdisciplinary academic endeavor that aims to promote and stimulate conversations on indigeneity and indigenous populations in the Americas and the transnational imaginary at Northwestern University.
value.Summary: The Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies is an  academic endeavor that aims to promote and stimulate conversations on indigeneity and indigenous populations in the Americas and the transnational imaginary at Northwestern.

value.Name: ColorStack
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Communications Residential College - East Fairchild
value.Description: East Fairchild is a residential college south campus and houses 109 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in an open suite-style layout. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
value.Summary: East Fairchild is on south campus and houses 109 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in an open suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is available to all undergraduate students.

value.Name: Community Health Corps
value.Description:
CHC recruits new volunteers in the Fall and Winter. Please e-mail nucommunityhealthcorps@gmail.com if you are interested in joining!

 

The Northwestern Community Health Corps (CHC) is a grass roots student run organization that aims to empower individuals to better manage their health in Evanston and Skokie area.

 

CHC student volunteers launched and operate the Community Health Hub, a health resource desk at Evanston Public Library where they help community members navigate through their health related questions and connect individuals to existing health information and resources. In addition, through a unique partnership with the American Red Cross, CHC recruits and trains students to be trainers in CPR/First Aid/AED courses in order to provide these trainings free of charge to underserved populations in our community. CHC has formed partnerships with the Evanston and Skokie Public Libraries, Erie Family Health Center, Asian Human Services, the Evanston and Skokie Health Departments, and community health leaders.
value.Summary: Community Health Corps is a student group dedicated to improving health outcomes in the Evanston and Skokie area by increasing access to health information and resources.

value.Name: Community Standards Student Reps
value.Description:
Student Representatives and Student Panel Members are part of the Office of Community Standards Team. This position offers students the opportunity to build community while gaining professional and leadership skills as a part of their service. Students will apply skills such as critical thinking, navigating conflict, and managing interdependence throughout their time in the position.

The Student Representative serves as a hearing officer, with a staff member from the Office of Community Standards, in non-separation level cases of alleged violations of university policy involving student organization/groups. The Office of Community Standards developed this process to allow students a meaningful role and voice in the adjudication process of student organizations/groups.

The second position, a Student Panel Member, will serve on a three-person panel inclusive of students, faculty, and staff to hear cases and make decisions of alleged violation of University policies (non-sexual misconduct) that have the potential to result in separation (suspension, expulsion) from the university. A panel convened for a hearing will typically consist of two faculty/staff members and one student member.
value.Summary: TBA

value.Name: Competition for Undergraduate Regenerative Engineering
value.Description: We work in small, interdisciplinary teams to research new solutions to healthcare problems with the help of faculty and professionals from Northwestern and beyond. The teams compete to create the best solutions before presenting their results at a final symposium in the spring. CURE provides a collaborative, peer-led environment for students to get involved in cutting-edge research.
value.Summary: CURE (Competition for Undergraduate Regenerative Engineering) is an engineering student research group designed to tackle medical challenges with regenerative engineering solutions. We use model wound systems and hands-on methods for applicable research.

value.Name: Comunidad Latinx
value.Description: The objects of this organization shall be to foster community oriented around Latinx identity, culture, and history; to provide a safe space for its members; to give back to the local Latinx community; and to educate the wider university community and public about Latinx affairs.
value.Summary: Latinx Graduate Student Group

value.Name: Concrete Canoe
value.Description: Every year we build a canoe out of Concrete, defying the laws of common sense. If you like to see the full life of a project from conception to use, than this is the club for you! If you like to get your hands dirty and think of solutions on the fly, then you will have great time. You can be involved as much or as little as you want, and everyone is welcome.
value.Summary: We build and race a Concrete Canoe!

value.Name: Consultants Advising Student Enterprises
value.Description:
Started in the spring of 2008, CASE is a student organization at Northwestern University dedicated to providing pro bono consulting advice to Northwestern-based organizations and beyond. We seek to harness our intellectual capital to help organizations become more efficient, active, and impactful.

The way we approach this mission is two-fold.

First, we provide measurable results to our clients. We stand behind our work 100%, and we follow through with our clients to ensure our recommendations are fully implemented.

Second, we provide the best possible learning experience for our consultants. Through ‘hands-on’ consulting experience, we develop our members to be well-rounded, analytical minds.

How to join:
CASE formally recruits twice per year. We will send out applications, after which there will be one-two rounds of interviews composed of both behavioral and case style questions.
value.Summary: Started in the spring of 2008, CASE is a student organization at Northwestern University dedicated to providing pro bono consulting advice to Northwestern-based organizations and beyond.

value.Name: Contemporary Thought Speaker Series
value.Description: The CTSS is an undergraduate initiative at Northwestern supported by the Offices of the President, the Provost, and the Division of Student Affairs. Our board of students seeks to identify and secure the most forward-thinking minds of our generation to speak to the Northwestern community on the purpose and value of a university education in today's world.
value.Summary: The CTSS invites the most influential and forward-thinking minds of our time to speak to the Northwestern community on issues of universal importance. Our mission is to encourage cross-campus dialogue and intellectual community at Northwestern.

value.Name: Conversations to Remember
value.Description:
Conversations to Remember is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that combats senior loneliness by arranging virtual visits between seniors and students in college and high school. Groups of 2-3 student volunteers meet with seniors in video calls on a weekly basis, building intergenerational relationships, improving senior self-esteem, and engaging in mental stimulation.

The Northwestern Chapter of Conversations to Remember offers various fulfilling volunteering opportunities for students. From Newsletter Contributor to Outreach Coordinator, there is something for everyone.
value.Summary: Conversations to Remember is a nonprofit organization that combats senior loneliness by arranging virtual visits between seniors and students in college and high school. C2R offers various engaging and flexible volunteering opportunities!

value.Name: Cookology
value.Description: Welcome to Cookology!
value.Summary: Cookology is a community that provides opportunities for Northwestern students to explore cooking techniques, recipes, and diverse cuisines and to cultivate interests in culinary arts through cooking lessons, student-run restaurants, and catered events.

value.Name: COPE (Cancer Outreach Prevention Education)
value.Description: C.O.P.E. unites and empowers college students in their initiatives to fight cancer through public awareness, fundraising, and patient support (volunteering) for a variety of cancer-related organizations. It is a group devoted to developing leadership, providing service with compassion and maturity, and positively impacting university and national medical communities. We are a creative, diverse, and dynamic bunch, and love new members to jump in at anytime.
value.Summary: C.O.P.E. unites and empowers college students in their initiatives to fight cancer through public awareness, fundraising, and patient support (volunteering) for a variety of cancer-related organizations. It is a group devoted  to developing leadership,

value.Name: CoPilot
value.Description:
Although traditional RTVF screenwriting classes allow us to write independently, there are no formal opportunities to simulate the daily routine in a real-world career—that of a writers' room. CoPilot is a space for screenwriters of any experience level to join forces to produce something magical: a complete set of scripts each quarter. Ownership of the final product is collective.

Members of CoPilot commit to accepting each other at any skill level, boosting each other up to greater literary heights, and telling stories that we feel are pertinent and imperative to tell. CoPilot prepares students for what it might be like in a real writers' room environment, and helps boost students' writing portfolios with collaborative work they can be proud of. Whether reaching for the next act break or for a career in screenwriting, members always push each other to inspire and be inspired.
value.Summary: The "mock TV writers' room" club for an entire miniseries (or the first season of a series) done over the course of one quarter in a collaborative setting.

value.Name: Coptic Club
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Council on Chinese Affairs
value.Description: We provide a platform for all the students and scholars from Northwestern University to discuss and explore issues on current economic, political and cultural situations, as well as to catalyze further understanding of business and economy relations between China and other countries. We bring in professors and professionals of diverse backgrounds and fields to share opinions and develop cross-border understanding on contemporary China.
value.Summary: We provide a platform for all the students and scholars from Northwestern University to discuss and explore issues on current economic, political and cultural situations, as well as to catalyze further understanding of business and economy relations

value.Name: Creative Writing
value.Description: Northwestern's creative writing club provides a space where students can work on personal creative projects and hone their skills as writers. The organization supplies students with prompts to stir their imagination and opportunities to gain critique. We aim to create a community of passionate writers of all experience levels and provide them with motivation, inspiration, and feedback on their work.
value.Summary: Northwestern's creative writing club provides a space where students can work on personal creative projects and hone their skills as writers. The organization supplies students with prompts to stir their imagination and opportunities to gain feedback.

value.Name: Crescendo for a Cause
value.Description:
Crescendo for a Cause is an officially registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization in the United States and a Presidential Volunteer Service Award (PVSA) certifying organization. Allen Beckwith, Kiran Mohan and Jonathan Raymond founded Crescendo for a Cause in 2018 with one mission in mind: to improve music education in underserved areas and utilize music performance as a vehicle for advocacy and community service.

 

The NU chapter is dedicated to establishing a mentorship program between Northwestern students and students in Chicago public schools that lack funding for high-level fine arts instruction. Our mentors foster these students’ interests in music and provide them with support outside of the classroom. Additionally, we give back to the community by performing virtual and in-person benefit concerts. Namely, we perform therapeutic music for residents in senior living facilities, and continue Crescendo for a Cause’s portfolio of virtual performances that have been sent out to nursing homes across the country. Finally, we are open to any student that is interested in getting involved — regardless of music experience — and have a fundraising committee that will donate to music nonprofits in the area.
value.Summary: We are the Northwestern chapter of Crescendo for a Cause, and we are dedicated to improving music education in underserved areas and utilizing music performance as a vehicle for advocacy and community service.

value.Name: Crossword Team
value.Description: Northwestern Crossword Team (NUXW) is the premier crossword team on campus. We are a co-ed team equally focused on improving our crossword skills and building a friendly, supporting community on campus. We work to facilitate a welcoming environment for students while also completing crosswords together. Meetings take place Monday nights, and application opportunities will be available at the beginning of each quarter. Students of all crossword abilities are welcome to apply!
value.Summary: NUXW is a co-ed team equally focused on improving our crossword skills and building a friendly, supporting community on campus.

value.Name: Cru
value.Description:
What is Cru about?

 

Real faith. Real relationships. Real life.

 

Northwestern Cru is a community where the gospel captures hearts, transforms lives, impacts the world and launches men and women into a lifelong adventure with Jesus Christ. We’re glad you’re here. In short, we are about students becoming world changers. God has you in one of the most exciting places of your life—the campus. Unlike any other place (or likely any other time in your life) the world is literally all around you. Take a look around you, I’m willing to bet that within a few minutes of where you’re sitting right now you can meet someone from a different country, a different culture, and a different family setting than your own. And you may not be able to see it right now, but within a number of years these very people that you are sitting around in class and living next to right now in your dorm, house or apartment building will be people who give shape to the culture, the community, the nation and the world! The campus is a pretty amazing place!

 

What’s more, amidst this amazing setting we see that God is doing something big on the campus. Have you ever been confused about God? Have you ever felt disconnected from Him? Have you ever wondered if he was really real at all? Or maybe you believe that He is there, but you just don’t feel close to Him or you are trying to figure out this faith thing. Well, our experience tells us that these are common questions for today’s generation—and for those who wonder, more are discovering something real and fresh in a personal relationship with God! In fact if you’ve ever wondered some of these things,take a few minutes now and email one of us. We may not have all the answers but would love to hear your story.

 

Cru is a movement of people across the globe that are growing in and helping others grow in a personal relationship with God–one filled with increasing purpose, hope, honesty, & intimacy. So why did you come to college? What will you leave with? What’s your purpose in life? We hope that you’ll find us, find God, and find the adventure that is waiting for you!

 

If you are curious about this relationship with God, or want to learn more about Christianity a great resource is Knowing God Personally from EveryStudent.com
value.Summary:
What is Cru about?
Real faith. Real relationships. Real life.
Northwestern Cru is a community where the gospel captures hearts, transforms lives, impacts the world and launches men and women into a lifelong adventure with Jesus Christ.

value.Name: CTF Team
value.Description:
The CTF Team aims to foster a healthy and active ecosystem in Northwestern and Chicago, and solidify our community on the map as a competitive organization for CTF challenges. We work towards this vision by doing the following:

  • Provide a gateway for interested students to learn about different cybersecurity skills related to CTF challenges
  • Connect students with professors to engage students in cybersecurity related research
  • Help our students with networking and career opportunities in the cybersecurity industry 
  • Collaborate with enterprises to empower our ecosystem
value.Summary: CTFs (capture-the-flag) are widely recognized as one of the best ways to train and evaluate cybersecurity skills. Our ultimate goal is to give Northwestern students the opportunity to compete in and join the CTF community.

value.Name: Cubing Club
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: The cubing club will provide for the intellectual advancement of Northwestern students through the activity of puzzle solving. Members will develop their mental abilities and dexterity as they learn to solve Rubik’s cubes and similar puzzles quickly. The

value.Name: Cycling
value.Description: Northwestern Cycling is a co-ed club sport open to both undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy riding their bicycles. The team organizes group rides of varying distance and speed throughout the year and competes in the Midwest Collegiate Cycling Conference for road races in the spring. Visit www.northwesterncycling.com for more information!
value.Summary: Northwestern Cycling is a co-ed club sport open to both undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy riding their bicycles. The team organizes group rides of varying distance and speed throughout the year and competes in collegiate races in the spring.

value.Name: Dale Duro Latin Dance Company
value.Description: Dale Duro Latin Dance Co. (DDLDC), Northwestern’s Latin dance team, is an inclusive dance group started in 2018 composed of Latin culture appreciators of all backgrounds and skill levels. We teach free workshops of varied Latin dance styles throughout each quarter, host community bonding events like karaoke nights and movie nights, and perform in our BIG annual spring show where we showcase our talents in salsa, bachata, merengue, flamenco, cumbia, reggaeton and more. We hope to continue fostering a supportive environment where we can all grow as Latin dancers, all while enriching and strengthening our perspective on Latin culture.
value.Summary: Dale Duro is looking to create an inclusive community for all students searching to enrich their appreciation for Latin culture through dance.

value.Name: Deeva
value.Description: Deeva is a nationally-recognized, all-female competitive dance team that blends the best of Indian classical, Bollywood, folk, ballet, lyrical, and hip-hop. Founded in 2001, the team has a unique mission: to generate and participate in an intercultural dialogue through dance. Each dancer brings a unique background from the diverse regions of South Asia and knowledge of a variety of dance styles from all over the world. By choreographing dances that mix cultures, Deeva is excited to not only bring increased cultural awareness to the student body, but to have a cultural exchange through dance.
value.Summary: Deeva is a nationally-recognized, all-female competitive dance team that blends the best of Indian classical, Bollywood, folk, ballet, lyrical, and hip-hop, founded in 2001.

value.Name: Delta Sigma Pi
value.Description:
Delta Sigma Pi is Northwestern's premier co-ed business fraternity. Our activities focus on three aspects: Professional, Social, and Community Service.

 

Through Delta Sigma Pi, you will develop lasting relationships with brothers who share a common passion for business in diverse fields and industries - from consulting and finance to technology, startups, and social impact organizations. Our members form a community and support each other in professional and academic endeavors.  We hold several social events per quarter and perform community service in the Evanston/Chicagoland area.


We develop our members professionally through a wide range of activities and career related workshops.  Past events have included consulting panels, Northwestern-wide stock competitions, prestigious guest speakers, site visits, and courses on resume building, interviewing, and networking. We also provide opportunities for leadership positions and a connection to the vast alumni base of the national organization of over 295,000 initiated members.  

We recruit in the Fall and Winter - please see our website for recruitment events and deadlines.
value.Summary: As the world’s leading professional fraternity for men and women, Delta Sigma Pi develops principled business leaders for the future by providing a lifetime of opportunity for members.

value.Name: Design for America
value.Description: Design for America (DFA) is an award-winning nationwide network of interdisciplinary student teams and community members using design to create local and social impact. DFA teaches human centered design to young adults and collaborating community partners through extra-curricular, university based, student led design studios to look locally, create fervently and act fearlessly. DFA currently tackles national challenges in Education, Health, Economy and Environment. We take applications for new projects every quarter! Email northwestern@designforamerica.com to get the application.
value.Summary: Design for America creates local and social impact through design. By organizing interdisciplinary groups of students and working in an extra-curricular setting, we tackle social challenges from a unique, creative perspective.

value.Name: Destino
value.Description:
Destino is an ethnic ministry at Northwestern designed to be a safe space for Latinx-identifying students to continue or initiate a relationship with Jesus Christ. We explore Latinx Northwestern students' ethnic identity in the context of Christianity and want to build up Latinx leaders. We are a welcoming and loving community who seeks to guide Latinx students in their spiritual walk, while also helping students to create friendships and resources that enhance their experience and life at Northwestern University. 

Get in contact: Destino Interest Form

To join GroupMe: https://groupme.com/join_group/38734694/15POYe
value.Summary: A spiritual resource for Latinx-identifying Northwestern students seeking to know God and develop or enhance their relationship with Jesus.

value.Name: Develop + Innovate for Social Change
value.Description:
DISC started as a student group in 2017 with the goal of expanding Northwestern students' perceptions of the capabilities of technology. Since then, we've gathered a diverse group of student leaders interested in using technology to make a positive impact on the world. We recognize the power of collaboration across difference, and look for the right balance of technical and non-technical skills when we work together.

We do this by assembling project teams of hardworking students, and challenging them to grow as they work with community clients making an impact in the Evanston/Chicago area.
value.Summary: DISC has the goal of expanding Northwestern students' perceptions of the capabilities of technology. Since then, we've gathered a diverse group of student leaders interested in using technology to make a positive impact on the world.

value.Name: Diversity in Biological Sciences
value.Summary: DIBS is an organization committed to fostering a community for underrepresented minorities (URM) and LGBTQ students within IBiS. This includes increasing resources for URM/LGBTQ students and advocating for an inclusive environment.

value.Name: Driskill Graduate Student Council
value.Summary: The DGP Student Council brings the concerns of students to the DGP administration and fills programming gaps in the areas of mentoring, social and research activities.

value.Name: Effective Altruism Club
value.Description:
Join our listserv here: 

https://bit.ly/eanu-signup

 

Ways to get involved this spring quarter:

-Intro Fellowship application

 

 

Are you a Northwestern undergrad hoping to learn about the most productive ways to combat the world's most pressing issues? Join Northwestern Effective Altruism Club!

From engaging with researchers focused on increasing efficiency of poverty alleviation, to interacting with professionals who work high-paying jobs to increase donation potential, to discussing high-impact careers with other students, Northwestern EA nurtures a community of students who aim to promote positive impact effectively.

 

Feel free to reach out to us with any questions at effectivealtruism@u.northwestern.edu!
value.Summary: Effective altruism is a philosophical and social movement that uses evidence and reasoning to determine the most effective ways to do good.

value.Name: Eight Counts Ballet Company
value.Summary: As Northwestern's only ballet-based organization, ECBC provides the Northwestern community with weekly ballet classes and performance opportunities.

2. To provide pathways for students to develop their skills in technology.

value.Summary: Community for FGLI (First-Gen Low-income) students who are interested in Tech!

value.Name: Engineering World Health Northwestern University
value.Description: EWH NU is part of a larger national organization that is headquartered in Chapel Hill, NC and is comprised of about 50 chapter worldwide. EWH works with university-based biomedical engineers, industry professionals, charities that manage donated medical equipment, the international health community and developing countries to combine innovation in appropriate technology with direct support to medical technology management, maintenance and repair. To learn more visit www.ewh.org
value.Summary: EWH NU seeks to inspire and mobilize students to improve the quality of healthcare in vulnerable communities. It provides members of NU EWH with the opportunity to repair, build, and learn about medical devices in the developing world.

value.Name: Engineers for a Sustainable World
value.Description:
Engineers for a Sustainable World at Northwestern (ESWNU) is an action-based group, mobilizing students through education, training, and hands-on projects related to environmental sustainability. Membership is not limited to engineers, but rather includes students from all schools at Northwestern, and entails working in student teams with faculty and professional advisers to further sustainability both locally and internationally. Our projects range in focus from renewable energy to urban agriculture, environmental technology, and much more. Check out our project blogs, website, and join our Slack channel here. For more information, please contact us at contact.eswnu@gmail.com.

*NOTE: Wildcat Connection membership is for existing members only, please join our Slack channel or send us an email if you would like to join ESWNU

https://youtu.be/Aae99SjBvGE
value.Summary: ESW empowers students to take on leadership roles in applying the principles of sustainability to their present and future work through action-based engineering projects and the education of ourselves and our community on sustainability topics.

value.Name: Engineers Without Borders
value.Description:
Engineers Without Borders-Northwestern works cooperatively with international communities to add engineering expertise to community-driven projects that address the community's most prevalent problems. Members of EWB-NU work throughout the academic year to brainstorm, research, survey, design, and prototype solutions to these problems, while working closely with a group of professional engineering mentors, an NGO, and most importantly, the partner community. These designs range from household necessities, to sanitation needs, to civil works, and beyond. Approximately once a year, EWB-NU sends a group of students and mentors to the community we work with to conduct further research and/or implement a phase of the project while building relationships with the members of the community.

EWB-NU also engages with the Northwestern, Evanston, and Chicago communities in to promote sustainability, engineering education, and stronger bonds between Northwestern and our surrounding communities. We do this through regular on-campus events, mentorship of local Chicago middle schools, and our developing service projects. We are always looking to increase the outreach that we do, so if you have ideas or a connection you would like to make, please reach out!

EWB-NU welcomes students of all academic backgrounds who are interested working toward making a positive impact on the world. Students gain experience in project management and leadership, design, teamwork, cross-cultural communication, fundraising, and interdisciplinary problem solving.
value.Summary: The mission of EWB-NU is to engineer and implement solutions that enrich the lives of communities and meet basic human needs through the completion of educational and collaborative projects — both locally and abroad.

value.Name: Environmental Engineering Undergraduate Society
value.Description: The Environmental Engineering Undergraduate Society (EnvEUS) at Northwestern gives students the opportunity to meet other Environmental Engineering students, participate in career development events, and apply technical skills outside of the classroom.
value.Summary: EnvEUS fosters community within the Environmental Engineering department at Northwestern.

value.Name: EPIC
value.Description:
Sign up for EPIC's email list here: https://forms.gle/YX18PND4cm6SPEhj6

Our Instagram 

 

EPIC is the premier entrepreneurial student org that aims to connect aspiring entrepreneurs with each other and with different entrepreneurial opportunities on/off campus. EPIC not only plans and creates amazing events and programs but also has internal teams that work on entrepreneurship focused projects and exposes students to the world of startups. Read below for brief descriptions on each team and/or program: 

General Membership: General membership is an opportunity for students to try out entrepreneurship in an open and supportive environment. They get exclusive access to EPIC events ranging from kick-ass speaker panels, design pop ups, product demos, and more. All internal and external EPIC members are also General Members.

 

Launch: Launch is a quarter-long student-led incubator program where you will learn everything from ideation to execution and turn napkin sketches into real, scalable businesses. Learn the ins and outs of an entrepreneurial mindset, then embark on an entrepreneurial journey (often for the first time) through an action-driven curriculum. Participants will form teams to start new companies that they build throughout the quarter, culminating in a Demo Day.  In the last 2 years we’ve helped 100+ students start over 25 new companies; you could be next.

 

Sprout: A week-long trip to the Bay Area with Workshops, Speakers, Site Visits, Networking, Startup Challenge, Food, Fun over Spring Break.
value.Summary: EPIC is Northwestern's interdisciplinary hub for entrepreneurship. From networking with alums and startup-building workshops, to our annual trip to Silicon Valley, to our accelerator, EPIC is the great starting place for entrepreneurship at Northwestern.

value.Name: Esports Club
value.Description:
A club for casual and competitive video gaming in the Northwestern community. Currently, there are regular meetings for League of Legends, Overwatch, and the Super Smash Bros. Series. While other franchises currently do not have regular meetings, there are plenty of ways to engage through Discord and through their respective games. If enough interest is expressed to have in-person meetings for game, they can easily be added.

Discord Invite: https://discord.gg/f5Hvydb (Join the Discord, it's where the vast majority of our events happen!)

Andres' (the President) Discord: Mark4447#5529 (Feel free to DM me with any questions/concerns!)
value.Summary: A club for competitive and casual video gaming in the Northwestern community. Competitive includes, but is not limited to, League of Legends, Super Smash Bros., Overwatch, and CS:GO. Casual encompasses everything else people are interested in.

value.Name: Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium
value.Description:
The Northwestern Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium (ESG) began in 2010 as an informal group of graduate students who were studying different disciplines, but doing similar work in the field of ethnic studies, an interdisciplinary field “that starts from the assumption that race and racism have been, and continue to be, profoundly powerful social and cultural forces in American society and in modernity at large” (as described by the Ethnic Studies Department at UC Berkeley). Although students were in programs as varied as African Studies, African-American Studies, American Studies, Anthropology, Asian-American Studies, Communication Studies, History, Musicology, Performance Studies, Religion, Rhetoric, and Sociology, they were all connected by an interest in similar authors, theories, and methodologies.

The ESG was created to provide an intellectual and social home for interested graduate students. Our programming activities, such as our quarterly potlucks and end-of-the-year workshop, are geared toward helping students achieve personal and professional goals as it relates to their work as Scholars of Color and scholars working in ethnic studies.
value.Summary: The Northwestern Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium (NU ESG) provides an intellectual and social home for graduate students doing work in the field of ethnic studies.
