Our members are of all skill and experience levels; from black belts with 10+ years of experience to some who have never heard of Taekwondo before joining, we are open to all. We offer weekly practices, hold belt tests, attend competitions, and perform at the annual KASA show. We are more than a team; we are a family :)
 
Our practices are mainly led by our experienced student captains, and are supported by a WTF-based external dojang. Practices involve a variety of activities including fitness training, sparring, poomsae, and demonstration prep. Join us Mondays 6:45-8:45pm, Wednesdays 6:45-8:45pm, and Saturdays 12:45-2:45pm in the Henry Crown Studio 1AB.
value.Summary: As the premier martial arts club on campus, we're dedicated to providing a friendly motivating environment for members of all abilities. We compete in tournaments and perform in shows year-round. Come learn the world's most popular martial art with us!

value.Name: Northwestern Triathlon Club
value.Description: The Northwestern Triathlon Club strives to make all members more confident in their triathlon abilities! We train together for both local and national competitions (or just for fun if racing isn't for you). We host swim, bike, and run workouts throughout the school year, all of which are optional. No tryouts required! Throughout the year, we race local races as well as races across the midwest as part of our conference, the MECTC. The club is open to people of all ability levels and currently has 90+ members. Whether you are a competitive athlete who is looking to improve, or somebody who wants to stay in shape while in college, this is the right club for you!
value.Summary: NU Triathlon competes at the highest level of collegiate triathlon and welcomes students of all abilities and backgrounds to join us. Already an elite triathlete? Ran or swam in high school? Don't know what a triathlon is? There's a place for you here!

value.Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Energy Club
value.Description: The Northwestern Undergraduate Energy Club (NUEC) seeks to develop and foster a community of NU undergrads who are passionate about the energy industry through educational, professional and discussion-based activities. By providing opportunities to learn about clean energy research, network with energy professionals and companies, or engage with energy initiatives both locally and globally, NUEC hopes to develop leaders in energy policy, business, and technology.
value.Summary: NUEC seeks to develop a community of NU undergrads who are passionate about the energy industry through educational, professional and discussion-based activities.

value.Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal
value.Description: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal (NULJ) provides a platform for the submission and discussion of law-related topics for students at Northwestern University. Our mission is to encourage legal and political awareness in the Northwestern community. Our website is thenulj.org
value.Summary: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal (NULJ) provides a platform for the submission and discussion of law-related topics for students at Northwestern University. Our mission is to encourage legal and political awareness in the Northwestern community.

value.Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal
value.Description: The Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal is an annual peer- and faculty-reviewed publication of research articles written by Northwestern undergraduates from all academic fields.  NURJ provides students the opportunity to experience writing and submitting original research.  The goals of the Journal are to encourage the dissemination of ideas, increase undergraduate involvement in research, and recognize the impressive work being performed by undergraduates.  NURJ staff members participate in finding peer and faculty editors, compiling the articles for the annual edition, designing the annual edition, and spreading the word about NURJ to the NU community.
value.Summary: The Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal (NURJ) is an annual student-produced journal that showcases outstanding research done by Northwestern undergraduates from across all academic fields.

value.Name: Northwestern University American Society of Mechanical Engineers
value.Description: ASME allows students to interact with practicing mechanical engineering professionals through quarterly roundtables or panels, providing the opportunity to network, develop skills, and learn together. At Northwestern, students learn from peers and faculty in skill workshops and a mentorship program, creating a community around mechanical engineering. Additionally, ASME serves to inform and assist students in their pursuit of career opportunities directly related to the field of mechanical engineering. Participation in design projects such as the ASME Student Design Competition provides outlets for hands-on project-based learning and skill development.
value.Summary: The Northwestern University chapter of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers

value.Name: Northwestern University Catholic Student Association
value.Description:
The Catholic Student Association (CaSA) is the student group representing Catholic students and their friends at Northwestern University. We are affiliated with the Sheil Catholic Center and provide opportunities to engage in fellowship, education, prayer, and service. 

 

CaSA welcomes all students to participate in our events, including retreats, lectures, discussions, service trips, bible study, small faith groups and many other ministries and activities. During the school year, Sunday Mass is celebrated at 9:30 a.m., 11:00 a.m., and 5:00 p.m. and daily Mass is celebrated on weekdays at 5:00 p.m.

 

Whether you identify as Catholic, Christian, or are seeking a spiritual path, we're here to walk with you on your spiritual journey. Come with your questions. Come as you are. You belong here!
value.Summary: CaSA gathers Catholic students and their friends to grow in friendship with each other and Christ. We invite students to explore faith, serve others, and enjoy each others' company. Our home is the Sheil Catholic Center.

value.Name: Northwestern University Community for Human Rights
value.Description:
The Northwestern University Community for Human Rights (NUCHR) is a voice for global human rights on campus.

Through informed dialogue, general member meetings, educational excursions, social events, and year-round programming, we bridge connections between undergraduates and international discussions on current human rights issues. Our group is oriented to assist students in grappling with complex histories and inequities in order to develop deep critical thinking abilities and to mobilize inspired action.

Each winter, NUCHR explores a distinct topic in the field of human rights while playing host to the largest student run, student attended human right's conference in the nation.
value.Summary: Welcome to the NU Community for Human Rights! Our aim is to spark dialogue, foster activism, and improve awareness surrounding global and local human rights challenges.

value.Name: Northwestern University Dance Marathon
value.Description:
Overview

Now in its 49th year, Northwestern University Dance Marathon (NUDM) is one of the largest independent student-run philanthropies in the nation. Our mission is to unite the Northwestern, Evanston, and Greater Chicagoland communities through philanthropic fundraising, service, and education. A year-long effort culminating in a 30-hour dance marathon, NUDM strives to create an inclusive and enriching environment for the NUDM student body, our rotating primary beneficiary, and our longstanding secondary beneficiary, the Evanston Community Foundation (ECF). Since 1975, NUDM has raised more than $20 million for more than 35 different charitable organizations.

Our History

In 1975, Northwestern University Dance Marathon, the philanthropic child of Alpha Tau Omega fraternity and the Associated Student Government, was born on the Northwestern University Evanston campus. It was initially called the “Dance to Give Them a Chance” marathon, and it benefited the American Epilepsy Foundation and the Arc. Fifteen couples made it through the 52-hour marathon, raising $9,100 at Blomquist Memorial Gymnasium.

 

This past year, NUDM raised $580,778 for Chicago Youth Programs– a nonprofit striving to improve the life opportunities and health of youth in underserved neighborhoods, primarily on the south and west sides of Chicago, through long-term academic, emotional and mental support– and the Evanston Community Foundation – which funds a variety of local grants to deserving organizations with the goal of helping Evanston thrive.

Where We Are Now

This year, NUDM is thrilled to partner with Chicago Youth Programs (CYP). CYP gives their participants the tools for self-regulation, empathy and communication, while also enriching their passions through socializing programs in arts and culture. This year, NUDM and CYP are working together to help Chicago’s youth overcome systemic inequities and obtain the higher education necessary to break the cycle of poverty.
value.Summary: NUDM is a year-long effort culminating in a 30-hour dance marathon that unites the Northwestern, Evanston, and Greater Chicagoland communities through awareness, service, education, and philanthropic fundraising.

value.Name: Northwestern University Model United Nations
value.Description:
Please see our website numun.org for more information!

The Northwestern University Model United Nations conference originated in 2004 when a group of dedicated Northwestern undergrads sought to fill a void in the community’s extracurricular department. In the years since, the conference has almost tripled in size, but its dedication to delegate experience has never changed. NUMUN is typically hosted every year at the Norris University Center on campus, directly adjacent to Lake Michigan.

Our mission is to be provide a premier high school conference and field a top tier competitive travel team. Our high-quality, dedicated secretariat and staff create a personal, professional, and passionate simulation experience. We seek to broaden delegates’ knowledge of worldwide politics, increase interpersonal skills, and create impactful experiences.
value.Summary: Our mission is to offer a premier Model UN conference for High School students from around the world, while fielding a top flight competitive travel team that can compete on the national American circuit.

value.Name: Northwestern University Nanotechnology Club
value.Summary: The Northwestern University Nanotechnology Club (nanoNU) is an interdisciplinary student organization focused on the current and potential applications of nanotechnology in society.

value.Name: Northwestern University Native American and Indigenous Student Alliance
value.Summary: Northwestern University Native American and Indigenous Student Association is dedicated to promoting and inspiring the interests of the community of Native American students and those who appreciate Native American cultures at Northwestern University.

value.Name: Northwestern University Outdoors Club
value.Description:
NOTE: Please visit our website Home | NU Outdoors Club (nuoutdoorsclub.org) and fill out the contact form to join our mailing list! Trip invitations and club updates will be exclusively sent out to our Listserv, so if you want to join the club, complete the contact form on the website or email us at nuoutdoorclub@gmail.com.

 

NUOC is a group of students who love the outdoors! Everyone and anyone is welcome to join, lead, or plan trips. Prior experience is rarely necessary. During our 50+ years of existence on the Northwestern campus, we have gone backpacking, canoeing, hiking, climbing, camping, skiing, snowshoeing, spelunking, and more. We also provide free gear rentals to club members. The next adventure is up to you! Send us an email at nuoutdoorclub@gmail.com to join our listserv!
value.Summary: Providing your outdoors fix since 1965.

value.Name: Northwestern University SACNAS Chapter
value.Summary: SACNAS is a society of scientists dedicated to fostering the success of Hispanic/Chicano and Native American scientists—from college students to professionals—to attain advanced degrees, careers, and positions of leadership in science.

value.Name: Northwestern University Sailing Team
value.Description:
Past History:
The Northwestern Sailing Team can trace its history back to the late 1950's when teams practiced in downtown Chicago, with the NU boathouse constructed on campus in 1974. Since that time the NU sailing team has ranged from a relaxed learn-to-sail program to a nationally competitive team attending numerous national championships and graduating two college all Americans: Roslyn Rea who received sailing's top honor 1987 and Scotia Ryer in both 1995/1996. Today Northwestern continues to be a top school in the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association.


Schedule:

Competition occurs from early September through Thanksgiving and starts back up in late March continuing through early June with regattas most weekends. The Northwestern sailing team attends upwards of 25 events each year. Practice is held in the fall and spring Monday thru Thursday from 3-6 out of the NU boathouse. Team members are asked to attend practice at least twice a week. Single-Handed and Sloop Nationals occur in the fall while Co-ed, Women's, and Team Race Nationals are held in the spring.

League Affiliation:

College sailing features over 200 schools and is governed by the Inter-Collegiate Sailing Association (ICSA). The ICSA is broken down into seven regional districts, with the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association, of which Northwestern is a member, stretching from Minnesota to Ohio.


Club Dues:

200 dollars per year. Team members are also required to purchase proper sailing gear their first year.


Tryout Schedule:

Try outs are held each fall.


Practice Locations:

NU Sailing Center, located on south beach which features a fleet of 12 420's and 8 lasers.


Competition Locations:

Schools all over the country, however most events are in the Midwest. Frequent locations are Wisconsin, Minnesota, Ohio State, and Michigan, however this past year we attended events in Seattle, Larchmont, and Dallas.
value.Summary: We are a student-run, student-led club sport team at Northwestern, practicing on Lake Michigan out of the NU Sailing Center and competing in regattas on both a local and national scale.

value.Name: Northwestern University Space Technology and Rocketry Society
value.Description:
NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY SPACE TECHNOLOGY AND ROCKETRY SOCIETY is a organization comprised of four different aerospace interest teams. The mission of each team is outlined below. Overall, the goal of NUSTARS is to advocate for research related to space exploration.

NASA Space Grant (NSG): Design, build, and launch a reusable rocket in accordance with NASA Midwest Space Grant competition rules

Aero NU: Design, build, and fly remote controlled planes

NUSTARS Experimental Technology (NSET): Design and build a CubeSat (a miniaturized satellite) for NASA's CubeSat Launch Initiative 

Certification and Education: Build and launch a high powered rocket for Level 1 High Power Rocketry Certification. Engage students and educators at Northwestern and in the Evanston and Chicago communities in learning about aviation, space technology, and rocketry

*NUSTARS is always looking to expand and create new teams. Any student with a passion for aerospace is encouraged to join!

Past teams include: 

Revolutionary Aerospace Systems Concept- Academic Linkage (RASC-AL): complete the design and documentation for a scientific payload, in accordance with the NASA Revolutionary Aerospace Systems Concept- Academic Linkage rules

Near Space Exploration Team: design, build, and launch a high altitude weather balloon with the long term goal of completing a data logging system and competing in a national design competition

Alka-Rocket: design, build, and launch an alka-seltzer powered rocket in accordance with the Bayer Alka-Rocket Challenge
value.Summary: We are Northwestern's aerospace interest group dedicated to participating in aviation and NASA rocketry competitions and facilitating student-proposed projects. We also reach out to local schools to get the next generation excited about space exploration

value.Name: Northwestern University Special Olympics
value.Description: The purpose of Northwestern University Special Olympics is to integrate individuals with developmental disabilities in our community through athletic competition, inclusive programming, and events to raise awareness. The objective of Northwestern University Special Olympics shall be to partner with Evanston Special Olympics in joint programming. Northwestern University Special Olympics coordinates over 100 student volunteers and coaches for Special Olympics athletes in the community, special events on campus, and awareness and educational outreach about intellectual disabilities.
value.Summary: Northwestern University Special Olympics is the oldest and largest collegiate Special Olympics chapter. Our mission is to integrate individuals with developmental disabilities into our community through inclusive programming.

value.Name: Northwestern University Table Tennis Club
value.Description:
History

The Northwestern University Table Tennis Club (NUTTC) was founded on March of 2006. Inspired by the table tennis talent and potential at Northwestern, a group of students came together to form a club to encourage and foster the skills and interests of table tennis enthusiasts around campus. Also, we seek to provide opportunities for students to compete in regional and national tournaments. Now, the club holds weekly practices and organizes local and regional tournaments throughout the year, and will be travelling to various locations to compete with other colleges. 

Philosophy

The club is open to all skill levels from those never having held a ping pong paddle before to those who have been trained by coaches for many years. We encourage all those who have interest in the sport to come join us at our practices. Attendance is not mandatory; members can come and go as they please. 

About the Club

We have around 15-20 regular members attending our weekly meetings. We have four tables, thanks to the great support of Norris and the Sports Club Department. We also provide table tennis balls and paddles for those who do not own one.

Practice Schedule

Our practices are typically held Sunday, Tuesday, and Thursday evenings from 8-10 pm at SPAC, in the second floor tennis court bleachers. 

Email reminders will be sent weekly. To receive these reminders or hear more weekly updates of the club, please subscribe to the listserv by employing the following steps:

1) Send e-mail to listserv@listserv.it.northwestern.edu without any subject line.
2) Type the following command in the message:

SUBSCRIBE NUTableTennis Firstname Lastname

(ex. SUBSCRIBE NUTableTennis John Smith)
value.Summary: The NUTTC is a student-ran group group focusing on the development of skill and interest in table tennis on campus. The club has both a competitive and recreational team to suit the preferences of students' interest.

value.Name: Northwestern University Women Filmmakers Alliance
value.Description: The Northwestern University Women Filmmaker's Alliance is a student-run film board dedicated to supporting women and LGBTQ+ in the entertainment industry. We provide grants, mentorship events, industry panels, and many other exciting events to the RTVF community.
value.Summary: Supporting the advancement of women in film, on and off campus.

value.Name: Northwestern Wildside
value.Description: Northwestern Wildside is the university's official athletic student section, which unites students at Northwestern University through their passion for athletics. The group is known for its energetic and enthusiastic support of the university's athletic teams, particularly at home games and events. As a society shared between NU Student Affairs and NU Athletics, Northwestern Wildside provides an inclusive space for students to come together, show their school spirit, and engage with their fellow peers. Through their collective efforts, Northwestern Wildside embodies the university's spirit of community and collaboration, helping to foster a sense of belonging among students from all walks of life.
value.Summary: Welcome to the student section of Northwestern University!

value.Name: Northwestern Women's Club Basketball
value.Summary: We practice 2 times a week and travel the Midwest for games throughout each quarter :)

value.Name: NROTC
value.Description:
The Northwestern NROTC unit was established as one of six original units in the United States. Today, the program develops midshipmen mentally, morally and physically and imbues them with the highest ideals of duty, and loyalty.

We welcome all freshmen and sophomores to contact Lauren Kearney for more information.
value.Summary: The NROTC Program was established to educate and train qualified young men and women for service as commissioned officers in the Navy and Marine Corps.

value.Name: NSSLHA-Undergraduate
value.Description:
The purpose of our organization is i) to encourage professional interest among undergraduate students in the study of Human Communication Sciences and Disorders, ii) to provide opportunities to gain practical and applicable experience and knowledge related to a future career in CSD, iii) to serve as a welcoming, open, and tolerant space to kindle CSD-related discussion by those pursuing or interested in the field of study from all identities and backgrounds, iv) to spread awareness of CSD causes to our general student body members and peers and v) to develop and sustain a meaningful and mutually beneficial connection between NSSLHA-Undergraduate and NU NSSLHA Graduate as well as faculty and leaders in the CSD Department. The intended goals for the organization are primarily based in the furthering of the bond within the CSD undergraduate community and in providing adequate and useful support, guidance, and opportunities to successfully achieve their professional goals with ease. 

More information on the overall mission and purpose can be found from the national NSSLHA organization.
value.Summary: NSSLHA-Undergraduate creates an open, inclusive, and equitable space for undergraduates interested in the study of Human Communication Sciences and Disorders to come together in pursuit of academic, social, and professional opportunities in this field.

value.Name: NU Asian Magazine
value.Description: NU Asian Magazine is Northwestern University’s Asian American-interest magazine. We publish at least twice a year and cover anything and everything related to the greater Asian American community.
value.Summary: NU Asian Magazine is Northwestern University's Asian American-interest magazine. We publish at least twice a year and cover anything and everything related to the greater Asian American community.

value.Name: NU Curling
value.Description:
NU Curling is a community-building graduate club dedicated to teaching and playing the great winter sport of curling. Our FREE events take place at the Chicago Curling Club, located a short carpool ride away in Northbrook. From fall to spring we host weekly lessons, games, and broomstacking (post-game drinks and snacks) and would like all of you to join in. Newcomers are highly encouraged to come try it out, as are any curling pros.

In addition to these weekly events, we have also sent teams to Regional and National Curling Tournaments and have held the Northwestern Bonspiel to end our past six seasons.
value.Summary: A community-building graduate club dedicated to teaching and playing the great winter sport of curling. Our FREE events take place at the Chicago Curling Club, located a short carpool ride away in Northbrook. From fall to spring we host weekly lessons.

value.Name: NU Heights
value.Description:
The volunteers involved with NU Heights have the opportunity to tutor and mentor local students in elementary, middle, and high school. The subjects include math, science, and reading comprehension, among others. There are morning and afternoon shifts each day throughout the week to fit your schedule! 

Tutors working in a classroom during the school day may assist the teacher with various tasks, work one-on-one with a student, or help a small group of students independently. The responsibilities vary depending on the teacher. After school, tutors may offer homework assistance, mentor, or do various fun activities with the students. There are also opportunities to work in Spanish since many of our students are ESL and use Spanish at home.
value.Summary: The volunteers involved with NU Heights have the opportunity to tutor and mentor elementary and middle school-aged students in various local schools. Tutors work either in classrooms throughout the school day or during after-school activities.

value.Name: NU Nights
value.Description: NU Nights is a student-led organization with the aim of bringing substance-free, late night programming activities to Northwestern undergraduate students and uniting our campus community through these activities. Programming includes a variety of on-campus and off-campus events, catering to the needs and interests of our student body, usually between 8pm to 11pm on Fridays or Saturdays. Events include, but are not limited to, arts and crafts, game nights, trivia, excursions, and student group collaborations.
value.Summary: NU Nights is a student-led organization with the aim of bringing substance-free, late night programming activities to Northwestern undergraduate students and uniting our campus community through these activities.

value.Name: NU Orthodox Christian Fellowship
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: NU Photonics/SPIE
value.Summary: We welcome people from the fields of engineering, materials science, chemistry, and others. We promote the science of light at Northwestern, as well as foment social and professional interaction of our student members and faculty.

value.Name: NU Robotics
value.Description:
NU Robotics is a student-run organization that sponsors a multitude of engineering focused projects for Northwestern University. Our mission is to develop a core community of undergraduate student builders interested in robotics and unifying them across majors. We offer a place for students to express their creative and innovative side as they work on student-created projects and apply the knowledge learned in class to gain practical experience in a fun way. The projects range from technical research projects to start-up ideas to yearly competitions. We welcome every type of student and hold workshops during the fall to teach and provide hands-on experience to newcomers, so students from all over can join the build!

We strongly encourage interested members to join our slack workspace- this is where we do most of our communication!  We'll send out reminders about events and give updates on what's happening in the club as well.
value.Summary: NU Robotics Club is an open interdisciplinary group working on robotics competitions and design projects in teams of undergraduate students. We are always looking for new project ideas, feel free to reach out. All skill levels are welcome!

value.Name: NU SIAM Student Chapter
value.Description: The aim of the Northwestern Student Chapter of SIAM is to provide a platform for students involved in science to interact with one another. We organize social and scientific events that bring together students from all areas of science as SIAM is a strong promoter of interdisciplinary collaboration. Students that use mathematical, computational, statistical, or visualization methods for their research are strongly encouraged to become a member and participate in this organization!
value.Summary: NU's official student chapter of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. We organize events to promote interaction between students involved in different areas of science.

value.Name: NU Solar Car Team
value.Description:
The Northwestern University Solar Car Team (NUsolar) is an undergraduate student-run organization that designs, builds, and races solar-powered electric vehicles. We are one of the most diverse student organizations within the McCormick School of Engineering. Our members come from all areas of expertise: software, electrical, mechanical, and chemical engineers, as well as economics, music, journalism, and film majors.


NUsolar’s mission is to prepare Northwestern students for careers in engineering, manufacturing, marketing, and leadership positions, by providing the opportunity for them to engage in real-life, out-of-the classroom projects. Our members learn how to function in a specialized team and work within budgets and deadlines. They make connections with their peers and with our advising professors, as well as with potential employers in all sorts of fields.

Each summer, our team participates in two nation-wide solar car races, the Formula Sun Grand Prix (FSGP) and the American Solar Challenge (ASC). Both races are endurance-type races in which we compete against teams from other universities, driving our car for up to a week on only the power we can get from the sun.

In addition to racing our car, we also participate in numerous outreach events in the wider Chicago area. We frequently take our car to elementary schools and community service events to promote an interest in STEM education and increase awareness for “green” vehicle alternatives within our community.
value.Summary: We are an undergraduate student team at Northwestern that builds solar powered electric vehicles, which we race in a number of national competitions against other university teams. We are also active in the Chicago community.

value.Name: NU Syllabus Yearbook
value.Description:
Syllabus, founded in 1885, is the official undergraduate yearbook of Northwestern University. Published by SPC (Students Publishing Company) and run by Northwestern students, Syllabus seeks to include memorable events and highlights of each year as well as campus groups, organizations, and living units. All seniors are invited to have their portrait taken for inclusion in our senior section. Parents and friends of graduating seniors may purchase a special ad. Syllabus yearbooks are delivered on campus in May of each year.

 

The Syllabus is created by students, for students. There are opportunities for photography, design, and copy writing ranging from academics, to sports, to clubs and organizations within Syllabus.
value.Summary: Syllabus, founded in 1885, is the official undergraduate yearbook of Northwestern University. Published by Students Publishing Company, Inc. Syllabus features the memorable events that make up the collective Northwestern experience.

value.Name: NU Thrift Store
value.Description: We are a student-run thrift store currently organizing pop-ups at the end of every quarter. Our mission is to bring affordable and sustainable clothing to the Northwestern community, while donating our proceeds to social/environmental justice groups. Our permanent location is in Parkes Hall.
value.Summary: We are a student-run thrift store currently organizing pop-ups at the end of every quarter. Our mission is to bring affordable and sustainable clothing to the Northwestern community, while donating our proceeds to social/environmental justice groups.

value.Name: Office of Fraternity & Sorority Life
value.Description:
Vision Statement:

We aim to create a socially just and responsible fraternity and sorority community.

Core Values:

  • Wellness: the physical, mental, and emotional well-being of the chapter.
  • Accountability: the knowledge of, commitment to, and willingness to accept responsibility for policies and expectations.
  • Chapter Development: the ongoing individual and collective development of members.
  • Social Justice: the holistic understanding of privilege, power, and oppression and a commitment to action.
  • Campus & Community Partnership: the contribution to campus and surrounding communities through the development of sustainable and purposeful partnerships.
value.Summary: The Office of Fraternity & Sorority Life provides support for the vibrant community of affiliated students at Northwestern University.

value.Name: Office of Student Enrichment Services
value.Description: Student Enrichment Services (SES) works with low-income and/or first-generation students to enhance their academic success, personal development, and professional growth. Through campus-wide partnerships, SES builds an inclusive Northwestern community by engaging students and their allies with programming and dialogue around the low-income and/or first-generation experience.
value.Summary:
Hear from students, staff, and faculty about their first-generation and/or low-income experience at Northwestern.
http://www.northwestern.edu/enrichment/about-us/we-are-here-video/index.html

value.Name: OM at Northwestern
value.Description: OM at Northwestern is a spiritual student group on campus whose mission is to share and cultivate an awareness of Hinduism with the Northwestern community through social events, educational discussions, and dialogue. Our vision is to have safe spaces for students to explore their curiosities in Hindu culture and traditions, while also being able to pray in comfort. All undergraduates, graduate students, faculty and staff are welcome to participate in OM's activities. Members of OM do not have to be Hindu or have a background in Hinduism.
value.Summary: Religious/Spiritual Hindu student organization on Northwestern University Evanston campus

value.Name: Omega Delta Phi Fraternity, Inc.
value.Description:
Alpha Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed November 25, 1997

"One Culture, Any Race."

Omega Delta Phi's Signature Events: Founders' Month Celebration, Cesar Chavez Day of Service, and Silver Rose Scholarship Banquet

You may visit the Alpha Alpha Chapter's website at http://www.nuodphi.com/.

 

National Organization Facts

National founding date: November 25, 1987

The purpose of this Brotherhood, a Service/Social fraternity dedicated to the needs and concerns of the community, is and shall be to promote and maintain the traditional values of Unity, Honesty, Integrity, and Leadership. This Brotherhood was founded in order to provide, to ANY man, a diverse fraternal experience which coincides with a higher education.

You may view the Omega Delta Phi national website at www.omegadeltaphi.com.
value.Summary: The Alpha Alpha Chapter of Omega Delta Phi was installed at Northwestern University on November 25th, 1997. The brothers of Omega Delta Phi make it their organization's goals to graduate its members and to serve its surrounding communities.

value.Name: One Book
value.Description: Over the summer, copies of this year's book will be delivered to the homes of every incoming first-year undergraduate and distributed to hundreds of members of Northwestern’ s faculty, staff and graduate student communities as well as community partners beyond our campus.
value.Summary: Nate Silver’s improbably entertaining book on statistics and forecasting, The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail — but Some Don’t, is Northwestern University’s One Book One Northwestern all-campus read for the 2016-17 academic year.

value.Name: Opera Project for University Singers
value.Summary: Opera Project for University Singers (OPUS) is an ensemble of undergraduate singers and actors at Northwestern University who seek to direct, produce, and perform student-driven opera.

value.Name: oSTEM (Undergraduate Chapter)
value.Description: TBA
value.Summary: TBA

value.Name: Out Da Box
value.Description:
Out Da Box is Northwestern's hit Campus Sketch Comedy and Improv group — their Spring Show in Shanley being the must-see show of the Northwestern Season. For more than 30 years, Out Da Box has strived to bring comedy to all Northwestern Students — of any major or background — through their consistently sold-out improv and sketch comedy shows. ODB commits to pushing social and political boundaries all while raising the bar of comedy on campus! Out Da Box has many prestigious alumni who've gone on to Second City, IO, and Comedy Central.
 
For audition information to join this one-of-a-kind group on campus, email president Almaya Wiley-Yancy at almayawiley-yancy2023@u.northwestern.edu!
value.Summary: From what started as a revue of the African American Theater Ensemble in the 1970s, ODB has emerged with sold-out sketch and improv shows that provide a spotlight for students of color and marginalized identities to practice comedy on their own terms.

value.Name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (Graduate chapter)
value.Summary: The goal of this oSTEM chapter is to empower LGBTQIA+ people in STEM to succeed personally, academically, and professionally by cultivating environments and communities that nurture innovation, leadership, and advocacy.

value.Name: Outdoor Volleyball Association
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Pakistani Students Association
value.Description:
PSA aims to represent a home away from home for international students, a way for the diaspora to connect with their roots, and a means to project a positive image of the country amongst the Northwestern community. Through programming and collaborations with different organizations, both within Northwestern and outside, we hope to offer the following along with many other:

  • Cultural gatherings e.g. for Eid, Independence Day etc. 
  • Collaborative literary and political speaker events with other interest groups like SASA, the Subcontinent Project etc.
  • Networking opportunities with Pakistani professionals in Pakistan and the US
  • Fundraising and awareness for community uplifting in Pakistan and for South Asian communities in the Chicago area 

It is difficult to represent every group under an umbrella which is why we hope to offer a unique space for those who find they do not completely fit in present structures, but without drawing any restrictions on membership. With the aforementioned programming we hope to offer members a sense of security, belonging and opportunities to engage with the identities they hold dear, hence allowing them to thrive in their time at Northwestern.
value.Summary: The organization intends to be a space for international and diaspora Pakistani students and all those interested in learning more about and connecting with the communities and traditions of Pakistan.

value.Name: Pan African Students' Union
value.Description: The Pan-African Students Union (PASU) is a student organization that is dedicated to developing a political and ethical consciousness among students who are committed to the advancement of the African continent. Inspired by the historic vision of Pan-Africanism, we engage in meaningful programs such as reading groups and discussion series to help us build an understanding of the challenges facing Africa today.
value.Summary: PASU is a student organization that is dedicated to developing a political and ethical consciousness among students who are committed to the development of Africa.

value.Name: Panhellenic Association
value.Description: The Northwestern Panhellenic Association (PHA) consists of 12 nationally-recognized chapters. Each sorority has a chapter house on the south end of Northwestern's campus. All of the organizations have a long-standing (inter)national history and traditions as many of the Northwestern chapters are more than 100 years old. Nearly 1600 women of all backgrounds and interests are members of PHA sororities at NU. Panhellenic women are leaders and participants in campus organizations, serve the NU and Evanston communities, and excel in the classroom.
value.Summary: The Northwestern Panhellenic Association (PHA) consists of 12 nationally-recognized chapters. Each chapter has a sorority house on the south end of Northwestern's campus, and all of the organizations have a long-standing history at NU.

value.Name: Panoramic Photography
value.Description: Panoramic Photography serve photographers on campus through providing workshops on photography skills, group photoshoots in Chicago, and an online magazine where photographers can showcase their work.
value.Summary: Panoramic Photography serve photographers on campus through providing workshops on photography skills, group photoshoots in Chicago, and an online magazine where photographers can showcase their work.

value.Name: Parliamentary Debate Union
value.Description:
Weekly Meetings: Tuesdays @ 7pm in Harris Hall L06.

All are welcome!
value.Summary: Parliamentary debate is a form of extemporaneous debate in which two teams of two people go against each other. You can debate about almost anything and no prior experience is needed!

value.Name: Peer Inclusion Educators
value.Description: Peer Inclusion Educators (PIE) is a student organization dedicated to fostering an inclusive learning environment for issues surrounding personal awareness and social justice to peers through facilitation of specific and intentional programming to campus organizations such as student groups, Greek letter organizations and residential communities.
value.Summary: Peer Inclusion Educators (PIE) is a student organization dedicated to fostering an inclusive learning environment for issues surrounding personal awareness and social justice to peers through facilitation of specific and intentional programming to campus

value.Name: Personal Finance Student Association
value.Description: The purpose of our organization is to assist Northwestern students in managing their personal finance. We hope to educate our fellow students in responsible financial practices and a healthy understanding of the five branches of personal finance (taxes, budgeting, credit, long-term planning/investing, and insurance), in addition to helping them navigate and utilize the resources Northwestern already offers. We also want to develop a community that understands the difficulties and supports the unique perspective of FGLI students, as well as advocate to the University in regards to the financial needs of all students.
value.Summary: Our organization's purpose is to provide financial education to students at Northwestern.

value.Name: Phi Alpha Delta
value.Description: The fundamental objective of Phi Alpha Delta is to assist undergraduate students to make an informed choice in selecting law as a career, in deciding which law school to attend, and in preparing for the rigors of law school. Phi Alpha Delta is an international coed professional fraternity, and it remains the only Law Fraternity with a national Pre-Law Program committed to meeting the needs of undergraduate students interested in the law.
value.Summary: Phi Alpha Delta is an international coed professional fraternity, and it remains the only Law Fraternity with a national Pre-Law Program committed to meeting the needs of undergraduate students interested in the law.

value.Name: Phi Delta Epsilon
value.Description: The Illinois Gamma chapter of PhiDE International Medical Fraternity at Northwestern University provides its members with mentorship, leadership and volunteering opportunities, social activities and scientific education. Our international philanthropy is Children's Miracle Network Hospitals, which we fundraise for every year. PhiDE brings high-profile speakers to NU's campus to discuss important issues in the medical field, such as the new health care plan, the role of research and funding in medicine, and even speakers that advice pre-medical students on their path into medical school. Our recruitment of members occurs in the fall and spring quarters.
value.Summary: Co-ed International Medical Fraternity that provides, mentoring, networking, leadership development, scientific education, volunteering opportunities, and a support community on the NU campus.

value.Name: Phi Gamma Delta
value.Description:
Pi Chapter, Northwestern University
2331 Sheridan Rd.

"Friendship, the sweetest influence."

Chapter President: Alex Conway

Organization Facts

National Founding Date: May 1, 1848

Colors: Royal purple

You may visit the national website at www.phigam.org.

Iota Chapter, Northwestern University
630 Emerson St.
