Organization Facts

National Founding Date: October 6, 1898 (New England Conservatory)

Object: The object of this fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit, the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students, the advancement of music in America, and a loyalty to the Alma Mater

Colors: Red, Black and Gold

Philanthropy: Mills Music Mission

You may visit the local website at: http://iotasinfonia.org

You may visit the national website at http://www.sinfonia.org
value.Summary: The object of this fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit, the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students, the advancement of music in America, and a loyalty to the Alma Mater

value.Name: Philanthropy Choir
value.Description: Philanthropy Choir is a student-run community service show choir dedicated to bringing quality musical performances to locations such as retirement homes, women’s shelters, and hospitals. This club is perfect for students of all experience levels who seek an outlet to perform music, have fun, and do good.
value.Summary: Philanthropy Choir is a student-run community service show choir dedicated to fundraising for local charities and bringing quality musical performances to locations around the community.

value.Name: Physicians for Human Rights Student Program
value.Description: The Physicians for Human Rights Student Program is a chapter of a national student program committed to advocacy for health and human rights violations on undergraduate and medical school campuses.
value.Summary: The Physicians for Human Rights Student Program is a chapter of a national student program committed to advocacy for health and human rights violations on undergraduate and medical school campuses.

value.Name: Pickleball Club
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment
value.Description: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment (PIE) is Northwestern University's chapter of the International Game Developers Association. We run game tutorials, host game jams, and provide students with the resources to make their very own games. It can be tabletop games, video games, card games, or whatever you can think of.
value.Summary: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment (PIE) is Northwestern University's chapter of the International Game Developers Association.

value.Name: Planned Parenthood Generation Action
value.Description: Planned Parenthood Generation Action is a movement of young people across identities and issues that organizes with, by, and for their generation in order to achieve reproductive freedom. Planned Parenthood Generation Action at Northwestern University will work with local Planned Parenthood staff to learn about and engage in youth organizing, leadership development, voter engagement programs, and infrastructure building.
value.Summary: Planned Parenthood Generation Action at NU will work with local Planned Parenthood staff to learn about and engage in youth organizing, leadership development, voter engagement, and other activities to promote reproductive rights and freedom for all.

value.Name: Plant-it Purple Graduate Garden
value.Description:
Plant-it Purple Graduate Gardens is a community garden located on the patio of the Technological Institute on Northwestern’s Evanston campus.  The garden provides a place where graduate students, staff, and others can interact and relax outside of their labs and offices.  Working in and utilizing the garden fosters relationships between graduate students from many different disciplines by bringing them together to cultivate and enjoy a living project.  The garden is a benefit and an outlet to students, staff, and the community.

 

Our organization is most active through our listserv and Facebook page (which is linked at the top right). Come join us, we'd love to have you!
value.Summary: We are a community garden located on the patio of the Technological Institute on the Evanston campus.  The garden is a place where graduate students, staff, and others can interact and relax outside of their labs and offices.

value.Name: Platypus Affiliated Society
value.Description: We are the Northwestern Chapter of the Platypus Affiliated Society. Platypus is a project for the self-criticism, self-education, and, ultimately, the practical reconstitution of a Marxian Left. The Platypus Affiliated Society, established in December 2006, organizes reading groups, public fora, research and journalism focused on problems and tasks inherited from the “Old” (1920s-30s), “New” (1960s-70s) and post-political (1980s-90s) Left for the possibilities of emancipatory politics today.
value.Summary: We are the Northwestern Chapter of the Platypus Affiliated Society. Platypus organizes reading groups, public fora, research and journalism on the history and present tasks of the Left and Marxism.

value.Name: Playing with Fire
value.Description:
Playing with Fire is a student-led playback theatre group at Northwestern University.

Playback Theatre is an interactive form of improvisational theatre in which audience members tell stories from their lives and cast them from an ensemble of players. The ensemble then enacts the story on the spot.
value.Summary: Playing with Fire is a student-led playback theatre group.

value.Name: Podcats!
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Polerize
value.Description: One of North America's first collegiate pole dance organizations, Polerize seeks to empower and educate the student population through pole dance classes and performances.
value.Summary: To create a safe space for body movement that allows students to explore the sensuality, strength, and physical fitness of their own bodies  — while defying historical narratives of gendered oppression.

value.Name: Polish American Student Alliance
value.Description: The Northwestern University Polish-American Student Alliance (PASA) was founded in the fall of 1996. Since its establishment, PASA has grown tremendously. PASA's mission is simple: to promote cultural awareness of all things Polish. The organization does not restrict membership solely to those of Polish descent. It welcomes students with any interest in Polish history, society, and culture. Its dual goal is to teach as well as to learn. We have accomplished this in the past by advocating for Polish language education, hosting bonfires, and holding an annual Polish Culture Night.
value.Summary: The Polish American Student Alliance (PASA) seeks to connect the Northwestern community with Chicagoland's rich Polish traditions. PASA commits itself to building a strong community among its members and working with other cultural student groups.

value.Name: Powerlifting Club
value.Description:
A club oriented towards all those interested in lifting. Come join a community of individuals with a shared interest in weightlifting and meet new gym buddies and friends. If you are looking to compete, this is also the place for you!

 

Join our groupme! https://groupme.com/join_group/87873271/E8EP4aR9
value.Summary: A club oriented towards all those interested in lifting. Come join a community of individuals with a shared interest in weightlifting and meet new gym buddies and friends. If you are looking to compete, this is also the place for you!

value.Name: Prairie Cats Ecological Restoration Club
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Pre-Dental Society
value.Description: Northwestern Pre-Dental Society (NUPDS) strives to unite NU pre-dental students and serves as a resource as students explore careers in oral healthcare or prepare to enter dental school.  NUPDS is focused on educating students about career options in dentistry and offering support to undergraduates navigating pre-dental preparations including course requirements, volunteer opportunities, and DAT test preparation.  NUPDS also aims to strengthen networking connections with dental professionals and students in the greater Chicago area as well as within the NU community.
value.Summary: The pre-dental society is a group dedicated to pre-dental preparation, education and service in the field of oral healthcare.  We strive to provide resources and a community for students pursuing pre-dental studies.

value.Name: Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University
value.Description: The Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University is a group dedicated to students who are pursing a pre-vet agenda on their path to veterinary school. The objectives of the Pre-Veterinary Society shall be to educate students interested in a career in veterinary medicine through guest lectures, meetings and community service. The society will aid students in the admissions process, promote connections between pre-veterinary students, and provide resources and guidance through the support of the University Academic Advising Center.
value.Summary: The Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University is a group dedicated to students who are pursing a pre-veterinary agenda on their path to veterinary school.

value.Name: Private Equity and Venture Capital Club
value.Description: Northwestern University Private Equity and Venture Capital Club is a student-run organization dedicated to those who have an interest in private equity, growth equity and venture capital. The organization seeks to expose students to the world of private and growth investing by providing formal education in each field, mentorship opportunities with alumni and Kellogg faculty, professional development workshops, simulated investing projects, speaker events, and connections with Chicago based PE/VC firms.
value.Summary: Northwestern University Private Equity and Venture Capital Club is a student-run organization dedicated to those who have an interest in private equity, growth equity and venture capital.

value.Name: Project MED
value.Description:
Project MED (Medicine, Exposure, and Development) is an organization that focuses on educating and preparing high school students for careers in healthcare, particularly in underserved communities. We have two primary goals:

  1. Expose high school students to the breadth of opportunities in the healthcare field
  2. Prepare students for a successful pathway to a career in healthcare
value.Summary: Project MED (Medicine, Exposure, and Development) is an organization that focuses on educating and preparing high school students for careers in healthcare, particularly in underserved communities.

value.Name: Project RISHI
value.ShortName: Rural India Social and Health Improvement
value.Description: Our purpose is to promote sustainable development and health advancement in India and provide medical care, health education, and easy access to health resources. We do so through fundraising efforts, service trips, and educational campaigns.  Throughout the year, members develop projects and info campaigns that will be implemented via collaboration with a local nonprofit, and network to create relationships with sponsors. During service trips, members will conduct needs assessments, analyze data, hold health camps, and form relationships with community members.  Currently, the Northwestern chapter is advised by physicians at Feinberg School of Medicine.
value.Summary: Project RISHI (Rural India Social and Health Improvement) is an organization dedicated to advancing public health and addressing sustainable development issues in rural India, through partnerships and collaborative work with local nonprofits.

value.Name: Project Sunshine
value.Description: Project Sunshine is a nonprofit organization focused on bringing joy to pediatric patients and their often forgotten caregivers! We work on delivering "the healing power of play" to children in hospitals through interactive events such as Teleplay, care packages, and arts and crafts. We also actively fundraise for our cause in order to raise money to support the national Project Sunshine headquarters, as well as strive to embody the organization values of SHINE (Safe, Healthy, Inclusive, Nurturing, Engaging).
value.Summary: Delivering the healing power of play to pediatric patients!

value.Name: Psi Chi
value.Description: Psi Chi, the International Honor Society in Psychology, was founded in 1929 with a mission to encourage excellence in scholarship and advance the science of psychology. More than three-quarters of a million lifetime members have joined including Distinguished Members such as Drs. Albert Bandura, B. F. Skinner, and Phillip Zimbardo. A few popular Membership Benefits include international recognition for academic excellence, as well as access to psychology-related publications and more than $400,000 in annual awards and grants. Lifetime Membership is open to undergraduate and graduate students, transfer students, full-time faculty members, and alumni. Individuals become members by joining their local Psi Chi chapter. See our specific membership requirements. After potential members are approved by a local faculty advisor, all 1,150+ Psi Chi chapters process their new members on our online system. The Psi Chi Central Office, located in Chattanooga, Tennessee, manages the Society under the direction of the Board of Directors, who are Psi Chi members elected by the chapters to guide the Organization. Psi Chi is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies and is an affiliate of the American Psychological Association (APA) and the Association for Psychological Science (APS). Our sister honor society is Psi Beta, the national honor society in psychology for community and junior colleges.
value.Summary: Recognizing and promoting excellence in the science and application of psychology.

value.Name: Public Affairs Residential College
value.Description:
The Public Affairs Residential College (PARC) is a south campus living community at Northwestern University focused on integrating public affairs concepts into the living environment. The building houses 70 students in single and double-occupancy rooms. Floors are co-ed, with students from different genders living on different sides of each floor. This building is available to all undergraduate students.

As a Residential College, PARC has special access to university resources and faculty which make our living experience particularly unique!  As a PARCer you can participate in Firesides with professors, an amazing yearly formal, weekly Munchies and Cookies and Conversation, trips to Chicago and cool places on campus, philanthropy events, Intramural Sports and much, much more!

At PARC, almost everything you need is right next door, if not in PARC itself. But for a Res College to be truly great, it has to be more than a pretty building in a convenient part of Campus; it has to be a community. What really sets PARC apart is the people. Even though our name says “Public Affairs,” the students who live here are diverse in their areas of study. While we have our fair share of SESP and Medill students, each of Northwestern’s six schools is generously represented in PARC’s student population, even McCormick (the walk to Tech from NMQ is really not that bad). Your fellow PARCers will help you grow both academically and personally. Not only will you learn from PARC’s college staff and guest speakers; you will also learn from your fellow PARCers themselves. Students in PARC hold leadership positions in countless organizations on campus, whether for student-run publications, engineering societies, student government, and more. PARC fosters dialogue between students so that ideas can flow freely between us. At PARC you won’t just find a dorm; you’ll find a home.
value.Summary: The Public Affairs Residential College (PARC) is a south campus living community at Northwestern University focused on integrating public affairs concepts into the living environment. The building houses 70 students in single and double-occupancy rooms.

value.Name: Public Speaking Club
value.Description: NU Public Speaking Club provides a unique opportunity to help members develop their speaking, listening and leadership skills. Members learn techniques for overcoming stage anxiety, connecting with any audience, assimilating verbal and non-verbal communication skills, and achieving a commanding executive presence. We have weekly meetings to practice giving prepared/impromptu speeches and provide feedback to each other. We also organize workshops, guest lecture series, and social events.
value.Summary: Our mission is to empower NU Students to become eloquent speakers and confident leaders through continuous opportunities to develop their communications and leadership skills in an inclusive community.

value.Name: Purple Crayon Players
value.Description: Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre and community service organization that produces professionally written theatre for young audiences within our mainstage season, as well as special projects and events by, with, and for youth. This year, you can use theater to engage, inspire, and educate audiences of all ages as an actor, director, designer, storyteller, teaching artist, team member or project leader.
value.Summary: Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre company on the Northwestern University campus committed to creating high quality productions, events, and educational materials regarding all aspects of theatre for young audiences.

value.Name: Purple Haze
value.Description:
Formed in 1996, Purple Haze has been singin', dancin' and lovin' for 25 years! Completely run by students, we rehearse on a weekly basis and put on a killer show every quarter. In the fall, we invite other groups from nearby colleges to perform in our Best of the Midwest concert. In the winter, we combine a cappella with games and improv for Too Much A Cappella Makes the Baby Go Deaf, based on the Neo-Futurists' popular Chicago show. And in the spring, we devise a new script to go with our songs and a theme of our choosing.

Aside from campus shows, Purple Haze also performs throughout the Chicagoland area.  In the past, we have even sung on ABC Chicago News! Purple Haze has released nine studio albums, with many songs recognized on national a cappella compilation CDs. Mouth Off, an a cappella podcast, called us “the best you’re going to hear out of the whole midwestern United States” and “the group that everyone wants to party with!” Our music is available on iTunes and Spotify.

Purple Haze goes on tour every year, alternating between domestic and international trips. We have recently flown to Fort Lauderdale, FL where we held workshops at various local schools and traversed the South Florida area. Past tours also include Havana, Cuba, Montreal, and Amsterdam. We also compete biennially in the International Championship of Collegiate a cappella, making it to the ICCA Semifinals in 2016 and 2018! But most importantly, Purple Haze is a group of friends who love to sing together!
value.Summary: In the vibrant Northwestern a cappella community, Purple Haze prides itself on maintaining the highest standards of musicality while keeping the fun and love alive!

value.Name: Purple Passion Dance Team
value.Description: Purple Passion is to provide a space where people can learn, practice, and collaborate about a style of dance called band dancing or majorette. Band dancing is a uniquely African American style of dance that began at Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
value.Summary: Majorette Dance Team

value.Name: Quizbowl
value.Description:
Northwestern Quizbowl participates in academic, buzzer-based competitions primarily held in the Midwest, including novice tournaments, regular events, and national championships.

We frequently travel to the University of Chicago, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Michigan, among others.

We also host middle school, high school, and collegiate tournaments over the course of the academic year. We have also hosted 2005 ACF Nationals, the 2011 PACE NSC, and the 2012 College National Championships of the National History Bowl.
value.Summary: Northwestern Quizbowl participates in academic buzzer competitions against other colleges.

value.Name: Rainbow Alliance
value.Description:
Check out our website:https://sites.northwestern.edu/rainbow/

Our purpose is to create a safe space at Northwestern University that encourages personal development for Northwestern’s 2SLGBTQ+ community and coalition building among our intersecting communities. To this end we:

  • Develop programming to actively address and solve issues surrounding gender and sexuality in the Northwestern community
  • Provide a supportive and fun social environment that creates a sense of community!
  • Fight homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, heterosexism, and genderism and the intersecting oppressions experienced within our diverse community
value.Summary: Our purpose is to create a safe space at Northwestern University that encourages personal development for Northwestern’s 2SLGBTQ+ community and coalition building among our intersecting communities.

value.Name: RAISO
value.Description:
Raiso is a student organization where students from various disciples can get together to learn, write, and talk about how AI and technology impact our current and future society. As education, healthcare, law, and criminal justice, and other areas of business and life grow more automated, we give students space and a platform to reflect and learn not just about how AI and automation work, but about its pitfalls and drawbacks. 

 

For example: while the largest language model in the world can be used to write code for you, that same model has been found to be harmfully biased in surprising, yet almost predictable, ways. 

 

There is a lot to take part in as a member of our community. As a member, you'll be notified about when we host speakers and activists working on AI innovation and responsible AI practices and research. You’ll also be able to participate in workshops to learn more about AI, and how it interacts with your major, gain connections and possible funding for internships focused on Responsible AI, write about and publish work to our website and newsletter, and much more. 

 

As an executive member, which you can become by application, you can directly lead these programs and help shape the future of Raiso, and ultimately, AI at Northwestern. There is a lot to be excited about!

 

We’re an organization for the technical, and the non-technical. Whether your interests are in global development, critical race studies, gender studies, psychology, social policy, etc, your knowledge and background are valuable in helping create, shape, and evaluate not just our community, but how AI will shape society in the near future. If you’re interested in AI, or passionate about its use in all facets of life, this is the place for you.
value.Summary: Raiso is a student organization where students from various disciples get together to learn, write, and talk about how AI and technology impact our current and future society.

value.Name: Red Cross Club at Northwestern University
value.Description: We, as the Northwestern branch of the American Red Cross, work to provide relief to victims of disaster, strive to raise awareness for all of those in need, hold quarterly blood drives, raise funds to support the Red Cross' various initiatives, and support the Red Cross principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality, independence, voluntary service, unity, and universality.
value.Summary: Northwestern University Chapter of the American Red Cross.

value.Name: Red Dot: Singapore Student Association
value.Description: Singapore Society (SingSoc) is a cultural organization that celebrates the uniqueness of Singapore. SingSoc organizes many events and get-togethers for anyone interested in Singapore's rich culture and history. We welcome absolutely anyone, and you do not need to be a Singaporean to join our organization!
value.Summary: Red Dot: Singapore Student Association fka Singapore Society (SingSoc) is a cultural organization that celebrates the uniqueness of Singapore. SingSoc organizes many events and get-togethers for anyone interested in Singapore's rich culture and history.

value.Name: Reformed University Fellowship
value.Description:
Reformed University Fellowship (RUF) is a Christian community at Northwestern seeking to reach out to people from diverse backgrounds with the message of the Gospel and to help one another live our lives in response to who Jesus is and what he has done for us. We meet every Tuesday night at 8:30pm in Vail Chapel for our large group meeting and offer a number of small groups that gather throughout the week to study the Bible, discuss a book, pray together, and build relationships with one another. We also host numerous social events and service opportunities throughout the year. Regardless of your beliefs or doubts, we would love to have you join us.

 

For more information on RUF and to be added to our mailing list, please visit www.rufnorthwestern.org
value.Summary: Reformed University Fellowship (RUF) is a Christian community at Northwestern seeking to reach out to people from diverse backgrounds with the message of the gospel and to help one another live our lives in response to who Jesus is and what he has done

value.Name: Refresh Dance Crew
value.Description:
To stay up to date on Refresh, Like us on Facebook at:

www.facebook.com/RefreshDanceCrew

Refresh Dance Crew was born in 2005 from a group of friends who wanted to learn how to dance. Since then, Refresh has grown into a large family of dancers with different styles that range from popping and breaking to choreography. People of all skill levels–from beginners to trained dancers–are welcome to attend weekly open sessions and free choreography classes. Additionally, Refresh holds auditions every quarter for specific shows. Refresh fosters a space of growth and community through a shared love of dance and three core values: Respect, Family, and Hustle.
value.Summary: Refresh Dance Crew was born in 2005 from a group of friends who wanted to learn how to dance. Since then, Refresh has grown into a large family of dancers with different styles that range from popping and breaking to choreography.

value.Name: Relay For Life
value.Description:
Relay for Life is the largest nationwide fundraiser for the American Cancer Society, raising hundreds of millions of dollars for cancer research and advocacy. Here at Northwestern, we have raised over $100,000 for 4 of the last 7 years and host an annual event with hundreds of participants. Throughout the year, we focus our efforts on advocacy, fundraising, and outreach, culminating in our final event in May, which is held in the Henry Crown Sports and Aquatics Pavilion.

Sign up for Relay at www.relayforlife.org/northwesternil

Watch a Relay promo video here: http://youtu.be/RF17W0cXe2A
value.Summary: Relay for Life is the largest nationwide fundraiser for the American Cancer Society, raising over $400 million for cancer research and advocacy. We regularly raise over $100,000 and host an annual event with hundreds of participants.

value.Name: Religious & Spiritual Life
value.Description:
The primary mission of the Office of the University Chaplains is to promote spiritual growth and nurture at Northwestern University.

Spiritual maturity entails

    * reflection on the meaning and purpose of human existence
    * appreciation for the depth and expanse of life
    * articulation of beliefs
    * development of spiritual resources to sustain one through good times and bad
    * a willingness to rethink values and to apply them to life
    * a concern for the welfare of humankind and a capacity to act with confidence upon that concern

Spiritual maturity is enhanced by critical dialogue and community with members of one's own tradition and through encounter with differing traditions.

Northwestern is privileged to enjoy a rich and diverse religious life, which supports and challenges the intellectual pursuits of the University.

We are delighted to introduce you to some of the organizations and programs at Northwestern that provide occasions for religious reflection and opportunities for worship, service, and action. Through the various religious traditions represented on campus, students may seek moral and spiritual insights into the meaning and value of human life and experience.

We invite you to explore the rich and varied options available to Northwestern students. Our office is open to all inquiries from students, their parents, and campus visitors. Campus religious leaders and advisors are always ready to help students broaden their faith.

It is our hope that together we can build a community of conscience and spiritual awareness and support the University's search for and celebration of "whatsoever things are true."
value.Summary: The primary mission of the Office of Religious & Spiritual Life is to promote spiritual growth and nurture at Northwestern University.  Spiritual maturity entails      * reflection on the meaning and purpose of human existence

value.Name: Remote Area Medical Volunteer Corps
value.Description:
The core purpose of this organization will be to give Northwestern University students the chance to participate in Remote Area Medical (RAM) trips focused on providing free services to those who are unable to afford medical care themselves and for those who do not have access to hospitals or healthcare facilities in their area. Through this organization, members will have the opportunity to volunteer and travel to RAM clinics across the nation. This will be an especially valuable experience to aspiring healthcare professionals. This organization will aspire to promote quality healthcare both locally and nationally to the fullest of its abilities.

Students will work to fundraise and plan trips to RAM clinics around the United States. At these clinics, volunteers will assist in a variety of fields, some of which include vision testing, patient registration, dental assisting, or making glasses. The Northwestern RAM chapter will also assist in disaster relief efforts, such as through hosting food and clothing drives. 

Click this link to join our groupme: https://groupme.com/join_group/86543501/5IgQOZ1K

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OEQA8RSvfbs
value.Summary: The Northwestern Chapter of Remote Area Medical (RAM) allows students to volunteer in pop-up medical clinics around the country in order to assist with providing free dental, vision, and medical care to those without access to healthcare.

value.Name: Repro at NU
value.Description: NORJ aims to demystify abortion and provide information about services near campus in order to improve access for the Northwestern community.
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Residential College Board
value.Description:
We serve as an advisory body for the residential colleges here at Northwestern University. Our membership is composed of the presidents of the ten residential colleges and eight executive officers. Each of the seven vice presidents specializes in an area specifically relevant to the residential college community: academic affairs, financial affairs, inter-college relations, philanthropic affairs, public relations, and social affairs. The president presides over the entire Board and coordinates long-term planning.

We hold general meetings every week in which we deal with problems and issues that arise during the week in individual colleges, plan activities for the entire residential college community, and discuss items for presentation to the University. In addition to these weekly meetings, the Executive Board meets every week to guide the Board's agenda.

The Residential College Board is responsible for a number of large-scale social events every year, including the Fall Formal, Winter Quarter Quiz Bowl, and the annual RCB Field Day.
value.Summary: RCB is comprised of the 10 Residential Colleges at Northwestern. Our motto, a tradition of living and learning, exemplifies our goal: to bring an enhanced sense of community to your dorm life and to help students learn outside the classroom.

value.Name: Residential College of Cultural & Community Studies
value.Description:
WELCOME! The Residential College of Cultural and Community Studies (CCS) is one big family of diverse and dedicated students. Its intimate setting and small population easily allow it be one of Northwestern’s best kept secrets. CCS houses 42 women, men, and all else on or off the gender spectrum in single, double, and triple-occupancy rooms. 

Students from as far away as China and as close as the western suburbs live together in CCS, one of Northwestern University's oldest residential colleges. Our majors range from RTVF to psychology to engineering, but we share a love of diverse cultures and concern for our local and global communities.

When not out enjoying the social scene around us on North Campus, we work with our fellows and outside organizations to put on activities like firesides, community service projects, and IM sports. For trips into Chicago, the Noyes El stop is conveniently close. Favorite outings include trips to ethnic neighborhoods, musical and dramatic performances, and camping.
value.Summary: The Residential College of Cultural & Community Studies (CCS) is one big family of diverse and dedicated students. Its intimate setting and small population easily allow it be one of Northwestern's best kept secrets.

value.Name: Residential Life
value.Description: University Residential Life (URL) is a Student Affairs department. Our vision is "Engage and educate: Creating communities of learners, leaders, and responsible citizens. "Through our mission we strive to promote a sense of community and encourage the growth and development of each student in a variety of living environments. Our program seeks to complement the academic mission of Northwestern University by providing students opportunities for learning in a safe, diverse, and respectful environment.
value.Summary: University Residential Life (URL) is a Student Affairs department. Our vision is "Engage and educate: Creating communities of learners, leaders, and responsible citizens. "Through our mission we strive to promote a sense of community and encourage the

value.Name: Residential Services
value.Summary: Residential Services at Northwestern is committed to providing an environment that fosters the academic and personal success of every student.

value.Name: Right to Life
value.Summary: Right to Life is established to advocate for the protection of the human right to life of unborn children, and to act to support women undergoing difficult pregnancies to provide them with the means to necessary to choose life.

value.Name: Rock Climbing Club
value.Description: To create an environment that both introduces students to climbing as a sport and offers experienced climbers a collaborative space to help improve their skill level. To climb is to embrace a culture of inclusiveness and resilience. The climber is an individual who, against all odds, defies their limitations to get to the top of routes that they would have thought to be impossible. Climbing is in many ways a team sport and we hope to highlight the collaborative and fun spirit that defines the best climbing communities.
value.Summary: The Rock Climbing Club was established to introduce the Northwestern Community to the sport of rock climbing.

value.Name: Rotaract
value.Description: Rotaract clubs bring together people ages 18 and older to exchange ideas with leaders in the community, develop leadership and professional skills, and have fun through service. In communities worldwide, Rotary and Rotaract members work side by side to take action through service. Rotaract emphasizes a strong commitment to promoting world understanding and peace through the development of leadership among those ages 18 – 30. Today, there are more than 8,000 Rotary-supported Rotaract clubs with more than 175,000 members in 164 countries around the world.This NU club is committed to promoting world understanding and peace through young adult leadership development. A variety of projects and activities are organized that fall into three categories: professional development, leadership development, and service project development. NU Rotaract dedicates spring break to international service, connecting with Rotaract chapters abroad and working on a week-long project.
value.Summary: As a sub-organization of Rotary International, Rotaract club brings us together to exchange ideas with leaders in the community, develop leadership and professional skills, and have fun through service. We also focus on international travel and community

value.Name: Russian Speaking Student Association
value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Scene+Heard
value.Description: Scene+Heard is purposed to connect artists and audiences and chronicle culture, on-campus and off. It was created on the basis of making arts more accessible and engaging to a broader network of students, rather than the more insular theater and music communities that often comprise the majority of performance audiences at Northwestern. The website, sceneandheardonline.com, will make information about performances more accessible to students through the prolific publication of new artistic and cultural events and happenings in our community.
value.Summary: Scene+Heard is Northwestern's official online arts and culture publication. Through dynamic content, exclusive interviews, and first-hand coverage of the best events on-campus and Chicago, we're transforming the way students interact with culture.

value.Name: Scholars of Finance
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Science Olympiad
value.Description: We are a group of undergraduate and graduate students at Northwestern committed to serving the Science Olympiad community. Most of us are alumni of Science Olympiad, having competed in Division B and/or C. We intend to host an Invitational-level Science Olympiad tournament for Division C (and hopefully Division B in the future) teams annually, as well as serve as volunteers and event supervisors for Regional and State level tournaments in Illinois. Professor Shelby Hatch serves as an advisor.
value.Summary: A volunteer-based organization committed to hosting a Science Olympiad invitational for Division C teams in Illinois and surrounding states and coordinating volunteers for Illinois Regional and State tournaments.

value.Name: Science Policy Outreach Task Force
value.Description: The Science Policy Outreach Task Force (SPOT) is a non-partisan organization of Northwestern University researchers focused on advocating for science, evidence-based reasoning, and scientifically-sound policy to the voting-aged public and policymakers. Members have the opportunity to learn and put effective science advocacy into political action through events to educate voters, meetings to educate and collaborate with policymakers, educational seminars to learn about the interface of science and policy, and activities with external science policy entities. As a group, our combined efforts allow for a greater impact toward the advocacy of science in politics than any one of us acting alone.
value.Summary: Advocating for science and evidenced-based decision making to policymakers and the voting public.

value.Name: Seesaw Theatre
value.Description:
Seesaw Theatre produces highly interactive, multi-sensory theatre for autistic and otherwise disabled individuals. Founded with the belief that all individuals should have the opportunity to experience theatre in a welcoming, safe environment, we offer autistic and otherwise disabled individuals and their parents the ability to experience theatre together free from societal expectations of what behavior should look like in a theatrical setting. Our theatre spaces are used in innovative ways to create an entire world to absorb, full of features that engage a variety of senses. Seesaw Theatre is produced solely by undergraduate students and continues to provide theatre free of charge.

For more information about our work please visit http://www.seesawtheatre.org. 

To get involved email us at seesawtheatre@gmail.com.
value.Summary: Seesaw Theatre strives to enrich the lives of autistic and otherwise disabled individuals by increasing their access to theatre and fostering the use of performance as a channel for expression.

value.Name: Segal Professional Bridge
value.Description:
Segal Professional Bridge is an organization aimed at connecting students, faculty members, and industry professionals who are passionate about innovation and entrepreneurship.

Highlights include:

  • Presenting students with networking opportunities through industry visits, speaker series, professional and societies panels
  • Helping students to get connected with relevant industry-level projects to enhance their skillset 
  • Exposing students to events hosted by the Northwestern and Chicago communities
  • Providing students with opportunities for professional development through mentorship programming
value.Summary: Segal Professional Bridge is an organization aimed at connecting students, faculty members, and industry professionals who are passionate about innovation and entrepreneurship.

value.Summary: Senior Year Committee

value.Name: Sexual Health and Assault Peer Educators
value.Description:
SHAPE is a Northwestern student organization affiliated with NU's Center for Awareness, Response, and Education (CARE) that combats rape culture and works to create a culture of healthy sexuality through education, public events, and an open dialogue on sexual health, sex positivity, and sexual assault. SHAPE's mission is to increase students’ comfort about sexuality, encourage them to learn and adopt healthy behaviors and help them recognize and address unhealthy and dangerous behaviors and attitudes regarding sexuality and relationships.

Members of SHAPE receive training from current SHAPE educators and Director of CARE, along with Northwestern's Title IX Coordinator and Northwestern- or community-affiliated doctors, nurse practitioners, advocates, counselors, and other experts in the fields of sexual health and sexual assault prevention. Peer educators are trained on a range of topics including:

  - Consent & Communication

  - Sexual Assault

  - Supporting Survivors

  - Safer Sex & STI’s

  - Intersectionality

  - LGBTQ+ sexual health and inclusivity

  - Healthy Relationships

  - Reproductive anatomy & birth control

  - Title IX

  - & More!

After training, peer educators provide presentations, workshops, and trainings to students, organize outreach events & tabling, collaborate with other student organizations, and serve as a resource for individual students looking for information about sexual health and sexual assault.

We also have a newsletter, The Bi-Weekly Shag, with upcoming campus/community events and fun sex tips! Join our listserv (SHAPEfriends@listserv.it.northwestern.edu) to get the best newsletter around & information on upcoming events, joining, etc.
value.Summary: SHAPE is a Northwestern student organization affiliated with CARE that combats rape culture and works to create a culture of healthy sexuality through education, public events, and open dialogue on sexual health, sex positivity, and sexual assault.

value.Name: Shepard Residential College
value.Summary: Shepard is a multithematic residential college that houses 74 students, mainly sophomores and freshmen. It is located on south campus, at the center of the sorority quad. Its residents refer to themselves as "sheep."

value.Name: Shia Muslim Association
value.Description: SMA aims to educate our Shia Muslim members and the broader Northwestern community by upholding and promoting the teachings of the Sublime Quran, the Prophet Muhammad, the Lady Fatimah, and the Twelve Imams from his Household. We actively get engaged in promoting dialogue with, creating cooperation with, and fostering participation in the broader Muslim and non-Muslim community at Northwestern University. We will contribute to religious and spiritual life on campus by shaping a forum for a comparative understanding of Shia Islam, other Islamic denominations, and other religions through holding lectures, workshops, and symposia.
value.Summary: SMA provides an educational forum for the intellectual development of Shia Muslims student community on campus and aims to spread the knowledge of the Quran, the Prophet Muhammad, the Lady Fatimah, and the Twelve Imams through lectures and symposia.

value.Name: ShireiNU A Cappella
value.Description: ShireiNU A Cappella is an open-minded, welcoming, and collaborative community of all backgrounds and identities. We are first and foremost a group of friends passionate about singing together and having fun. As Northwestern’s premier Jewish a cappella group, we arrange and sing a variety of musical genres, including pop, indie, and alternative, with a few Hebrew pop songs per year.We host a show once per quarter and perform at a variety of venues and events throughout Northwestern, the Chicagoland area, and on tour in cities across the country! Check us out on Instagram and YouTube (@ShireiNUaCappella)
value.Summary: ShireiNU A Cappella is Northwestern's premier Jewish a Capella group, founded in 2009. With both Jewish and non-Jewish members, we sing English and some Hebrew music all over campus and throughout Chicagoland!

value.Name: SIG Theater
value.Summary: Special Interest Group in Chinese Theater (SIG Theater) is a TGS-sponsored theater club at Northwestern. Our goal is to broaden student life by hosting theater-related events.

value.Name: Sigma Alpha Iota
value.Description:
Sigma Alpha Iota is an international music fraternity for women, open to female and nonbinary identifying students of all majors as an opportunity to continue their musical involvement after high school. We offer performance opportunities, music related philanthropies and social events and outings for all of our members. Our House is located in the Sorority Quad, right next to the Willard Residential College. As SAI is outside of the PanHellenic system, students are able to be in both SAI and a PHA sorority if interested. 

Visit our full website or visit our Facebook Page to learn more details!

___________________________________

Sigma Alpha Iota is an organization which promotes interaction among those who share a commitment to music. Members of SAI are active in all areas of campus music and campus life, working closely with faculty, administration, campus and community groups, music professionals and patrons. In addition to personal encouragement and support, members may receive scholarships, loans and awards in many areas and at all levels of music-related study. Sigma Alpha Iota has long been recognized as a leader in the field of music and provides a lifetime of fraternity contact.

The SAI Alumnae Association allows alumnae members to remain active and supportive of the ideals of SAI.

Members of Sigma Alpha Iota, in collegiate and alumnae chapters, devote their talents and energies to many national and international projects including those of Sigma Alpha Iota Philanthropies, Inc.:

  • The SAI quarterly, PAN PIPES, comprehensively lists American premieres and works-in-progress in each Winter issue, and is included in the Library of Congress Archives.
  • The People-to-People Music Committee, Inc., sends music, instruments, and educational materials to deserving musicians world-wide.
  • The triennial Inter-American Music Awards (IAMA) and commissions recognize and encourage the finest in creative composition throughout the western hemisphere.
  • Undergraduate, Graduate, and Doctoral Scholarships and Loans, Summer Music Scholarships, and Chapter Outreach Grants are available to SAI members and chapters.

Sigma Alpha Iota accepts with pride the responsibilities and privileges of being a leader in the pursuit of music creation, performance, and scholarship.

To visit our national website, click here.
value.Summary: Sigma Alpha Iota is an international music fraternity for women, open to female identifying students of all majors as an opportunity to continue their musical involvement after high school. Visit our website at http://sainorthwestern.wixsite.com/saibeta

value.Name: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.
value.Description:
About Sigma

Sigma Gamma Rho was founded on and continues to be steadfastly committed to the tenets of excellence in Scholarship, Sisterhood and Service.  Sigma Gamma Rho has a proud legacy of providing positive and proactive community leadership and support when and wherever needed as indicated by the sorority's international slogan, "Greater Service, Greater Progress."

 

 

Foundation

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was organized on November 12, 1922, in Indianapolis, Indiana, by seven young educators: Mary Lou Allison Gardner Little, Dorothy Hanley Whiteside, Vivian White Marbury, Nannie Mae Gahn Johnson, Hattie Mae Annette Dulin Redford, Bessie Mae Downey Rhoades Martin and Cubena McClure. The group became an incorporated national collegiate sorority on December 30, 1929, when a charter was granted to Alpha chapter at Butler University.


Soaring To Greater Heights Of Attainment Around The World, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, has met the challenges of the day and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.
value.Summary: The Eta Chapter of Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.

value.Name: Sigma Nu Fraternity
value.Description:
Sigma Nu recolonized the Gamma Beta Chapter at Northwestern during the spring of 2013!

A group of 45 men came together to recolonize Gamma Beta in the winter of 2013. Since then, 15 more have joined in an effort to create a fraternity from scratch, to mold it into what they believe a model fraternity should look like. This group of men strive to create an inclusive, friendly, and collaborative environment where everyone is welcomed and encouraged to take on leadership opportunities. 

Now, we are 80 members strong and growing. With a new house, strong motivation, and a close brotherhood, we invite you to see if you want to be part of something greater than yourself.

...
Visit the website for more info and fill out a prospective member questionnaire!
http://becomeasigmanu.org/prospective-member-questionnaire

If you'd like to make a membership referral, please click the link below.

value.Name: Sigma Phi Epsilon
value.Description:
The Illinois Lambda Chapter of Sigma Phi Epsilon was founded at Northwestern University in 1989, and rechartered in 2016. As a chapter, we strive to provide the single best undergraduate Greek experience on campus. Please reach out if you would like to know more about us!

As a national organization, Sigma Phi Epsilon is the nation's largest fraternity with over 15,000 undergraduate members and more than 295,000 total lifetime members.

"Building Balanced Men"

value.Name: Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
value.Description:
Alpha Beta Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed May 10, 2008

President: Elaine Jiang

"True to our colors, red and gold. Sisters forever, heart and soul"

Organization Facts

National founding date: March 23, 1994

The fundamental goal of Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority is to promote awareness of the myriad Asian/Asian-American cultures. Our sorority addresses this issue through leadership, outreach, individual, community interaction, and most importantly, the bonds of sisterhood. The sorority also promotes development among its members, the students and the faculty at each of the campuses we represent. In order to achieve this goal, we partake in political, social, educational, and cultural activities. Each effort improves our environment, and instills within our sisters experiences that will follow them long after they've graduated. Through a network of like-minded yet highly individualistic women, the sorority lends structure and support to sisters that share this Sigma vision. We believe the strength of our foundation derives from the unity of sisterhood, one that was proudly established years ago. In addition, we work in collaboration with other Greek and non-Greek organizations to provide services for the local communities and the community at large. It is through our various participation in these cultural events, educational workshops, and philanthropic support that we make a difference. Nationally, regionally, and individually, we strive to embody the ideals of Sigma Psi Zeta.

Colors: Red and Gold

You may visit the Sigma Psi Zeta national website at www.sigmapsizeta.org.

value.Name: Significant Others
value.Description:
Founded in 1994, Significant Others is Northwestern’s treble voices a cappella group. SigO is a close community of friends who love to sing and make amazing music together! We are a completely student-run organization that puts on a unique show each quarter featuring a fun theme and setlist that we arrange.

While we were initially founded as a women’s a cappella group, we have since expanded our mission statement to include female, non-binary, trans, and any other non-cis identifying individuals. We strongly value inclusivity and creating a safe space for historically marginalized gender identities.

SigO puts on three different shows during the school year: a fall show, a winter show, and a spring show. Throughout the year, we sing at various gigs on campus and throughout the Chicagoland area, including charity events, opening acts for other groups, and new student week performances. We also travel to perform with a cappella groups at other universities throughout the midwest!

For more information, check out our website and Instagram @sigonu!
value.Summary: Significant Others is Northwestern's premier a cappella group for treble voices, founded in 1994. We are a close community of female and non-binary folx who love to sing together! We are also avid Just Dance fans.

value.Name: Sit & Spin Productions
value.Description: Sit & Spin Productions exists to expand the definition of theatre at Northwestern University by giving artists opportunities to explore unconventional, risk-taking works. We promote new approaches to existing material, adapted or original work, and site-specific theatre. We are dedicated to providing administrative, artistic, and production support for all aspects of our season.
value.Summary: Sit & Spin Productions is a theatre board at Northwestern University that produces unconventional, risk-taking, and site-specific work.

value.Name: Skate Club
value.Description: Skateboarding, longboarding, rollerskating ... experienced skaters, people who've always wanted to try ... everyone is welcome to join!
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Slivka Hall
value.ShortName: Residential College of Science and Engineering
value.Description:
The Science and Engineering Residential College at Slivka Hall provides a unique living and learning opportunity for undergraduates interested in science, engineering, and technology. College members take part in tutorials, firesides, and distinguished lectures on topics ranging from ethics in the lab to quantum teleportation to AIDS in America. They participate in community service projects and fundraisers, go to Chicago sports events, and organize camping and biking trips. The college sponsors an annual Thanksgiving dinner, and a barbecue is held in June to "toast" our graduating seniors.

Slivka is located on north campus just a short walk from the Technological Institute, the science and engineering library, the Henry Crown Sports Pavilion and Norris Aquatics Center, and Patten Gym.

Slivka houses 140 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in a closed suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
value.Summary: The Slivka Residential College of Science and Engineering provides a unique living and learning opportunity for undergraduates interested in science, engineering, and technology. Slivka houses 140 students in single and double rooms.

value.Name: Social Justice Education
value.Summary: Social Justice Education (SJE) creates co-curricular educational opportunities in partnership with our student community that foster self-exploration, facilitate conversations across difference and support actions that create social change on campus.

value.Name: Society for Ecological Restoration (Northwestern Chapter)
value.Description: The Society of Ecological Restoration creates and participates in restoration projects and programs, and facilitates opportunities for organization members to build essential skills in the science, practice, and policy of ecological restoration. Our organization will leverage existing partnerships with organizations committed to restoration and conservation (such as the Chicago Botanic Garden, the Forest Preserves of Cook County, the Chicago Park District, and the Illinois Native Plant Society) to foster a local restoration network within Northwestern University that delivers positive impacts in our communities.
value.Summary: The Society of Ecological Restoration creates and participates in restoration projects and programs, and facilitates opportunities for organization members to build essential skills in the science, practice, and policy of ecological restoration.

value.Name: Society of Asian Scientists & Engineers
value.Description: The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) seeks to advance Asian-heritage scientific and engineering professionals and help achieve their full potential. SASE members help create and partake in a variety of cultural and professional development activities as well as volunteering work to help the surrounding community. SASE is open to all majors, races, ethnicities, and genders, and is an organization where students can connect over an appreciation of Pan-Asian culture and support each other.
value.Summary: SASE prepares Asian heritage scientists, engineers & technologists for success in the global business world, celebrates diversity & provides opportunities for students to contribute to their local communities.

value.Name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers
value.Description:
SHPE History
The Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE) was founded in Los Angeles, California, in 1974 by a group of engineers employed by the city of Los Angeles. Their objective was to form a national organization of professional engineers to serve as role models in the Hispanic community.
The concept of networking was the key basis for the organization. SHPE quickly established two student chapters to begin the network that would grow to encompass the nation as well as reach countries outside the United States. Today, SHPE enjoys a strong but independent network of professional and student chapters throughout the nation.

SHPE Mission
SHPE at Northwestern University promotes the advancement of all ethnicities, majors, and backgrounds in education, employment, and society. SHPE at Northwestern University serves the Northwestern Community and surrounding schools through academic workshops, community service, and student group collaboration.

Chapter History
In the mid-1990s, SHPE was founded as a source of encouragement for the underrepresented Latinx minorities in Engineering at Northwestern. As of this year, we have grown to over 20 active members. We are currently in the process of researching and maintaining our local chapter's history, as well as establishing connection with our alumni.

Vision
SHPE is the leading social-technical organization whose primary function is to enhance and achieve the potential of Hispanics in engineering, math and science.

Strategic Focus Areas
We will fulfill our mission by increasing educational opportunities, promoting professional and personal growth, carry out our social responsibility to be involved in education, business and government issues and enhancing pride within our organization and reinforcing our reputation as a vital Hispanic organization

Statement of Values
We are brought together by heritage, social responsibility, and desire to improve the equality of all people through the use of science and technology. We value excellence in education, professional pursuits and leadership. We obtain excellence through integrity, empowerment, achievement, diversity and continuous improvement.

Connect with us:

Join our groupme, where members can be updated on upcoming events and activities:

https://groupme.com/join_group/30690709/PO7uQlE8

If you wish to be added to our emailing list, please reach out to shpe@u.northwestern.edu
value.Summary: Our mission is to promote the development of Hispanics in engineering, science, and other technical professions to achieve educational excellence, economic opportunity and social equity.

value.Name: Society of Physics Students
value.Description: The Northwestern University Society of Physics students seeks to connect students interested in physics, astronomy, and related fields. Whether you're looking for a pre-professional organization or just a community of STEM (well, science) enthusiasts, SPS is for you! We plan public lectures, demonstrations, and events open to the entire Northwestern community, as well as informal meetings to help students and professors get to know each other. We are also expanding our outreach efforts to local elementary and high schools to encourage younger students’ interest in science.
value.Summary: SPS is a community for anyone interested in physics, astronomy, space science, engineering ... Whether you're seeking pre-professional experience or a community of like-minded enthusiasts, the Society of Physics Students welcomes you!

value.Name: Society of Professional Journalists
value.Description: The Northwestern/Medill chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists aims to promote student journalism and connect the Northwestern community with professionals in the field, internship opportunities and career services. We host discussion spaces, lectures and workshops open to all students, not just those majoring in journalism. Join us to meet other journalists and discuss relevant topics such as news sustainability and reporting ethics.
value.Summary: The Northwestern/Medill chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists promotes student journalism and provides resources for the Northwestern community to connect with industry professionals and learn important tools to improve as journalists.

value.Summary: N/A

value.Name: Society of Women Engineers
value.Description: SWE hosts a variety of events to foster community and support for fellow undergrads and all gender minorities in STEM. Our five committees are Professional Development, Outreach, Social, Publicity, and HeforSWE. To receive more information about how you can get involved, join our listserv at https://nu-swe.weebly.com/contact.html!
value.Summary: SWE’s mission is to create a supportive community of women and non-binary engineers through professional and social programming. We aim to empower our members to fulfill their full potential as engineers and leaders and inspire the next generation.

value.Name: Songwriters Association at Northwestern
value.Description:
SWAN aims to create a space on campus for songwriters at Northwestern University (NU) to create and share their work with fellow musicians. SWAN encourages collaboration and inclusion for musicians of all levels and creative goals.

 

Our Events:

- open mics

- songwriting prompts/challenges

- studio sessions/music production workshops

- coffee houses

- music festivals

- Battle of the Bands

- and more!
value.Summary: SWAN aims to create a space on campus for songwriters at Northwestern University (NU) to create and share their work with fellow musicians. SWAN encourages collaboration and inclusion for musicians of all levels and creative goals.

value.Name: Soul4Real
value.Description: Soul4Real A Cappella is Northwestern's premiere Black student a cappella group. Founded in 2009, S4R serves to expose the Northwestern community to the fullest spectrum of historically Black musical genres including R&B, Soul, Hip-Hop and more.
value.Summary: Soul4Real A Cappella is Northwestern's premiere Black student a cappella group. Founded in 2009, S4R serves to expose the Northwestern community to the fullest spectrum of historically Black musical genres including R&B, Soul, Hip-Hop and more.

value.Name: South Asian Students Alliance
value.Description:
The South Asian Students Alliance (SASA) is the largest cultural student organization on campus that is dedicated to the celebration of South Asian culture. We proudly put on events that display our South Asian culture throughout the year, the largest of which is the annual SASA Show held in February. Other events include a Spring Speaker, a Garba/Raas/Bhangra, Holi, and student dialogues (among others). We dedicate time and effort to fostering a vibrant student community that engages with South Asian culture on the NU campus and in its surrounding community.

 

For any questions, comments, or concerns, please contact:

Co-Presidents Niki Gummadi and Dhruv Patel at nusasaexec@gmail.com
value.Summary: The South Asian Students Alliance (SASA) is the largest cultural student organization on campus that is dedicated to the celebration of South Asian culture.

value.Name: Spectrum Theatre Company
value.Description: Spectrum aims to inspire thought and dialogue both on campus and within the larger community. Spectrum is dedicated to recognizing the spectrum of beliefs, opinions, colors, creeds, and lifestyles of all people by producing thought provoking and challenging theater. We seek to collaborate with and empower the Northwestern community through theatre. Our seasons consist of scripted plays, devised work, and public happenings centered around a relevant politically and social conscious issue.
value.Summary: Spectrum Theatre Company is dedicated to empowering the greater Northwestern community by raising awareness, inspiring dialogue, and affecting change through theatrical experiences based on relevant social and political issues.

value.Name: Speech Team
value.Description: Members of the speech team spend their year crafting immaculate performances for competitions around the country, all in the hopes of receiving useful feedback (and maybe a trophy or two). Revise. Memorize. Repeat. Since 1994, the Northwestern Speech Team has won five Team National Titles, 18 individual national championships, and placed in 87 national final rounds. We've also made a lot of friends along the way! With 11 different events to choose from, you are sure to find an avenue to explore your interests and develop your public speaking skills. While high school speech experience will translate, no previous forensics experience is required. The team is looking for students who are passionate about the activity, eager to learn, and ready to work.
value.Summary: The Speech Team offers students a venue to participate in collegiate public speaking competitions. We also host showcases and tournaments on campus, such as the Tournament of Champions in Extemporaneous Speaking.

value.Name: SPG Improv
value.Description: We're Northwestern's only Graduate Student improv troupe!
value.Summary: Graduate Student Improv Troupe

value.Name: Spirit Squads
value.Description:
After a great 10-2 regular season, and an exciting trip to The Outback Bowl in Tampa, FL, the Wildcats are looking forward to the 2016-17 season! With football games at Ohio State, Michigan State, Purdue, Iowa and Minnesota, great travel opportunities exist for the 2016-17 Spirit Squad!  The Northwestern Cheerleaders and Willie the Wildcat appear at all home and away football games. You could have a chance to cheer at some of the most storied stadiums in college athletics! The NU Cheerleaders and Willie the Wildcat also makes appearances at all home men’s and women’s basketball games, as well as Big Ten basketball tournaments and assorted school and alumni events throughout the year. Great opportunities abound!

The Northwestern Spirit Squad  is completely funded through the athletic department. There is no cost to participate. All uniforms, practice gear, camps, travel, etc. are paid for by the spirit fund. Some members of the team may receive a monetary grant. This will be determined after the completion of each season.
value.Summary: The official spirit squad of the Northwestern University Department of Athletics and Recreation.

value.Name: Splash
value.Summary: Northwestern Splash is an outreach organization that allows Chicagoland high school students to take classes taught by members of the NU community.

value.Name: Spoon University
value.Description:
Spoon is the food resource for the millennial generation.

Spoon is on a mission to make food make sense - our content is written by college students, for college students. On our site and in our magazine, you can find the simplest recipes, the most obvious hacks you can’t believe you didn’t know, and the best restaurants around campus that you haven’t found yet. For many of us, this is the first time we’re navigating our campuses or our kitchens on our own, and Spoon University is here to simplify and celebrate that.

We offer opportunities for involvement through writing, photography, videography, and marketing.  We publish editorial content daily and a yearbook-style print magazine each Winter and Spring.  Please visit  our chapter's website, our national website,  our instagram, or email us at spoonuniversitynu@gmail.com for more information!
value.Summary:
Spoon is the food resource for the millenial generation.

Follow @spoon_nu on insta for recruitment info! Please don't request membership through Wildcat Connection or through the join button on Spoon's website. Our app will be linked in our insta bio.

value.Name: Sports Analytics Group
value.Description: The Sports Analytics Group is a group of Northwestern undergraduates committed to strategic data analysis and outside-the-box thinking in the world of sports. Our organization serves as an outlet for Northwestern students interested in sports analytics, attracting those who are creative, have a dedicated passion for sports statistics, and use analytical thinking to solve problems. We offer our members the ability to bridge the gap between sports and data analytics by fostering the education and guidance necessary to produce content that provides valuable insight into all facets of sports (business, roster management, fantasy, in-game strategy, etc.).
value.Summary: The Sports Analytics Group is a group of Northwestern undergraduates committed to strategic data analysis and outside the box thinking in all facets of sports (business, roster management, fantasy, in-game strategy, etc.).

value.Name: SPS MSA Student Organization
value.Description:
Successful networking can be an essential component for entry into the sports field. Northwestern University's MSA program provides a range of networking opportunities that provide MSA students and alumni with a competitive advantage as they begin and look to advance in their careers.

  • MSA faculty and staff have access to team executives, sports agents, corporate sports consultants and a broad range of other professionals in collegiate, professional and amateur athletics administration.
  • The MSA student board offers networking events that give students inside access to Chicago-area sports operations and provide opportunities to meet with and learn from team management and executives. See below for recent events.
  • Select MSA courses feature guest speakers from the sports industry who provide their insight and guidance.
  • MSA alumni hold positions in many areas of sports. As Northwestern University alumni, MSA graduates become part of an alumni population known nationwide for excellence and achievement.
value.Summary: The School of Professional Studies offers a part-time Master of Arts in Sports Administration (MSA) program that focuses on the business of athletics. The MSA Student Board adds opportunities to meet and socialize with industry professionals.

value.Name: Squash Club Team
value.Description:
Joining the team 

Tryouts will be held in September/October. Look for the Squash Team table at the Wildcat Welcome Fair to learn more.
Students are also able to join the team at any time throughout the season.

Practice 
Practices and home matches are held at SPAC.
We practice with challenge matches(to determine the ladder for the team) and conditioning drills 2-3 times a week. The team's practice schedule is to be determined for the 2021-2022 season.

Competitions against other schools take place on weekends.

Away matches 
At least two flying trips are taken each year to compete with other schools. Pre-covid we went to Boston and Palo Alto. 

Local matches
Additionally, we will compete in a tournament against other schools from the Midwest and participate in an annual match with the University of Chicago. Every year, the Squash Team competes in the National Championships held in mid-February.

League affiliation: College Squash Association


If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to the team's captain at aumbhuva2022@u.northwestern.edu
value.Summary: We are committed to providing an enjoyable and competitiion-driven experience for our members. We love the sport and enjoy getting better at playing and being better teammates.

value.Name: Steam Heat Dance Company
value.Description: Steam Heat is Northwestern's premier musical theatre dance company dedicated to preserving original musical theatre choreography and inspiring new musical theatre dance. Steam Heat was founded in 2009 by Dance major Danielle Kipnis. Today we practice and perform several dance styles such as Musical Theatre, Jazz, Jazz Funk, Tap, and Contemporary.  We perform at various events on and off campus throughout the year and have a main-stage show each spring complete with lighting, costumes, sets, props, and a live band! We have performed original pieces from Chorus Line, Sweet Charity, Lion King, and more. We also strive to further the art form by creating our own choreography and incorporating live singing into several pieces of our show.
value.Summary: Steam Heat is Northwestern's premier musical theatre dance company dedicated to preserving original musical theatre choreography and inspiring new theatre dance. We perform dance styles including jazz, tap, contemporary, and more!

value.Name: STITCH
value.Description: STITCH is a fashion publication at Northwestern University. Since its creation in 2006, the student-run and funded magazine has distributed four to five print issues per year to the Northwestern University student body, the Evanston community and select stores in Chicago. Founded by Joyce Lee, Matthew Alfonso, Christopher Adamson, Nate Adkisson and Kevin Burke, STITCH is now comprised of 80+ staffers from among the Northwestern University student population. Our blog, www.stitchfashion.com, is updated daily, and our latest print issue can be found at https://issuu.com/stitchfashion/docs.
value.Summary: STITCH is a fashion publication at Northwestern University. Our blog, www.stitchfashion.com, is updated daily, and our latest print issue can be found at https://issuu.com/stitchfashion/docs.

Student Affairs offers support to students in need and creates an environment that makes Northwestern students Wildcats for life.
