value.Name: Student Branch of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
value.Description:
The primary purpose of IEEE NU is to provide the means through which all students at Northwestern University may explore the EECS Department’s disciplines. It also serves the role of conveying the opinions and insights of the Department’s student body to the Department itself.

The secondary purpose is to foster a community for EECS students to meet people of similar interests and connect with others in the school. We want to help students create connections that will last them through their time at Northwestern and into their further careers.
value.Summary: IEEE NU exists to provide all students at Northwestern University with an avenue for participating in events and activities that promote the disciplines within the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.

value.Name: Student Organization Finance Office
value.Description:
The Student Organization Finance Office (SOFO) serves as the banking center for all student groups recognized by Northwestern University. As such, it facilitates financial transactions and offers an independent and verifiable record of all the activity that occurs on these organizational accounts.

Student organizations are financially accountable to their members and the student body at large. Though they are not recognized as legal entities outside of Northwestern, they do, at times, “represent” the University unofficially by the programs and activities they sponsor and make available to the general Evanston public. This association with the University brings them many benefits (e.g., exempt status from Illinois sales tax) and responsibilities (e.g., adherence to documentation requirements).

SOFO is committed to providing student organizations with a financial framework that helps student treasurers maintain accurate and detailed records while allowing them and student presidents the flexibility to pursue their organizations’ stated purposes and objectives.
value.Summary: The Student Organization Finance Office (SOFO) serves  as the banking center for all student groups recognized by  Northwestern  University. As such, it facilitates financial transactions  and offers an  independent and verifiable record of all the

value.Name: Student Organizations & Activities
value.Description:
Students have the opportunity to participate in over 500 student organizations on campus or create one of their own. Our office provides support, advising, and training for students and their organizations. Through educational and programming opportunities we facilitate and nurture experiences in:

  • Leadership
  • Campus programming
  • Student community service
  • Social justice
  • Student organization development

We encourage students to visit us to find their passion, develop ideas, and think creatively about their student organizations.
value.Summary: Student Organizations & Activities seeks to engage students in involvement opportunities that build a sense of belonging and community at Northwestern University.

value.Name: Student Philanthropy Council
value.Description:
Mission

The mission of the Northwestern Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) is to educate the current undergraduate student population about philanthropy at Northwestern University and inspire a lifetime connection to the University through giving back.

About The Council

Established in 2017, the Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) provides a student voice to philanthropy programming at Northwestern. The Council is comprised of representatives from each of the current undergraduate classes. The Council meets monthly to plan, discuss, and execute Student Philanthropy education and programming opportunities.

The Council is a vital component of the Student Philanthropy program. All members have a voice in the kind of programming that the Office of Alumni Relations and Development provides current students. Members actively engage and participate in shaping the conversation around philanthropy.

Some of the programming and events the Council hosts include the Fall and Spring PhilanthroFests, I Heart Northwestern Week, and Snack Attack.
value.Summary: The Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) provides a student voice to philanthropy programming at Northwestern. The Council meets monthly to plan, discuss, and execute Student Philanthropy education and programming opportunities.

value.Name: Student Theatre Coalition
value.Description: The Northwestern Student Theatre Coalition, or StuCo for short, is a collective of nine student theatre groups and two dance groups, each with its own executive board and mainstage performance series. StuCo exists to provide organizational support for the common practices of the student theatre community at Northwestern, including general auditions for shows, space allocation, and acquisition and maintenance of shared equipment.
value.Summary: The Northwestern Student Theatre Coalition, or StuCo for short, is a collective of nine student theatre groups and two dance groups, each with its own executive board and mainstage performance series.

value.Name: Students Consulting for Non-Profit Organizations
value.Summary: We are a community service organization that provides free strategic consulting services to local non-profits. See more information at our website: https://nuscno.com

value.Name: Students Demand Action
value.Description: Students Demand Action at Northwestern is a campus chapter of a national network of students organizing to end gun violence. Through gun violence education, voter registration, rallies, lobbying, and campaign work, we connect with community organizations and elected leaders at every level to advocate for common sense gun legislation and end the American gun violence epidemic.
value.Summary: Students Demand Action at NU is the Northwestern chapter of Everytown for Gun Safety, a nonprofit organization advocating for gun control and against gun violence.

value.Name: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development
value.Description: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development, SEED, one of the largest, ASG recognized environmental groups on campus, promotes concern for the environment in community decisions and in daily life, through both education and action. SEED’s mission is to pioneer, teach, and model environmental stewardship so as to inspire our future leaders to act in ways that protect and sustain our planet. We seek to engage and educate the Northwestern community on environmental issues by making them relevant and relatable. In doing so, we espouse not only the challenges we face, but make clear the opportunities to improve the welfare of people and the planet together in an effort to produce a healthier, just, and sustainable world.
value.Summary: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development (SEED) works to affect the state of the environment and to support progressive environmental movements at Northwestern University through event programming, service, education and advocacy.

value.Name: Students for Justice in Palestine
value.Description:
SJP is a diverse group of students, faculty, staff, and community members at colleges & universities throughout the US. Our group is organized according to democratic principles in order to promote justice, human rights, liberation, and self-determination for the Palestinian People.

As an advocacy group, SJP is committed to a core set of principles to which it expects its members to adhere. SJP believes that while the Palestinian people must ultimately be able to decide their future in Palestine, certain key principles, grounded in international law, human rights, and basic standards of justice, are fundamental to a just resolution of the plight of the Palestinians. These include the full decolonization of all illegally held Palestinian lands, the end of the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, and East Jerusalem. Furthermore, we believe in a just and fair resolution to the Palestinian right of return and repatriation of Palestinian refugees, as well as an end to the Israeli system of discrimination against the indigenous Palestinian population. Just as SJP condemns the discrimination underlying the policies and laws of the state of Israel, SJP rejects and condemns any form of hatred or discrimination against any religious, racial, or ethnic group. SJP is committed to overcoming anti-Semitic sentiments towards both Arabs and Jews in the community. Rooting its strength in the diversity of its membership, SJP welcomes individuals of all ethnic and religious backgrounds to join in solidarity with the struggle for justice in Palestine.
value.Summary: SJP is a diverse group of students, faculty, staff, and community members at universities throughout the US. Our group is organized according to democratic principles in order to promote justice, human rights, liberation and self-determination.

value.Name: Students Joining Forces for Affordable Housing
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: Students Promoting Education, Awareness, and Knowledge (SPEAK) for Change
value.Description: The mission of SPEAK for Change is to utilize activist efforts in order to challenge the normalization of sexual and interpersonal violence at Northwestern and in society at-large, as well as to foster a campus community in which survivors can thrive.
value.Summary: The mission of SPEAK for Change is to utilize activist efforts in order to challenge the normalization of sexual and interpersonal violence at Northwestern and in society at-large, as well as to foster a campus community in which survivors can thrive.

value.Name: Studio 22 Productions
value.Description:
Studio 22 is a student-run, not-for-profit, film production company.

In addition to making short films, Studio 22 serves the community by
providing workshops on filmmaking as well as by bringing in industry
professionals to help transition our filmmakers from the university
setting to the professional world.
value.Summary: Studio 22 is a student-run production company that exists to provide extracurricular filmmaking opportunities not offered in production classes. Studio 22 continually strives to promote education, ambition, and quality in Northwestern filmmakers.

value.Name: Supplies for Dreams
value.Description: Supplies for Dreams is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that provides underprivileged Chicago Public School students with critical resources and extra-curricular opportunities ranging from basic school supplies to field trips and social/academic mentoring. The Northwestern Chapter of SFD strives to give opportunities for NU students to help SFD do this, as well as bring awareness of the issues in education that exist.
value.Summary: Supplies for Dreams is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that provides underprivileged Chicago Public School students with critical resources and extra-curricular opportunities ranging from basic school supplies to field trips and one-on-one mentoring.

value.Name: Surf Club
value.Summary: Surf Club hopes to build a fun-loving and supportive community of student surfers! We will strive to give access to surfing equipment to as many students as possible, regardless of skill level.

value.Name: Survivor: Northwestern
value.Description: Survivor: Northwestern is an organization that aims to mimic the reality television show "Survivor" here on campus. It is completely recorded, edited, and produced by students at Northwestern, and a typical season runs from January to May, with pre- and post-planning.
value.Summary: Survivor: Northwestern is an organization that aims to mimic the reality television show "Survivor" here on campus.

value.Name: Sustained Dialogue
value.Description: Student-led program coordinated by Social Justice Education.
value.Summary: Sustained Dialogue (SD) is a student-facilitated program that encourages conversation across lines of difference. Students participate in weekly 90-minute sessions throughout the quarter in which they explore issues around their social identities.

value.Name: Swing Left
value.Description:
Swing Left is a student group organizing Northwestern to help Democrats keep the House, Senate, and the White House as well as end Republican voter suppression.

We engage in direct voter contact by writing letters and making calls to Swing Left's Super States: Arizona, Colorado, Texas, Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maine, North Carolina, Georgia and Florida.
value.Summary: Swing Left introduces Northwestern students to the most effective voter contact opportunities to elect Democrats up and down the ballot in key states across the country.

value.Name: Tabletop Club
value.Description:
• You're invited to join our Discord! https://discord.gg/TdRKybf

 

  • For the 2022-23 year, Tabletop Club will continue to offer both virtual and hybrid activities so anyone can participate to any extent in the amazing world of tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPGs).

 

  • We hold Game Night events! Whether it’s virtual or in-person, these are always a good time. Drop to play Jackbox games, Coup, Werewolf, and other favorites. 

 

  • Our longer campaigns are great for those who would like to play an ongoing story with a consistent group of people. Anyone is welcome to run or join a campaign! Campaigns usually last a quarter, but they can be shorter or longer depending on the group. They are often a weekly commitment, but scheduling is quite flexible and will be figured out with every member of the party. If you'd like to run a campaign, don't hesitate to join our Discord and start organizing!

 

  • We also have intermittent One Shot games. These are casual, 4-ish hour long games for people with any amount of experience with TTRPGs. These games will be run in varying systems like Dungeons & Dragons, Honey Heist, Monster of the Week, and more! The one shots are a great opportunity to dip your toes in the water and learn about TTRPGs. They are also awesome for more experienced players who are looking to try out new systems, meet people interested in the hobby at NU, or get their dose of TTRPGs without needing to commit too much time!
value.Summary: We aim to facilitate tabletop roleplaying at NU by providing everyone the opportunity to learn, explore, and enjoy the hobby in an inclusive, friendly environment. Join our discord! https://discord.gg/TdRKybf

value.Name: Taiwanese American Students Association
value.Description:
Northwestern University's premiere student group for those passionate about Taiwan and Taiwanese culture!

Previously known as TASC, we are rebranding to TASA!

The Taiwanese American Students Association (TASA) was established in 1992, and the Associated Student Government recognized TASA as a student organization in January of 1994. Since then, TASA has grown from a group of eight members to an Associated Student Government A-status organization with members from all backgrounds, Asians and non-Asians alike.

TASA was founded to provide a forum in which Taiwanese history, culture and current events could be openly celebrated and shared among all Asian Americans and the NU community at large. Our mission is two-fold: to build community amongst students interested in Taiwan, and to provide the larger Northwestern community the chance to explore and learn about the many facets of Taiwanese culture.
value.Summary: A Taiwanese-American student interest group striving to promote cultural awareness through educational events like Taiwanese Night Market, Karaoke Night, Dragon Boat Festival, Celebrasia, and more.

value.Name: TAMID Group
value.Description: TAMID at Northwestern provides students the opportunity to gain exposure to the fields of consulting, investment management, venture capital, entrepreneurship, and technology innovation. Through experiences such as hands-on start-up consulting and portfolio management, our members are prepared to enter the workforce with invaluable skills. Israel’s economic landscape embodies the ideal model of integrating technology with entrepreneurship. By connecting students with the Israeli economy as a case study, TAMID at Northwestern educates students and prepares them for their professional careers.
value.Summary: TAMID at Northwestern provides students the opportunity to gain exposure to the fields of consulting, investment management, venture capital, entrepreneurship and technology innovation by learning from industry leaders and consulting for Israeli startups

value.Name: TBD
value.Description:
Founded in 2015 in collaboration with the Chicago Neo-Futurists, TBD is Northwestern's premiere Neo-Futurism inspired performance group. TBD is an ensemble of students who strive to create non-illusory theatre that shares our thoughts and feelings as simply as possible so that it is more accessible to all audiences. We play ourselves without the normal conventions of theatre, telling our own truths onstage. We create an environment where the audience is as important as the people on stage, and we create a space for sharing the human experience as honestly as one can whilst performing.

Our ensemble members write and direct their own short plays, which can range in length anywhere from 1 second to 5 minutes! Our plays are wacky, serious, hilarious, political, sad, and anything in between. We perform on Northwestern's campus once per quarter in a fast paced, audience interactive showcase of new plays.
value.Summary: A Neo-futurism inspired performance group

value.Name: TEDxNorthwesternU
value.Description:
TEDxNorthwesternU is an independently organized TEDx conference held annually at Northwestern University. The organizing team is comprised of undergraduate students representing all of Northwestern's undergraduate schools and colleges.

Every spring we host a TED conference on campus, bringing together students and speakers to discuss and share ideas. The board is broken down into three committees: Marketing, Curation, and Logistics/Finance, each with its own role in developing and planning content for the conference. 

Check out our website here, or look up any of our old TED talks on youtube!
value.Summary: TEDxNorthwesternU is an independently organized TEDx conference held annually at Northwestern University.  The organizing team is comprised of undergraduate students representing all of Northwestern's undergraduate schools and colleges.

value.Name: TGS Cross-Cultural
value.Description: Northwestern University is a community devoted to producing successful and competent leaders for the modern workplace. Producing such leaders requires that graduate students have skills of cultural competence to successfully navigate the growing diversity of our global workplace. Northwestern University has an office of multicultural affairs, which contains programs related to diversity and cultural competence, demonstrating Northwestern’s recognition of the importance of instilling cultural competence and intercultural dialogue. To this end, a graduate student cross-­‐cultural communication committee can strengthen and further promote skills of graduate student cultural competence through advertising and co-­‐hosting programming aimed specifically at creating an inclusive atmosphere where all graduate students can interact and learn how to be successful communicators.
value.Summary: We are student group aimed to promote cross-cultural dialogue, awareness of situations where cultural sensitivity is important, so that students from different backgrounds can have good conversations together.

value.Name: The Bix
value.Description:
THE BIX is Northwestern's premiere musical improv group!! With the help of our music directors, The Bix improvises scenes, songs, and more. We are a goofy bunch of improvisers who refuse to take ourselves too seriously. Throughout the year, we put on shows using short form and long form skills culminating in a fully improvised musical. 

***Not a singer? Not a problem! The Bix prides ourselves on our diversity of skills. If singing or music isn't your thing, but you love being a goofball, The Bix just might be the perfect fit!***

 

Wanna know more? https://thebiximprov.weebly.com

 

Questions? Shoot us an email at thebiximprov@gmail.com
value.Summary:
THE BIX is a comedy improv group at Northwestern University focused on, but not limited to, musical improvisation. 
Not a singer? Not a problem!

value.Name: The Black Creative Collective
value.Description:
The purpose of this organization is to provide community, foster collaboration, and ground a specific focus of work in a space for critical feedback. Specifically, this organization aims to create a community amongst black graduate students at Northwestern who are either practitioners or in a field of study pertaining to the representation of people of African descent in film, video, and other media.

Our goals are derivative from TGS’ pillars of advocacy, connection, and cultivation but focused in a way that is specifically necessary for Black students to commune and thrive in the graduate school at Northwestern. We aim to advocate for an authentic space for culturally specific engagement with students' works. We aim to cultivate and foster a community that connects students with each other through the engagement of work and culturally relative discussion. This organization also aims to include the consistent and earnest engagement of Black faculty within the university and externally through alumni, artists, thought leaders in the community, and professionals in various fields of creative industries. In doing so, our overarching goal is to cultivate a thriving Black artist community within the graduate program whose work is confidently grounded in the rich cultural landscape of students’ place of origin, the Chicagoland area, and the larger world as understood by people of African descent.
value.Summary: This organization aims to create a community amongst black graduate students at Northwestern who are either practitioners or in a field of study pertaining to the representation of people of African descent in film, video, and other media.

value.Name: The Blackout
value.Description: The Blackout, Northwestern's Late Night Show, infuses Northwestern humor and the late-night structure to create a unique show capturing the Northwestern experience in a satirical light. The crew of 100+ students write, direct, and produce filmed and live sketches, scout out and book local talent for musical and performance guests, and throw one live-show for the student body per quarter.
value.Summary: The Blackout is Northwestern's premiere late-night comedy show. Drawing inspiration from "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert" & "Saturday Night Live", The Blackout utilizes the structure of a late-night talk show and infuses it with Northwestern humor.

value.Name: The Campus Kitchen at Northwestern University
value.Description:
Campus Kitchens collects over 3,000 lbs of excess food from Northwestern dining halls that would otherwise be thrown away. We package the food into healthy meals and deliver these meals to low-income Evanston residents for free. We are conveniently based on campus in The Great Room Kitchen at 600 Haven Street. 

Beyond regular operations, we also participate in on and off campus programming. In the past, we have done pumpkin carving with kids at Asian Youth Services, cooked meals for Memorial Day at Second Baptist, and helped students with their homework and St. Patrick's Day crafts at Salvation Army, taught nutrition education classes at YOU and Dawes Elementary School. On campus, we have screened documentaries, partnered with other groups to feature social justice-related speakers, co-hosted a Hunger Games competition and more. Our organization looks to expand our Evanston community-based programming as well as reach more Northwestern students.

 

We have volunteer shifts every day of the week - no prior experience is required! Sign up for a shift here. 

 

this
value.Summary: CKNU empowers students to create sustainable pipelines for food justice in the local and national community, recovering food from dining halls, and then working to distribute leftovers in healthy meals to work towards equity, one sandwich at a time.

value.Name: The Cancer Journal Club
value.Description:
• The Cancer Journal Club (CJC) seeks to generate interest in novel and significant cancer research among the Northwestern student community and to provide pathways and mentors in which students of any background or major may explore their interests in cancer research.  
  • Through the review of relevant topics in the field of cancer research, the Cancer Journal Club will serve to educate its students about the science of cancer itself, as well as the efforts in research behind it that aim to put an end to cancer. By reviewing articles biweekly, students can sharpen their ability to read and understand scientific literature, as well as become educated in a clinical field that relates to the well-being of others. This aligns with Northwestern’s mission, as following the goals of the CJC can lead to increased involvement and education in the field of research, as well as increased scientific awareness in our community of students.
value.Summary: The Cancer Journal Club seeks to generate interest in novel and significant cancer research among the Northwestern student community and to provide pathways and mentors for students of any background or major to explore an interests in cancer research.

value.Name: The Club Ski Team
value.Summary: We are a competitive team, focused on alpine skiing, that will compete within the Midwest Division of the USCSA. We will run events and fundraising to build a winter sport community on Northwestern's Campus. Joins us this inaugural winter and get stoked!

value.Name: The Daily Northwestern
value.Description: One of the nation's most respected college newspapers, The Daily Northwestern has won dozens of regional and national awards. In 2017, The Daily was named Best All-Around Daily Student Newspaper in the nation by the Society of Professional Journalists. The Daily received 18 awards at the 2016 ICPA convention. In the last decade, The Daily has won two prestigious national awards, the Gold Crown Award and the Pacemaker, several times.
value.Summary: One of the nation's oldest and most respected college newspapers, The Daily Northwestern has won dozens of regional and national awards and has been publishing since 1871. Both print and online publications are produced entirely by students.

value.Name: The Dead Pancreas Society
value.Summary: A club for the pancreatically challenged that provides community and support while raising awareness for type 1 diabetics.

value.Name: The Dolphin Show
value.Description: The Dolphin Show is a non-profit student theatre organization that annually produces America's largest student-produced musical. Having evolved from a swim team fundraiser in the 1940's to an annual professional-caliber musical production, The Dolphin Show celebrates the diverse talents of the Northwestern University undergraduate community by providing opportunities to learn and excel in all artistic and administrative fields of non-profit theatre. The Dolphin Show additionally involves the greater Chicago area communities through outreach programming. Successful Dolphin Show Alumni include actors David Schwimmer, Warren Beatty and former Miss America Kate Shindle.
value.Summary: The Dolphin Show is a non-profit student theatre organization that annually produces the nation's largest student-run musical.

value.Name: The Graduate School
value.Summary: The mission of The Graduate School of Northwestern University is: to be a trusted, responsive, and visionary leader and partner in order to maintain and promote the highest quality master’s and doctoral education.

value.Name: The Open Democracy
value.Description: We are a student-led chapter of Indivisible, a grassroots movement of thousands of groups with a mission to elect progressive leaders and rebuild American democracy. The goal of The Open Democracy Project is to provide students with action-oriented opportunities to develop organizing and leadership skills, and to meet and work with other students interested in addressing social issues like climate change and social justice. The Open Democracy Project is the organization supporting the first ever Participatory Budgeting process in Evanston.
value.Summary: We are a student-led chapter of Indivisible, a grassroots movement of thousands of groups with a mission to elect progressive leaders and rebuild American democracy.

value.Name: The Panini Players
value.Description:
The Panini Players are a theatre ensemble who perform in the style of Commedia dell'Arte. We hold one feature performance per quarter, which includes a make-your-own panini dinner and a one-hour show. We mix lowbrow physical comedy with highbrow wit, which produces an interesting comedic dynamic.

https://vimeo.com/256685839
value.Summary: The Panini Players are a theatre ensemble dedicated to bringing the classical style of Commedia dell'Arte to campus. Commedia is distinctive for its use of masks,  stock characters, physical comedy and improvisation.

value.Name: The Set-Up
value.Summary: The Set-Up is a Standup comedy club dedicated to workshops, showcases, open mics, watch parties, and all other forms of standup performance/appreciation.

value.Name: The Spiel
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: The Subcontinent Project
value.Description: The Subcontinent Project aims to foster meaningful conversations among the Northwestern and Chicagoland community by organizing events pertaining to South Asian issues including, but not limited to, democracy and human rights, gender and sexuality and nationalism, and situating these topics as a part of larger global conversations that are currently taking place.
value.Summary: The Subcontinent Project aims to foster meaningful conversations among the Northwestern and Chicagoland community by organizing events pertaining to South Asian issues.

value.Name: The Undertones
value.Description:
Founded in 2001, the Undertones are a co-ed a cappella group that loves to travel, compete, and be goofy together. We pride ourselves on maintaining a very high level of musicianship, resulting in the group placing second at the 2018 ICCA Great Lakes Quarterfinals and receiving the “Outstanding Soloist” award. Tones have studied in every major school Northwestern University has to offer and hail from all over, creating opportunities for the group to tour nationally (The White House, NYC, Orlando, Denver) and internationally (Edinburgh, Scotland and Barcelona, Spain).  Although much of our time together is spent rehearsing, performing, and recording, the Undertones are also a close group of friends who love spending time with one another and keeping the fun and silliness alive in the work we do!

Check us out on Instagram and YouTube (@nuundertones) or on Spotify (Northwestern Undertones).
value.Summary: A cappella group from Northwestern University. We sing and laugh while keeping the love and silliness alive.

value.Name: The Waa-Mu Show
value.Description:
As Northwestern’s oldest theatrical tradition, The Waa-Mu Show provides undergraduates with the unparalleled opportunity to create an original musical each year. Students serve as leaders in every aspect of development from conception through production to create a show exploring themes and stories that inspire us as college students, challenge us as musical theatre artists, and engage us with our surrounding communities.

The Waa-Mu Show strives to place itself at the forefront of new musical theatre writing, continuing to push the limits of the “greatest college show in America” (Associated Press).
value.Summary: The Waa-Mu Show is Northwestern University's own original musical, written, performed, and presented by Northwestern students.

value.Name: The Women's Network
value.Description: The Women’s Network (TWN) was created for ambitious women looking to grow professionally while being lifted by their community. TWN offers opportunities to gain exposure to the professional world, network with high-profile speakers, and meet peers around their campus and the country. TWN meets biweekly (twice a month) and holds speaker meetings, various networking events, resume, internship and LinkedIn workshops, alumni networking receptions, and interactive activity sessions to develop relationships with fellow members. Our workshops and guest speakers help prepare you for your next steps and may open your eyes to career paths you hadn't considered. TWN prides itself on its non-competitive, inclusive, and supportive community of high-achieving and ambitious members. This organization offers exclusive internship opportunities, workshops and support to help you build your LinkedIn/resume. More personally, TWN is a great place to meet new people within Northwestern, around the country and make friends from various majors.
value.Summary: The Women’s Network is a networking organization that celebrates ambition and connects women to fellow high-achieving, noncompetitive peers on their respective college campuses and to seasoned female professionals in various fields.

value.Name: The Youth Movement Against Alzheimer's
value.Description: TBA
value.Summary: YMAA is a national non-profit organization that focuses on "curing" Alzheimer's through raising awareness of neurodegenerative diseases amongst youth, reducing stigma surrounding Alzheimer's, and alleviating caretaker/family stress.

value.Name: Theme Park Engineering & Design
value.Description:
The Theme Park Engineering & Design Group (TPED) is a design club under McCormick School of Engineering. 


TPED provides theme park enthusiasts from ALL academic majors a fun multidisciplinary space to pursue their passion for themed entertainment. TPED is a platform for members to further their professional development and delve deeper into this unique field of interest by focusing on three main areas:

1. Collaborating on themed entertainment design projects and competitions.
2. Learning from and networking with professionals in the themed entertainment industry via talks, workshops, and conferences.
3. Creating opportunities to discover and hone industry-related skills.

If you're a designer, artist, engineer, musician, programmer, or literally any person who's interested in making memorable themed experiences, join us!
value.Summary: Theme Park Engineering & Design Group (TPED) is a multidisciplinary design club for themed entertainment enthusiasts from all backgrounds!

value.Name: This We Believe Northwestern
value.Description:
This We Believe Northwestern is based on the popular National Public Radio program, “This I Believe,” (thisibelieve.org) where regular people create and share short essays reflecting on an aspect of their personal philosophy.

Organizations throughout the country have developed their own versions of the program, and have built community and space for reflection. At Northwestern, we successfully piloted the program in the spring of 2012. Over four weeks, small groups meet over a meal to write and share their own essays in a supportive environment. It is one way we can build deeper connections with students, staff, and faculty.

This We Believe Northwestern grew out of a group of Northwestern staff working on implementing and assessing the Spirituality learning domain of the Division of Student Affairs.

If you would like to nominate a student or staff/faculty member, please contact Eric Budzynski at e-budzynski@northwestern.edu  

You may also nominate yourself(!) or inquire about more information on this fantastic program.
value.Summary: This We Believe Northwestern is an initiative where students, staff, and faculty come together to share a meal and create belief statements reflecting on an aspect of their personal philosophy.

value.Name: THUNK A Cappella
value.Description:
THUNK a cappella is Northwestern University's oldest co-ed a cappella group. Since their beginning on campus in 1993, THUNK performs three shows every year on campus, while also performing at numerous external gigs and workshops on campus and in the Chicago area.

Follow us on Instagram for audition updates!

⬇︎⬇︎ Check out our Videos & Social Media below! ⬇︎⬇︎
value.Summary: THUNK a cappella is Northwestern's premier co-ed a cappella group. They have been singing and wearing hot black on campus since 1993. They perform on campus and in the Chicago area

value.Name: TONIK Tap
value.Description: Founded in 2001, TONIK Tap is Northwestern University’s premier tap dance ensemble. TONIK’s members hail from all over the country and collectively study a variety of majors, but we all have one thing in common – we love to create rhythm. We perform at various Northwestern and Chicagoland events, from Rhythm Nation and Eberhard's chemistry show in the fall, to Wildcat Days and Dance Marathon in the spring. We also produce two shows a year on campus, with original choreography and video interludes. TONIK's self-choreographed repertoire has been recognized and featured as part of Dance Chicago, a city-wide dance festival in downtown Chicago. We have tapped with soccer balls, an a cappella group, eggs, on contact explosives, and have recreated classic choreography by Gene Kelly. What can we say, tap goes with everything! Email us at toniktap@gmail.com.
value.Summary: TONIK Tap is Northwestern's premier tap dance company. We come from all over but we all have one thing in common -- we love to make rhythm! As a completely student-run group, we perform all over campus and the Chicagoland area.

value.Name: Track Club
value.Description:
The NU Track Club is a group of runners from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL. The goals of the group are to:

  •  Promote the sport of running and track and field
  •  Provide a supportive group training environment
  •  Have fun!

    The club is composed of all types of runners, from those running to stay in shape to those seeking competition. The track club is also a great way to meet new friends and we are always accepting new members.

We meet for practice on weekdays at 5:30pm in front of SPAC.

For contact information and more about the team please visit our website: 

http://sites.northwestern.edu/runners/ . 

 

If you would like to join our Listserv (mailing list) and GroupMe (our main form of communication), sign up at: https://jointrack.club

 

If you have any questions or concerns, email our President, Gavin!
value.Summary:
Go check out our main website: 
 http://sites.northwestern.edu/runners/

value.Name: Trading Card Game Club
value.Description:
Helping Northwestern students find groups to play trading card games, help them develop as trading card game players, and to provide an inclusive environment in which new and seasoned players alike can play trading card games together.

Please feel free to join our Discord @ https://discord.gg/v9PX3pgT or follow our Instagram @tcgclubnu for details!
value.Summary: Our goal is to help Northwestern students find groups to play trading card games, help them develop as trading card game players, and to provide an inclusive environment in which new and seasoned players alike can play trading card games together.

value.Name: Transfer Student Organization
value.Description: Transfer Student Organization (TSO) fosters a welcoming environment for Northwestern transfer students across all years. TSO facilitates social events every quarter which serve as a platform for transfers to meet, make friends, and access mentorship. In 2018 TSO launched the Transfer Mentorship Program–an initiative which pairs incoming transfer students with transfer mentors based on common interests. Given the self-guided mentor approach, the goal is to ease the process for new transfers. In addition, we promote inclusion and secure resources by voicing community perspectives to the Associated Student Government and university offices. All transfers are welcome to join!
value.Summary: As the only Northwestern group of its kind, TSO aims to cultivate a dynamic and supportive community of transfer students. We hope to overcome any challenges standing in the way of transfer integration into Northwestern, especially the incoming class.

value.Name: Transportation Club
value.Description:
Northwestern Transportation Club is a platform for all students interested in transportation at Northwestern. We connect communities, generate interest, and create space for transportation enthusiasts and career-seeking students to collaborate and celebrate their shared passion. We organize seminars, workshops, field trips, and networking events.

Some highlights are: visiting American Airlines flight tower in 2018, visiting United Airlines headquarters in 2019, holding online social events and game nights in 2020 during the pandemic, and holding online industry event with Amazon and DHL in 2021 in collaboration with Northwestern's Informs Club.

The goal is provide an environment for members and students to stay-in-touch outside of a course environment through relaxing and fun social events, advancing the experience of students through boots-on-the-ground visits and events, and providing networking and job opportunities through industry events.

Anyone who is interested in Transportation is welcome to join the club!
value.Summary: The Northwestern Transportation Club is a graduate student club focused on students interested in Transportation. Undergraduate students are also welcome to join to club events.

value.Name: Treblemakers
value.Description: Treblemakers is Northwestern’s premiere East-Asian interest a cappella group and welcomes all identities. We sing everything from mainstream American pop, to jazzy Asian ballads, to mashups featuring the best of both worlds. Apart from our quarterly shows, we have year-round gigs performing at Homecoming, Christkindlemarket, CISA show, Celebrasia, and many others. Celebrating cultural exchange, we’ve had the opportunity to tour Hong Kong, Seoul, Beijing and California, as well as collaborate with other special-interest a cappella groups for shows. Throughout the year, everyone has the chance to pitch songs, arrangements, show themes and whatever tickles their fancy. When we’re not making music with our mouths, you can catch us on a road trip around the midwest, going out for a boba run, or just kicking back for a game night. While attending Zoom University, we’ll be making those matrix-styled group videos, featuring solo showcases and participating in other online shenanigans.
value.Summary:
Treblemakers is Northwestern’s East-Asian interest a cappella group and welcomes all identities. We sing everything from mainstream American pop, to jazzy Asian ballads, to mashups featuring the best of both worlds.
Link: https://linktr.ee/Nutreble

value.Name: Tufaan Entertainment
value.Description: Tufaan Entertainment is Northwestern's premier Bollywood-fusion dance competition. It identifies itself as a student-led philanthropic entertainment organisation aiming to raise awareness of South Asian culture in the US and promote education through the arts abroad. Tufaan hosts esteemed teams from across the country as they compete for a national bid at the Bollywood America competition. Tufaan Entertainment is dedicated to supporting Shanti Bhavan, a K-12 school in rural India providing a world-class liberal arts education for socioeconomically disadvantaged children.
value.Summary: Tufan Entertainment is a student led non-profit organization that presents talented South Asian performers from across the country in an intercollegiate dance competition to raise funds for a school in India.

value.Name: Turkish Graduate Student Association
value.Description: The purpose of our organization, Turkish Graduate Student Association (TGSA), is to bring the large population of Turkish graduate students, Turkish faculty, and general graduate community together to create a safe, inclusive, social, and connective environment. We aim to create a welcoming and supportive environment for all students, Turkish and NU graduate community, to share their ideas, build a network, and enrich the graduate community at NU through cultural, educational and professional events. Along with contributing to Turkish community at NU, our organization aims to hold outreach events in both U.S. and Turkiye to promote and encourage networking and collaborations between the strong Turkish graduate research community.
value.Summary: The purpose of Turkish Graduate Student Association (TGSA) is to bring the large population of Turkish graduate students, Turkish faculty, and general graduate community together to create a safe, inclusive, social, and connective environment.

value.Name: Turkish Student Association
value.Description:
The Turkish Student Association (TSA) aims to gather Turkish students under one umbrella and create a supportive environment while introducing Turkish culture to Northwestern, thus creating a more diverse environment. Some of the events that TSA organizes are (but are not limited to): watching Turkish national team games (i.e., football [soccer], basketball), dinner organizations, national holiday celebrations, and many more. All Northwestern students are welcome to take part in the events.

 

Additional Info: Citizens of Turkic heritage countries (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, and Northern Cyprus) and Turkic-Americans are more than welcome to join the club as members (some fluency in one of the Oghuz Turkish branches might be helpful).
value.Summary: The Turkish Student Association (TSA) aims to gather Turkish students under one umbrella and create a supportive environment while introducing Turkish culture to Northwestern, thus creating a more diverse environment.

value.Name: Typhoon Dance Troupe
value.Description:
Typhoon Dance Troupe is a student organized dance group that highlights popular, classical, ethnic, and contemporary dances of East and Southeast Asia. Through the art of dance, we dedicate ourselves to displaying pieces of the regions' rich, diverse cultures and to promote more interest and appreciation in the community for those cultures.

Dances are open to people from any type of background, ranging from beginner to experienced, in many styles of dance, including but not limited to: Traditional Han and ethnic Dai Dance, Hip-hop and street dance, jazz dance, and kpop dance. We have weekly workshop and rehearsals and we also invite famous dancers all over the world as our "Master Class" program. We learn and practice for several performances in Northwestern-affiliated productions and off-campus events, most notably Celebrasia, the annual Chinese New Year celebration co-sponsored by CSA and TASC, which draws over 500 people annually. We also make dance videos to record our work and memorable time together. 

Examples of our dance:

"Caiwei" (Chinese classical dance) https://youtu.be/dHs60XSBxRY

"Peacock" (Chinese Dai dance) https://youtu.be/KK3Isi67XQc

"Flying Apsaras" (Chinese style popular dance) https://youtu.be/rAWcKl5P9TM

"Layin Low" (K-pop dance) https://youtu.be/w7Ir_F7sknc

"Moment" (Chinese style jazz dance) https://youtu.be/ZmtOqXIXrzA

"Grain in Ear" (Chinese style jazz dance ) https://youtu.be/HNUdvEhGTvA
value.Summary: Typhoon Dance Troupe is a student organized dance group that highlights popular and classical dances of East and Southeast Asia. Through work of art, we dedicate ourselves to displaying pieces of the regions' rich and diverse culture.

value.Name: Ukrainian Club
value.Summary: Ukrainian Club provides an inclusive environment where students can explore Ukrainian identity and culture through educational and social events.

value.Name: Ukulele Club
value.Description:
Ukulele club is a relaxed, fun organization which welcomes students of any major and skill level. We have a ton of beginners along with more advanced players, and all are invited to jam with us! Ukulele club meets weekly, along with playing at a number of various events throughout the year, such as Cider Nights, the Lakefill Bonfire, end of the quarter performances, and more!

Ukulele club meets every Friday at 4:30 PM in Annenberg Hall. Generally, we’ll chill out and catch up with the other members of the club for 5 or 10 minutes. Announcements will be given, and then we’ll either teach the songs for the week or jam out! We also do breakout rooms based off skill level, so anyone and everyone is welcome! Lessons involve new chords, finger-picking techniques, and strum patterns. After the lesson, we will continue to jam as a whole group!
value.Summary: The purpose of Ukulele club is to teach people how to play ukulele, and to help people who already know how to play the ukulele improve. Additionally, our goal is to foster an accepting and welcoming environment where people can jam with friends.

value.Name: Undergraduate Chemistry Council
value.Description:
The UCC welcomes students of all majors who are interested in the science of chemistry. We hold quarterly chemistry-related events including UCC Pizza Talks with fellow undergraduates giving talks about their research. We also provide community outreach events for grade school-aged children in the Evanston and Chicago area. In addition, each year the UCC helps put on campus-wide chemistry shows that attract hundreds of people, the most popular ones being the Halloween and Eberhard Beach shows, and each spring we bring a distinguished speaker to come to Northwestern and speak about their research.

Join our listserv here!
value.Summary: The UCC welcomes students of all majors who are interested in chemistry! We put together chemistry-related events each quarter as well as campus-wide chemistry events such as the Halloween show and liquid nitrogen ice cream social!

value.Name: Undergraduate Economics Society
value.Description:
The Undergraduate Economics Society is a group for undergraduate economics majors, and others interested in economics and business.

Our mission is to increase resources for students interested in economics and business and further their academic and career goals. We strive to provide a variety of events to enrich students’ experiences at Northwestern and to continue the pursuit for excellence in the events we host and sponsor.

In the past, UES has hosted Career Workshops on topics such as Resume, Cover Letter, Recruitment, and Industry Overview. Also, UES holds multiple Speaker Events every quarter featuring renowned economists in Northwestern and Kellogg, Internship speaker panel, and Professionals.
value.Summary: The Undergraduate Economics Society is a group for undergraduate economics majors, and others interested in economics and business. We hold a variety of events to increase resources and to enrich students’ experiences at Northwestern.

value.Name: Undergraduate Premedical Society
value.Description: The Undergraduate Premedical Society at Northwestern University (UPS) is an organization designed to provide premedical students with resources and opportunities as they plan to apply to medical school.  Please contact premednu@gmail.com if you have any questions.  For more information visit the UPS Facebook Page at www.facebook.com/NorthwesternUPS.
value.Summary: The Undergraduate Premedical Society at Northwestern University (UPS) is an organization designed to provide premedical students with resources and opportunities as they plan to apply to medical school.  Contact: premednu@gmail.com

value.Name: Undergraduate Prison Education Partnership
value.Description: The Undergraduate Prison Education Partnership cultivates collaboration between Evanston undergraduates and incarcerated students in the Northwestern Prison Education Program at Stateville Correctional Center through prison education initiatives. These initiatives include events, tutoring, workshops, and classes at Stateville CC, awareness and advocacy campaigns in Evanston, supplies drives, and fundraising events supporting prison education.
value.Summary: Our student group works closely with the Northwestern Prison Education Program (NPEP) to develop prison education initiatives at Stateville Correctional Center and Cook County Department of Corrections

value.Name: Undergraduate Psychology Association
value.Description: The Undergraduate Psychology Association (UPA) is a group of students who share a passion for exploring Psychology. UPA welcomes students of all majors to participate in academic, career-oriented, and social events during the school year. Our primary goals are to help undergraduate students learn more about psychology in a non-classroom setting, foster student-faculty communications, and facilitate the awareness of professional opportunities related to psychology.
value.Summary: The Undergraduate Psychology Association (UPA) is a group of students who share a passion for exploring Psychology. UPA welcomes students of all majors to participate in academic, career-oriented, and social events during the school year.

value.Name: Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association
value.Description: URSA is the Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association. It is made up of 10 or more student representatives in the Radio/TV/Film department. We act as the liaison between the student body and the faculty. Our role is to relay students' issues, concerns, and complaints about the curriculum to the faculty so that these problems can be solved. Our co-chairs attend monthly faculty meetings and meet with the department chairs regularly in order to ensure that the students are being heard.
value.Summary: URSA is the Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association. It is made up of 10 student representatives in the Radio/TV/Film department. We act as the liaison between the student body and the faculty.

value.Name: Undergraduate Real Estate Club
value.Summary: The Northwestern University Real Estate Club (NUREC) seeks to prepare undergraduates with the required skills to thrive in the real estate finance industry. Club members will undergo financial modeling training, take part in networking events, and more.

value.Name: UNICEF NU
value.Description: UNICEF NU seeks to engage Northwestern University students in global health issues and to advocate for the rights of children and other vulnerable populations worldwide. In the past, UNICEF NU has hosted a number of events, including a speaker panel about women's health, documentary screenings about human trafficking, and a water walk to raise awareness about the need for clean water across the globe.
value.Summary: UNICEF NU is an organization that aims to educate, advocate and fundraise on behalf of UNICEF.

value.Name: United Students for Veterans' Health
value.Description: tba
value.Summary: tba

value.Name: UNITY Charity Fashion Show
value.Description:
About Us:

Uniting communities through fashion and philanthropy.

UNITY Charity Fashion Show is a non-profit, student-run organization working to provide an outlet for students and those in the Greater Chicago area to use their love for fashion, style, and art for good. Each year, during Northwestern's spring quarter, UNITY hosts a fashion show featuring student performers, dancers, musicians, and artists with an audience of 200+ people. Proceeds from the show benefit a charitable organization in Chicago chosen by our own members. UNITY also hosts fundraising events throughout the year such as clothing drives, pop-up thrift shops, and model Q&As. In the past, we’ve partnered with Social Works and raised $10,000 towards their efforts for Chicago Public Schools. This year, UNITY partners with Arts of Life, which is a non-profit organization for artists with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

Any inquiries about involvement, press, or sponsorships, please contact unity.northwestern@gmail.com.
value.Summary: UNITY Charity Fashion Show is an annual event sponsored by diverse student groups from across campus. Together, students from all backgrounds come together for their love of fashion and raise money for a different charity every year.

value.Name: University Bible Fellowship
value.Description: UBF is a nondenominational, evangelical fellowship with one-to-one and group Bible studies, reflection sharing, Sunday worship, and conferences. One-to-one Bible studies are flexible appointments; students can determine location and time. Email for more information.
value.Summary: UBF is a nondenominational, evangelical fellowship with one-to-one and group Bible studies, reflection sharing, Sunday worship, and conferences. One-to-one Bible studies are flexible appointments; students can determine location and time. Email for info.

value.Name: University Blood Initiative
value.Description: UBI’s mission is to replenish a blood donor pool that is lacking both in numbers and diversity of blood type by engaging youth and local communities to become invested blood donors. UBI seeks to build lasting and sustainable relationships within communities to allow our nation’s blood supply to thrive and save lives. We do this by educating and spreading awareness of the serious blood shortages throughout our healthcare system. UBI therefore is distinct from other organizations that offer blood drives and similar activities. While blood donations and drives are only a portion of other organizations’ activities, UBI focuses on using grassroots efforts to reduce our nation’s significant blood shortages.
value.Summary: UBI’s mission is to replenish a blood donor pool that is lacking both in numbers and diversity of blood type by engaging youth and local communities to become invested blood donors.

value.Name: University Christian Ministry
value.Description:
UCM is an ecumenical and queer-inclusive campus ministry at Northwestern University. We are sponsored by the United Methodist Church and the Presbyterian Church (USA). If you are looking for the Wesley Foundation or the Westminster House at Northwestern University, you have found us! All are welcome at UCM.

On Sundays at 5:00 PM we have a casual worship service in our living room. Stay afterwards for fellowship and let us get to know you better. Occasionally we share meals and have holiday parties. We also host guest speakers throughout the quarter who address a variety of current social justice issues. Annual retreats give us a chance to get away from campus, bond with each other, and find spiritual renewal.  

Discover how our campus ministry expresses God's love in action, compassion and justice on the campus of Northwestern University.
value.Summary: Authentic community, queer inclusive, Jesus lovers, justice seekers.

value.Name: University Special Interest
value.Description: University Special Interest is a label for student organizations related to Northwestern University (i.e. The Northwestern Daily, NU Channel 1, etc.).
value.Summary: University Special Interest is a label for student organizations related to Northwestern University (i.e. The Northwestern Daily, NU Channel 1, etc.).

value.Name: Vertigo Productions
value.Description: Vertigo is an executive student theatre board dedicated to producing new work by fellow undergraduate students.
value.Summary: Vertigo is an executive student theatre board that produces 6+ shows a year that are written by fellow undergraduate students. Want to learn more? Check out our website at http://www.vertigoplays.org/ or reach out to tessa@u.northwetsern.edu

value.Name: Vibrant Colors Collective
value.Description: At VC², we color OUTSIDE the lines: VC² is a Northwestern theater organization that strives to approach and produce theatre through a multicultural lens. We are devoted entirely to producing theater for the communities that have been historically silenced- not just at Northwestern, but in the theater community as a whole. Our objective is to spark a conversation about the space and lack thereof marginalized communities have had in the theater community and PWI spaces. We aim to provide them the space to experience joy and positivity while celebrating their CULTURE and VIBRANCY on the stage.
value.Summary: Northwestern's only multicultural student theatre board.

value.Name: Vietnamese Student Association
value.Description: VSA is for everyone who has an interest in the Vietnamese culture. VSA exists in order to promote awareness of and appreciation for Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture and history within the student body as well as to form a mutual relationship between Northwestern University and the local Vietnamese community. We host a variety of social and cultural events, such as Pho Outings, Tet Night, and SEA Night, and attend different conferences with other VSAs in the area. We also do a lot of collaborated events with other VSAs, primarily at UIC, Loyola, and UIUC. You do not have to be Vietnamese to join!
value.Summary: VSA exists in order to promote awareness of and appreciation for Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture and history.  You do not have to be Vietnamese to join! We are actively seeking new members, and currently offer junior exec positions!

Competition schedule:

Generally three tournaments in the fall finishing with the Big Ten Championships / Then approximately one or two tournaments in winter and spring quarters / One home tournament a year (generally held in the winter) / Womens tournaments in spring

value.Name: WAVE Productions
value.Description:
WAVE Productions (WAVE) is a self-supporting, not-for-profit student theatre company operating primarily on Northwestern University’s Evanston Campus. WAVE Productions exists to open the door to a better future. We strive to produce stories the campus needs by empowering our peer collaborators in pursuit of their passions and growth.

To fulfill its responsibility to the Northwestern University campus and surrounding communities, WAVE sets for itself the following objectives:

-    To sustain and nourish a dynamic and progressive presence on campus in large part by fostering a diverse theatrical season.

-    To provide an environment in which students can educate and empower themselves and others through the art and business of theatre.

-    To create a supportive community and provide a safe environment in which creativity can flourish.

-    To encourage ongoing exploration, discovery, and reflection through theatre.

-    To engage and provoke response within our communities by striving to produce stories the campus needs to hear.

-    To inspire new theatre artists and audiences.
value.Summary: WAVE Productions exists to open the door to a better future. We strive to produce stories the campus needs by empowering our peer collaborators in pursuit of their passions and growth.

value.Name: WE ARE SAATH
value.Description:
We mobilize communities around mental health awareness and highlight its intersectionality with cross-cultural issues in social justice.

We educate our community with evidence-based information about mental health challenges, treatments, and resources.

We amplify voices in the South Asian community, creating platforms to share stories.
value.Summary: Increasing access to Mental Health resources for the South Asian community through education, activism, and storytelling.

value.Name: Werewolves Club
value.Description:
Werewolf is basically poker, plus rationalization, minus cards and betting. During the game, each player needs to logically come up with convincing speeches and reasonable deductions within a very short period of time.


Many have found that they have become better at critical thinking and making impromptu speeches after participating. More importantly, they develop strong bonds among themselves while having great fun. This game is extremely popular among both undergraduate and graduate students (our first few trial events have attracted around 50 students each time). However, many students tend to stick to their own local groups and do not have the chance of meeting new players due to the lack of interaction between graduates and undergraduates. Also, it is very hard for them to find enough people each time. Our aim is to provide such
an opportunity to bring these excellent players together and help them meet new people, so they can share new strategies and improve their conversation and networking skills. Players of any experience level are welcome, and our members are ready and able to teach the game to any new players. We intend to host a weekly event for both undergraduates and graduates and participate in national tournaments (which are hosted sporadically). At this stage we mainly focus on Werewolves using Chinese, but ultimately we would like to include players from all of the world and introduce more strategic board games to our members.
value.Summary: Our organization mainly hosts ‘The Werewolves of Millers Hollow’ (‘Werewolves’ in shorthand), which is a strategic board game involving 8 and 18 players debating.

value.Name: Wild Roots
value.Description:
Wild Roots Garden was founded at Northwestern University in the fall of 2009 through a collaboration between the One Book One Northwestern project, three undergraduate environmental student organizations (SEED, ECO, and ESW), Facilities Management, the graduate student garden, and Norris University Center.   Today, Wild Roots is managed by undergraduate students.  Our fresh produce is harvested and donated to community groups in Evanston. During the school year, we work with other environmental student groups to host fun and educational events on campus.

We are located on the south lawn of Norris University Center (outside of Norbucks).  Come visit us!
value.Summary: Wild Roots is a student-directed garden that grows fresh produce for the Northwestern and Evanston communities using sustainable practices.

value.Name: Wildcat Connection Pages
value.Description: Wildcat Connection is managed by representatives in Student Organizations & Activities as well as Student Affairs IT.
value.Summary: Wildcat Connection is the directory for student organizations, campus departments, fraternity/sorority chapters, and more.

value.Name: Wildcat Welcome
value.Description:
Be a Part of Wildcat Welcome!

Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors Can Apply to Be on the Wildcat Welcome Staff

The Office of New Student and Family Programs relies heavily on student volunteers to plan and execute Wildcat Welcome and Parents' Weekend. Freshmen, sophomores and juniors can apply for two positions within the Wildcat Welcome staff structure starting late Fall Quarter and ending mid-Winter Quarter. The positions include the Board of Directors, and Peer Advisers.

Requirements and Characteristics of Staff Members

Applicants should display exceptional communication, organizational and interpersonal skills,  a positive attitude and passion a for WW, Northwestern University and new students. If you want to be a staff member, we expect you to...

- Devote the majority of your time to Wildcat Welcome activities during the week of Wildcat Welcome

- Be motivating, spirited, and enthusiastic

- Have a positive attitude

- Demonstrate excellent communication skills

- Demonstrate exceptional interpersonal relationship skills

- Be organized, flexible, mature, and professional

- Be passionate about Wildcat Welcome, Northwestern University, and new students’ need

- Serve as a role model and mentor

- Be open-minded toward diverse cultures, ethnicities, lifestyles, and backgrounds

Duties of Wildcat Welcome Staff Members

- Attend all  trainings and meetings during Spring Quarter--an attendance policy will be in effect

- Maintain close communication with your Board liaison or freshmen over the summer for Wildcat Welcome updates, answers to questions, and concerns

- Attend One-Day Intensive Training, one day prior to the beginning of Wildcat Welcome

- Assist with new student move-in at assigned residence hall area. This includes check-in, moving boxes, conversing with parents and family members, and creating a welcoming environment

- Attendance at required assigned Wildcat Welcome events and activities

- Wildcat Welcome responsibilities associated with your particular school

- Assist with implementing the Essential NUs

- Attendance at all sessions, social activities, President’s Convocation, and various other Wildcat Welcome events

- Lead thoughtful and effective discussions after Essential NU sessions. Topics include diversity, safety, alcohol, etc.

- Answer all new students’ questions with honest and appropriate answers

- Coordinate solutions to problems, issues, or emergencies encountered during Wildcat Welcome

- Be prepared to devote the majority, if not all of your time during Wildcat Welcome to Wildcat Welcome events

- Assist with assigned Academic School’s Dean’s Convocation
value.Summary:
Be a Part of Wildcat Welcome!
Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors Can Apply to Be on the Wildcat Welcome Staff!
The Office of New Student and Family Programs relies heavily on student volunteers to plan and execute Wildcat Welcome and more!

value.Name: Wildcats for Israel
value.Description: Wildcats for Israel invites the Northwestern community into a deeper conversation about Israel through dynamic educational and cultural events. Wildcats finds speakers and organizations that promote a more well-rounded understanding of Israeli past, present, and future. Wildcats is a non-partisan organization welcoming participants of various ethnicities, religions, and backgrounds.
value.Summary: Wildcats for Israel is Northwestern's pro-Israel group on campus that strives to advocate, educate and discuss all topics concerning Israel including culture, politics, and history.
